text: Tuesday, 16 August 2005 ----

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: Unknown
text: Hon. David Hawker) took the chair at 2 pm, and read prayers. NA

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: MINISTERIAL ARRANGEMENTS
text: Further to my advice to the House last week, the Minister for Human Services will be absent from question time today and for the remainder of this week. I also inform the House that the Minister for Ageing will be absent from question time today for personal reasons. The Minister for Health and Ageing will answer questions on behalf of both the absent ministers. NA Workplace Relations

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer to the fact that yesterday the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations said: I'm sure there will be a Senate inquiry ... I'm one whose making the suggestion we have a Senate inquiry. So we'll have one and it will be something of the Government's doing. I also refer to the fact that last night the Prime Minister said, ‘We're running a bit ahead of ourselves.' Can the Prime Minister clear up this confusion and tell the House will there or won't there be a Senate inquiry into the government's extreme industrial relations changes?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There will not be a Senate inquiry into an extreme industrial relations proposal because there is no such proposal. I want to make that perfectly clear. But the question of whether there will be a Senate inquiry into this or any other piece of legislation will, of course, be a matter for the Senate. I do not hold the view of my predecessors that the Senate is unrepresentative swill. I hold the view that the Senate is the expression of the will of the Australian people, just as this House is. Economy

Speaker: Mr BAIRD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of recent comments on the outlook for the Australian economy? What is required to ensure that Australia's economic strength is sustained?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Cook for his question and for the work that he did on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration when his committee took the semiannual testimony from the Governor of the Reserve Bank in Melbourne on Friday. I think the honourable member will agree with me that the outlook which was presented by the Reserve Bank governor was pretty upbeat. He noticed that consumer demand had slowed and there was a consolidation of the household balance sheets going on but also that the economy was showing good growth, particularly in employment and investment. In quite colourful language, the Governor of the Reserve Bank described the low-inflation outlook for the Australian economy as ‘nirvana'-a more colourful word than I would use or the government would use. They were the words of the Reserve Bank governor. He also said in his testimony: This is a pretty comfortable position in which to be. We are not expecting to change monetary policy in the near term, and when we look further into the future we no longer see a clear probability of it moving in one direction rather than the other. So that is a pretty stable outlook, and I have always said that if we keep inflation low in Australia we can keep interest rates low. That optimistic testimony from the Reserve Bank governor no doubt comes as a severe shock to the shadow Treasurer, the member for Lilley, who in extraordinary scenes in April, expecting an interest rate rise, wired himself into a TV studio so he could give a live commentary on what he expected would be an interest rate rise. I have seen a lot of shadow Treasurers but I have never seen one so opportunistic as to get into a studio at 9.30 on the day after the Reserve Bank board meeting so that he could weep crocodile tears about an interest rate rise that he was expecting. He was severely embarrassed when interest rates did not rise that day and, instead of being glad for millions of Australians, he attacked the central bank for not raising interest rates. He said: They barked a lot but they only bit once, so very hard for them to be taken seriously now. That is what Labor understands by an independent central bank. He went on: You don't go barking for months like they did then just give a nibble. We have seen some opportunists come and go as shadow Treasurer, but we have never seen one of the dimension of the member for Lilley. He no doubt was disappointed by the testimony which was given by the central bank governor in Melbourne last Friday, but millions of Australians will not be because they know that low inflation means low interest rates. Under this government they have had a chance on their mortgages, they have had a chance with their jobs and good economic management will keep on coming.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. Given the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts is recommending a $3 billion Telstra fund, does the Treasurer stand by his earlier claims about what this means for the economy and interest rates? Treasurer, is a $3 billion fund fiscally irresponsible and a risk to interest rates?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I can say this: it is not the greatest risk to interest rates in Australia. The greatest risk to interest rates in Australia would be you becoming Treasurer of this country. I can think of millions of Australians falling into threat, but you getting into government would be the greatest threat to the well-being of millions of Australians. So, having relieved ourselves of that threat in the near future, we will go on and we will talk about Telstra. I say to the member for Lilley, who apparently is now apprised of what the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has recommended to the it's cabinet-I must say, it comes as news to me, but then again the member for Lilley no doubt has inserted his little listening devices in the cabinet room and he knows what is and going on-in relation to Telstra that it is certainly the view of the government and I think of most analysts that the ownership of Telstra has to be resolved. It can be either fully nationalised or fully privatised. I do not believe there is anybody in Australia that believes that it should be fully nationalised; therefore, its status can only be resolved in one way. Can I also make it clear that this government believe that the proceeds of the sale of a capital asset should be invested for future generations. That is what we have always done in relation to retiring debt. In relation to retiring debt, have a look at the record. The Telstra record is this: when this government were elected Commonwealth net debt was $96 billion. By the end of the last financial year we had relieved future Australian generations of $80 billion of Labor debt. If you reduce debt by $80 billionMr Tanner-Anybody can sell assets.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Let me take that interjection. The member for Melbourne said, ‘Anybody can reduce debt by selling an asset.' That is what he said. The Labor Party sold off Qantas and increased debt in the same year. The Labor Party sold off the Commonwealth Bank and increased debt in the same year.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I go to a point of order on relevance. The Treasurer a week ago said that a proposition to put $2 billion aside from the sale of Telstra would threaten interest rates. His question was: what will billion do? Can we kindly get an answer to it?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. I remind the Treasurer that interjections are disorderly and I would ask him to return to his answer.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The point I was making was that this government has believed that when you sell a capital asset you should replace it with further assets or retire debt, and the point I made is that the Australian Labor Party not only sold a capital asset and spent the proceeds in one year but increased debt simultaneously. That is a trifecta.

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, this is the bloke who went around talking about the $2 billion increasing interest rates. Answer a question or two on it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. If he wishes raise a point of order he should make it clear that he is doing so. Before calling the next question, could I remind the Treasurer that the use of the word ‘you' in reference to other member is strongly discouraged. Free Trade Agreements

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. Would the Deputy Prime Minister, in his capacity as Minister for Trade, outline to the House the benefits that have accrued to Australian exporters through free trade agreements with Singapore and Thailand?

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Hinkler for his question. As he knows, a number of his own constituents have been beneficiaries of the free trade agreements that have been negotiated with Thailand and Singapore-a policy perspective, I suppose it is fair enough to say, that has been opposed all the way by the Australian Labor Party. None$3 the less, it is an indication of our government getting on with the job of improving the circumstances for Australians and providing more opportunities both at home and abroad for the Australian business community. The Thai and Singapore FTAs are delivering real benefits to Australian exporters, particularly those in the electorate of Hinkler. The Singapore free trade agreement entered into force two years ago and since then Austrade has assisted 454 companies enter into the market, and over half of those were actually new exporters entering the Singaporean market for the first time. That effort has delivered an extra $320 million worth of additional exports, just into that market alone, as a result of the Singapore-Australia Free Trade Agreement. As far as Thailand is concerned-and of course the Thai FTA has not been going for a full 12 months-Australia's merchandise to exports to Thailand have grown 40 per cent since 1 January this year when the FTA came into force. Total two-way trade with Thailand is now over $8 billion, which is quite signifian- cant. The areas of improvement with Thailand include a 43 per cent increase in the export of wine, a 19 per cent increase of pharmaceutical products, a 25 per cent increase in aluminium and a 62 per cent increase in fresh fruit and nut products going into the Thai market. So the point here is that the exercise of negotiating bilateral free trade agreements is absolutely imperative to our effort to see economic growth across Australia as far as our exporters are concerned. The company in the electorate of the member for Hinkler that has done extremely well out of these negotiated outcomes is a company called Austchilli that exports chilli products and food additives across the world. They have taken advantage of these agreements in exporting product into Singaporenot to mention another company, in Western Australia in the electorate of Canning. I am sure the member for Canning would recognise a company called Edwards Hot Water from Canning. They are now exporting hot water systems into Thailand. So there are primary products but also manufactured goods going out of Australia into these markets, sustaining Australian jobs in the Australian economy-jobs that we want to see sustained for many years into the future. We have embarked upon a serious reform program over the years, including targeting bilateral free trade agreements to enhance opportunities for Australian businesses so they can generate more employment in the Australian economy. The reforms that we propose today, particularly the industered trial relations reforms, are targeted and aimed at doing exactly the same things as far as the work force in Australia is concerned. Trade Practices Legislation

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Treasurer. Will the Treasurer confirm that in relation to negotiating one on one with big business he said recently to the Emerald Hill Weekly, ‘I don't know that small businesses are necessarily disadvantaged'? Will the Treasurer confirm that he also said on the question of whether a person such as a small business person would have access to collective bargaining, ‘Well, it's question of choice'? Given these statements, will the Treasurer guarantee to small business people like Bob, an owner-driver whom I met today, that they will be able to choose to bargain collectively represented by a union under the government's trade practices legislation, a choice Bob wants to make because of his concerns about his safety, the safety of others on the road and his family's livelihood?

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Under the Trade Practices Act people can bargain collectively as long as they give notification; otherwise, it would be construed as anticompetitive conduct. The government has put in place procedures which will make it easier to engage in collective negotiation of small business even though, prima facie, it is considered anticompetitive conduct under the Trade Practices Act. But the government does not propose to allow the Trade Practices Act to become a vehicle for trade unionism. The Trade Practices Act is a vehicle which regulates economic relations. It is the Industrial Relations Act that regulates trade unionism and it is under the Industrial Relations Act that trade unions register and get members. I have never seen a trade union yet have itself regisunder the Trade Practices Act and get legal personality, corporate status, the rules approved and its elections conducted under the Trade Practices Act. That is done under the Industrial Relations Act. That will not be changing under the new system. The Trade Practices Act will continue to regulate economic activity. Indonesia: Aceh

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will the minister update the House on the signing yesterday of a peace agreement for Indonesia's Aceh province? What impact a will this have on Australia's post-tsunami rehabilitation assistance?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Deakin for his question. I am not surprised he is interested as he was part of the parliamentary delegation that visited Aceh in June. I appreciate the insights he has brought back and I know his constituents appreciate his interest as well. The government warmly welcomes the signing of the historic agreement to end hostilities between the government of Indonesia and the Free Aceh Movement, known as GAM. That agreement was signed in Helsinki. This is a tragic conflict which has lasted for over three decades and it has brought enormous suffering to the people of Aceh and more broadly to Indonesia. It is estimated that there have been something like 15,000 people killed as a result of this conflict. This is a peace agreement that offers a real opportunity for lasting peace for the people of Aceh who, after all, are still rebuilding their lives after the devastating tsunami of Boxing Day last year. I can only congratulate both sides on this achievement. When Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono became the President of Indonesia he said, amongst other things, probably to the Prime Minister but also to me and to others, that he wanted to resolve the Aceh problem peacefully. He did not want to use military means to resolve it. This agreement is an enormous tribute to President Yudhoyono and to his team. They have done an extraordinarily good job in the most difficult of circumstances. I do not detract from the credit that must be given to the Free Aceh Movement as well. They deserve credit from their perspective. I think President Yudhoyono has done a great thing here, and we very much hope that this peace agreement will stick and that both sides will fulfil their obligations under the agreement. It is significant that, as I have mentioned already, it is in Aceh itself where reconstructration tion is taking place. The fact of peace breaking out in Aceh will obviously facilitate the reconstruction work post tsunami. We have already allocated an initial $50 million rehabilitation package to Aceh as part of our $1 billion, five-year funding under the Australia-Indonesia Partnership for Reconstruction and Development. This will make it all the easier to help rebuild Aceh. In conclusion, there is to be an Aceh monitoring mission. It will be of about 200 to 250 personnel. They will be from the European Union and ASEAN. They will do a good job overseeing the implementation of this agreement and we will always be happy to provide logistical assistance to that peace monitoring team should they require any logistical assistance from Australia. Trade Practices Legislation

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Prime Minister and follows from the answer the Treasurer has just given. I draw the Prime Minister's attention to the reduction in the rates of pay, lowering of safety standards and the stifling of small business investment that arises as a result of the government's proposed amendment to the Trade Practices Act. Will the Prime Minister withdraw the bill to allow small business people, like the members of the TWU in the gallery today, to choose how they negotiate their rates of pay and personal safety rather than remove the ability of small businesses to choose?

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The government will be proceeding with the amendments to the Trade Practices Act. The main reason we are proceeding with those amendments is that they enhance the bargaining capacity of small business. That is the reason we are going to proceed with them. As the Treasurer correctly said, he is not aware, and I am not aware, of a union that has ever sought regisunder the Trade Practices Act or sought to have its rules and the conduct of its affairs governed by the Trade Practices Act. The Leader of the Opposition knows that this is a ridiculous proposition, but of course maintaining the position that he does is entirely consistent with the cherry-picking approach the Labor Party has always adopted to the rights of trade unions under the law of Australia. This House will remember that for years and years the Labor Party argued that the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act, which regulated commercial conduct, should be taken out of the Trade Practices Act and put into the Industrial Relations Act. Why? Because those provisions would be ineffective as part of the Industrial Relations Act. The proposition of the Leader of the Opposition is not one to advance the interests small business. Small business will be advantaged by our amendment, just as small business will be advantaged by the changes we propose to the Workplace Relations Act and just as small business has been advantaged by the reductions in interest rates. I will wager that every person to whom the Leader of the Opposition has spoken today has been a beneficiary of the enhanced economic conditions of the last 9½ years. If those conditions are to be maintained and strengthened in the future, instead of opposing what the government is doing, the Leader of the Opposition should be getting behind not only the amendments to the Trade Practices Act but also the amendments to the Workplace Relations Act. Workplace Relations

Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations. Would the minister inform the House how the new workplace relations system will protect vulnerable workers? Are there any alternative views?

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Stirling for his question and his interest in this subject. I can inform him and the House that, under the new workplace relations system, workers will continue to be protected against inappropriate conduct by employers. For example, it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss or to victimise an employee for refusing to agree to a new workplace agreement. The Office of the Employment Advocate will continue to provide a strong inspection service and, indeed, in 2003-04 the Office of Workplace Services concluded more than 4,700 investigations into breaches of federal industrial laws. Under our proposals, it will continue to be unlawful for employees to be dismissed for refusing to sign an AWA, for example. This will not change. It will continue to be unlawof ful to dismiss a person taking temporary absence from work due to illness or disability. It will continue to be unlawful to dismiss a worker who is absent from work because of their family responsibilities. And it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss a worker in relation to the filing of a complaint or participating in proceedings against an employer involved in an alleged violation of laws or regulations. None of these things will change under these proposals. I see that the ACTU has put out another booklet setting out some scenarios. What it fails to point out is that these scenarios, even if they are true, are unlawful under the current provisions and will remain unlawful in the future. What we see from the ACTU is a campaign in which it is happier to exploit and manipulate workers than to actually tell them the truth. The depth of this campaign was revealed last Wednesday evening on the Lateline program when the President of the ACTU, Sharan Burrow, was filmed at an ACTU campaign meeting in which she is recorded on film as saying: I need a mum or a dad of someone who's been seriously injured or killed. That would be fantastic. That is an absolute disgrace. It is deeply offensive to all decent Australians that the President of the ACTU would be saying on film at a campaign meeting that what it needs is the parent of a dead or injured worker in order to continue its politically motivated campaign. That is shocking. It is a disgrace. The President of the ACTU had a chance this morning on radio in Adelaide, on the Leon Byner program, to retract that disgraceful statement and she said, ‘I make no apology for that.' This is a statement for which there is no defence. There is no defence for saying, ‘We should run a political campaign off the back of a seriously injured or dead worker in Australia.' Yet that is what the ACTU is saying. It is disgraceful. The former presidents of the ACTU are in here-the member for Throsby, the member for Batman, the member for Hotham. I do not believe that they would have said something like that. I invite them to get on the phone this afternoon and ask Sharan Burrow to retract this disgraceful statement. This is offensive-deeply offensive. It ought to be retracted. Skilled Workers

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Won't the latest push for yet another 20,000 skilled migrants next year bring the total number of extra skilled migrants under the Howard government to 270,000? Isn't it true that the Howard government has turned away 270,000 Australians from TAFE since 1998? Doesn't this mean that for every extra skilled migrant the Howard government has imported at least one Australian has been turned away from TAFE? Why isn't the Howard government's priority training Australians first?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Jagajaga for her question. I am very shocked to think that the Australian Labor Party, the alternative government in this place, would want to talk down those who have come to Australia with skills that we need in our economy. In fact, to try to defeat the notion that migration is somehow something less than a nation-building exercise invites a very simple observation. When the Labor Party was last in power, 60 per cent of the people arriving in this country went on welfare. Under this government, over 60 per cent of people arriving in this country under a migration program that is focusing on Australia's interests and on Australia's terms and conditions are going into jobs. This government has delivered higher levels of apprentices in training. This government has delivered higher levels of people taking on training and higher levels of people completing training. We have put all of that in place. At the same time, we know that in order to gear up Australia for the future we will have new innovation and new opportunity that we will present to the generations to come. If the Labor Party really cared about getting people into training they would do a couple of things. First, they would stand against the TAFE fee increases that the states have presided over-and they will instantly take a point order because they know I am right. Ms Macklin- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The question is about the 270,000 Australians who have been turned away from TAFE. What are you going to do about that?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The question is also about the 100,000 or more who did not get a start in TAFE because the fees went up. Over 100,000 people walked away from TAFE opportunities because the states put fees up. The question is also about the 143,000 people who are being offered an opportunity under the new national training agreement, which the Labor states have yet to sign up toMs Macklin interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The deputy leader has asked her question.

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: If the member for Jagajaga were really concerned about more training opportunities for Australians she would urge the union leadership in each of the various states and territories to get phone to their state education and training minister and urge them to sign up to the new national training agreement which will instantly deliver over 140,000 extra training places for Australians-and they can do it now. But in doing so, in trying to establish her case, the member for Jagajaga is talking down the contributions of migration to Australia's economy. She should be ashamed. This sort of xenophobic, picking on the minority, approach from those opposite places them, in the minds of average Australians, in every possible way, as being ill-suited to ever taking over on this side of the House.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Were such a remark specifically directed at me, I would be offended by it. On behalf of the members, a remark that suggests that a member is xenophobic is offensive and should be withdrawn. It comes ill from a minister who is part of a government that supported Pauline Hanson.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There is no point of order. Middle East

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the government's reaction to Israel's disengagement from Gaza? What has Australia been doing in response to this initiative?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Wentworth and acknowledge the great interest he has in the Middle East. I appreciate his interest in asking this question. Prime Minister Sharon's disengagement initiative is, I think, a very positive step taken by him and the Israeli government towards bringing about the goals of the road map for the Middle East, which our government strongly supports. I want to make this point because I do not think it is made often enough. Prime Minister Sharon deserves on the enormous credit for the courage he has shown in taking this extraordinarily difficult and sensitive step. I would also like to acknowledge the professionalism of the Israeli defence forces in carrying out this decision, because it has obviously been very sensitive as well. I think that so far they have handled it very well. We would encourage Israel to continue to maintain their efforts. Likewise, I welcome Palestinian President Abbas's commitment to stopping terrorism and incitement to further bloodshed in the context of the disengagement. It is obviously important that the Palestinian authority is firmly able to control law and order and to ensure that this process of disengagement is not in any way disrupted by terrorists. I would urge all Palestinians not to waste this opportunity that has been provided. I hope that both sides can now build constructively on the momentum of disengagement. The honourable member for Wentworth asked what Australia was doing about it. We announced a week or so ago a tangible contribution to the disengagement process with the secondment of an Army officer to the international Security Sector Working Group. I have also been talking with Jim Wolfensohn-who, honourable members will recall, was the Australian President of the World Bank; he is now the quartet's Special Envoy for Disengagement-on ways that Australia can make a significant contribution through our aid budget to making sure that disengagement works. We have been discussing particular projects to assist the Palestinians in the context of disengagementparticularly to assist Palestinians obtain work and to develop business opportunities. I really do want to emphasise the admiration we in this government have for the decision that Prime Minister Sharon and the Israeli government have taken to make this big step of disengagement. It is difficult. It has been politically very challenging for them to do it. Ministers and parliamentary supporters and campaign workers have been politically lost during this process, but Prime Minister Sharon has stuck with it and he deserves great credit for it. Regional Partnerships

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. Can the minister confirm that he approved a $1.2 million Regional Partnerships grant for the Primary Energy ethanol project in the former Deputy Prime Minister's electorate, despite the fact that the ject failed to meet program guidelines? Did the project fall outside Regional Partnerships guidelines because it sought funding for planning activities and a prospectus? Minister, was Primary Energy in fact a singleshare $1 shelf company?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Once again, the Labor Party are showing how little they understand the importance of Regional Partnerships in the community. They have mounted a politically motivated attack on a very important program which is providing tremendous support to communities throughout Australia. The decision taken by me was consistent with the Regional Partnerships guidelines. However, as is allowed under the Strategic Opportunities Notional Allocations guidelines, the normal exclusions for the prospectus were waived because of the significant potential national benefit of the project. The Labor Party laugh and joke about this project. I remind the Labor Party that, in a letter sent to the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, on 14 February 2005, Ian Kiernan AO, the Chairman of Primary Energy, reminded the Leader of the Opposition of the benefits of this project. They included the project's capital expenditure of $100 million, annual operation expenditure of $81 million, expansion of the local economy base of $170 million, generation of an additional $30 million in household income per year, farmer sustainability, additional grain markets, $47 million in export income, $88 million in domestic revenue and, most importantly, 40 permanent jobs, 500 construction positions, 350 permanent employment positionsMrs Irwin- Mr Speaker, it is quite obvious that the minister

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Is this on a point of order? Mrs Irwin-Yes, it is. The point of order prois on relevance. It is quite obvious that the minister is not answering the question. The question was

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member will resume her seat. The minister has completed his answer. Mr Ripoll- Mr Speaker, could you ask the minister to table the document from which he extensively read?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Was the minister reading from a confidential document? The minister was reading from a confidential document. Influenza

Speaker: Mrs DRAPER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister update the House on how the government is preparing to meet the potential threat of a new flu pandemic?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Makin for her question. I can advise the House that, so far, the government has spent some $160 million to prepare our country against this potential threat. There are 21 thermal imaging screeners that could be deployed to airports within hours of a possible human pandemic outbreak. The government is stockpiling 40 million surgical masks, 50 million syringes and 303 ventilators. There are six quarantine centres prepared to deal with some 500 people each. On a per capita basis we have the world's largest stockpile of antivirals after Finland. Also, the government is upgrading the World Health Organisation collaborating influenza laboratory in Melbourne and, most recently, the government has committed almost $5 million to ensure that a candidate vaccine against pandemic flu starts trials next month. That is the latest advice I have from CSL. In addition, a live exercise to test our pandemic preparedness will take place in November. We cannot tell if, or when, there will be a pandemic flu outbreak but, according to the World Health Organisation, Australia is as well prepared as any other country to meet this potential public health disaster. Regional Partnerships

Speaker: Mr LLOYD

Mr Crean- Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order which goes to relevance and the specific confinement of this question. Why won't the minister answer these questions?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Braddon has the call. Insurance Premiums

Speaker: Mr BAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer. Would the minister inform the House how the government has helped to reduce premiums for public liability and professional indemnity insurance?

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Braddon for his question and his obvious interest in the business and community associations in his electorate that understand the significance of the availability and the affordability of insurance. Members of the House will only too well remember the collapse of HIH and the fact that the federal government committed some $640 million to the HIH Claims Support Scheme to ensure that insurance would be available to businesses and community groups at that most challenging time. I congratulate the states for working with the leadership of the federal government at the time to ensure the tort law reform that came in. I report to the House today that the ACCC and APRA surveys, two independent surveys, have now confirmed that the downward pressure that we were trying to achieve on premiums has been achieved with up to a 4.8 per cent reduction in public liability and professional indemnity insurance premiums. That is good news for Australian businesses. But unfortunately there are still some real impediments to the affordability of business insurance, public liability insurance and professional indemnity insurance: Labor state and territory governments. In New South Wales metropolitan areas, for every $100 that a business pays in business insurance premiums, an extra $37 goes to the state in the form of taxation. In metrothat politan Victoria, for every $100, an extra $38 goes to the state Labor government in taxes. But in regional Victoria-and I do not know how any business can survive there-they are hit with a massive 82 per cent. For every $100 of premium paid, there is an extra $82 in state taxes collected by the Victorian ernment in the form of the fire services levy, GST and stamp duty-82 per cent. So, on one hand, whilst the Labor governments have worked well to bring down tort law reform and that is having downward pressure overall on premiums, on the other hand, the state Labor governments continue to charge these exorbitant taxes and taxes on taxes to our business community stymieing the growth of business. I have one example here from a small delicatessen in regional Victoria-no doubt a mum and dad operationwhose premium was $2,191 but, when you add state Labor taxes, it jumps to $3,158. Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Leader of the Opposition says that it is GST. It is in fact the fire services levy and stamp duty. The study of the Insurance Council of Australia indicates that over the last five years state Labor governments have increased their take of state taxes on insurance premiums by 51 per cent. They are now collecting $3.2 billionmoney that could be well spent on creating more jobs in regional Victoria, in metropolitan New South Wales and throughout Australia. The Labor Party not only stands for higher taxes but delivers higher taxes. Regional Partnerships

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is again to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads. Minister, was departmental advice about the Primary Energy grant changed after the senior adviser to the Deputy Prime Minister wrote to the minister's department in July last year instructing the grant be approved and moneys paid as a matter of urgency, or was it changed because referees for the application included the then Deputy Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade, the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, a senior adviser to the Prime Minister and the Associate Secretary of the gov- Prime Minister's department?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Where a project is considered under Regional Partnerships and is located in a minister's electorate, it is normal practice for another minister in the portfolio to act as the decision maker for that project, which is of course quite proper to do. In accordance with this established procedure, Minister Campbell, at that time, was the decision maker on Primary Energy. Minister Campbell, in his then role as the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, asked the department to progress the application. I signed off on this project on 27 July 2004. Again, I remind the House of the importance of this project to that community and the importance of Regional Partnerships to communities around Australia. Mr Ripoll- Mr Speaker, could you ask the minister to table the document which he was obviously reading from?

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Was the minister reading from a confidential document?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Yes. Petrol Sniffing

Speaker: Mr TOLLNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister inform the House how the government is working to reduce the incidence of petrol sniffing in mote Indigenous communities, particularly those in the Northern Territory?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Solomon for his question. I appreciate how serious this problem is in the Northern Territo tory and in other remote Indigenous communities around Australia. I regret to tell the House that the advice I have is that petrol sniffing has claimed some 100 lives over the last couple of decades. Under a scheme operating since 1998, the government is supplying unsniffable petrol to some 42 remote Indigenous communities. In the recent budget the government committed a further $9 million to supply unsniffable petrol to another 23 remote Indigenous communities, and the government is currently talking to the Northern Territory government about a possible further extension of the scheme to include a wide area of Central Australia. This government certainly will not leave vulnerable communities to cope on their own. As people like Noel Pearson have recognised, in the end benevolent government is not capable of solving all the problems of these communities. Some communities such as Yuendumu have successfully tackled this problem by quite literally taking sniffers by the scruff of the neck and sending them to rehabilitation at outstations such as Mount Theo. While I appreciate that what works in one place does not necessarily work elsewhere, I do commend the example of selfhelp at Yuendumu to all Indigenous communities that are afflicted by this terrible problem. Regional Partnerships

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads and follows from the previous questions asked. Can the minister confirm that more than $1 million of Regional Partnerships grants to Primary Energy has realready been paid? Can he confirm that this $1 shelf company received $426,800 simply for signing the funding contract with his department? Can he confirm that two payments of $342,100 and $235,400 have been made the company to assist it with travel costs and advice on tax avoidance? Finally, can the minister confirm that, despite receiving $1 million in taxpayer funding, this company is yet to produce a single litre of ethanol?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: What I can confirm is that the decision that was taken by me to approve that grant was consistent with the Regional Partnership guidelines. I have been in this House long enough to know that I will not just take the Leader of the Opposition's word on what he is asking. I will check the facts and, if I have anything of further substance that I should bring back to the House, I will do so. New Apprenticeships

Speaker: Mr CAMERON THOMPSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Would the minister inform the House of initiatives which are providing significant financial assistance to new apprentices and their employers?

Speaker: Mr HARDGRAVE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Blair for his question. Since 1996 there has been a 100 per cent increase in the number of new apprentices in training in the torate of Blair. That is an additional 860 ple who have had an opportunity not just simply to build the skills they need for today but also to become the leaders of tomorrow. On that theme, I want to acknowledge that Group Training Australia has today, as part of a three-day leadership course, here in the gallery 21 superior apprentices from the Australian work force who will become the leaders of tomorrow. Apprentices, as you know, are not simply creating opportunities for themselves; they go on to become employers themselves and give opportunities to the next lot of people who come along. That is something the member for Brand forgot when he was the minister in charge. We actually saw the record drop for people in training in those days. We are still paying the price for that. After question time, these 21 apprentices will be meeting with the Prime Minister, which is terrific. In answer to the member for Blair's question, each year the publicly funded training system in this country trains 1.7 million Australians, an increase of half a million since 1995. Over the next four years there will be $10.1 billion of Australian government investment. Leadership that we are providing at the national level, to try and coerce and encourage the state governments to realise their national obligations as well as their state imperatives, is absolutely critical. As part of our new support for apprentices in 2005-06 we are spending $587.1 million on a number of new initiatives. That will help to ease the financial burden for apprentices and their employers. The Commonwealth Trade Learning Scholarships-two payments of $500 for eligible new apprentices in skills needs trades-will assist around 90,000 new apprentices in the first two years alone. There is a new payment of $25 per week for the third-year apprentices who have moved away from their family elechomes. That will benefit about 3,000 annupeoally. That will mainly help people from rural and regional areas. It will bring, too, some 7,600 people who are benefiting under that approach, for the first, second and third years of their apprenticeships. As well, all employers who have made a significant contribution to a new apprentice's training will share in the $2,750 completion initiative recognising the commitment of employers who have provided 25 per cent or more of a new apprentice's training. Of course from 1 October we will start to see first year apprentices being able to gain access to the $800 tool kit allowance. That is a very popular initiative, let me tell you. With the extension of entitlements to Youth Allowance, Austudy and Abstudy to new apprentices, as many as 93,000 will benefit over three years. This government know that the economy is strong today. This government know that the training of apprentices is at record levels today, but we are not taking any of it for granted. We are looking at the years of the future and know that the investments we make today will build a long-term sustainable platform for the Australian economy. It is good for the individuals involved; it is great for Australia. Regional Partnerships

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads and relates to his approval of $1 million of taxpayers money to the Primary Energy ethanol project-a project which is yet to produce a litre of ethanol. Minister, can you confirm the existence of an original departmental brief recommending against providing funding to Primary Energy, the $1 shelf company that got the million dollars? Can the minister confirm that this departmental brief recommending against payment was intercepted by the acting departmental secretary?

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: What I can confirm is that Mr Martin Ferguson-Don't you know when you are making a fool of yourself. Answer the question.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The member for Batman!

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I signed off on a $1.21 million grant on the adviceMr Crean- Mr Speaker, on a point of order: we know what the minister signed off on. We want to know about the existence of a departmental brief recommending against it.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The member for Hotham will resume his seat. The minister has the call.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: This grant application was within the Regional Partnerships guidelines. The brief that was provided to me from my department, which I signed off on, approved the grant. Work for the Dole

Speaker: Mr RANDALL
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Workforce Participation. Would the minister inform the House of the benefits of Work for the Dole for job seekers? Are there any alternative views?

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am happy to sing the praises of Work for the Dole. In response to the member for Canning, when we came to government in 1996, under Labor unemployment had been at 9.1 per cent in the electorate of Canning. Today it is at six per cent, so congratulations to the member for Canning and congratulations to the Howard government for putting in place programs which reduce unemployment. We also know that, since 1997, 352,000 Australians have been helped through the Work for the Dole program. Many of them have gone on to work and many of them have benefited from a program that has helped them to understand work experience, working in a team environment and giving back to the community. We know that it has been a wonderful program.

Speaker: Unknown
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr DUTTON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There are always lots of interjections when we talk about Work for the Dole. So far there have been 334 occasions that members opposite have interjected and said that Work for the Dole is not a good program. I do not understand why the Labor Party hates Work for the Dole. It is very difficult to understand. What we need from Labor is a champion of Work for the Dole. Last week the member for Franklin had some sensible comments to make, so I call on him today: if he is interested in advancing the cause of the Labor Party, he should tell his leader and his colleagues to get behind Work for the Dole because it is a great program.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper. NA

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: DOCUMENTS
text: A document is tabled as listed in the schedule circulated to honourable members. Details of the document will be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings. NA Condolence Motion: Rt Hon. David Lange

Speaker: Mr MURPHY
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I would appreciate it if you would inform the House why there was no condolence motion in this place today to mark the passing of the former Prime Minister of New Zealand, the Rt Hon. David Lange.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: The Prime Minister has something to say on the matter.

Speaker: Mr HOWARD
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: With the indulgence of the parliament, I am very happy to respond to the member for Lowe. I did give some consideration to this. The normal practice of the parliament is, of course, to have condolence motions for former members of this House and then, as I understand it, by the decision of the government of the day in relation to other distinguished Australians and, from time to time, distinguished citizens of other countries. We, for example, have not had a condolence motion to mark the death of the former British Prime Minister Edward Heath-that is one name that comes to my mind. It is a question of judgment. By deciding not to have it I did not mean any disrespect to David Lange. I did make some comments in the media on behalf of the government, but there is no invariable rule, no custom and no convention of the past that says that every time the prime minister of a country with which this country has close relations dies we have a condolence motion. I would have to check the record; I am not certain that we, for example, had a condolence motion when the former Prime Minister of Japan, Mr Obuchi, died, although the Leader of the Opposition and I both attended his funeral in Tokyo. There was no disrespect. It is not because he was part of the Labour Party, let me assure you; it is simply that it has not been the custom always to do that. I think that in making a decision on balance not to do so I was merely reflecting the custom of the past. Questions in Writing

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, understanding order 105(b), I ask you to write to the Minister for Health and Ageing to seek an answer to my question No. 966.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Fraser. I will attend to that. Questions in Writing

Speaker: Ms ROXON
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, similarly, I ask for your assistance understanding order 105(b) to write to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence seeking an answer to question No. 1668. It is regarding Defence contracts and the government is now in the process of deciding on another one and has failed to answer my question.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: The member has raised her point. I will attend to that also. Standing Orders

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I seek a clarification understanding order 92. The member for Denison raised a point of order on an expression used by the Minister for Vocational and Technical Education. Standing order 89 provides that members may not use offensive words. The minister used the word ‘xenophobic', and I am wondering for the benefit of those new members in the House whether you could provide a clarification of that ruling.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Kingsford Smith. As I think the member for Denison acknowledged at the time, the minister's comment did not refer to a specific member. There have been many precedents where speakers in the past have not ruled such expressions to be offensive. Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: As the member for Batman reminds me, there are precedents that go the other way, but on balance I felt that this was not an occasion to ask for a withdrawal.

Speaker: Mr KERR
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I may be mistaken-if I am, excuse me-but I did raise the point of order on the understanding that it was specifically directed towards a member. It was my understanding that that was the case. I did not pursue the matter and, if the reason for you not accepting the point of order was that it was directed more generally towards all of us, I accept that, but I think if one examines what precisely was said it was directed towards a specific member and, in any case, as a member on this side I would object even were it to be directed to us generally, because this side of the House would regard it as extremely offensive to be labelled as xenophobic. Coming to the particular, if you check the Hansard I suspect you will discover that it was directed to a particular member.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Denison. Can I say that while the word ‘xenophobic' is not desirable I am not aware that it has been ruled unparliamentary before, but I will check it further. Questions in Writing

Speaker: Ms GRIERSON
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, understanding order 105(b), I ask that you write to the Treasurer seeking an answer to my question No. 703, placed on the Notice Paper on 7 March 2005.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO THE SPEAKER
text: I thank the member for Newcastle. I will follow the matter up. NA Telecommunications

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Brand proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the Government to provide and protect decent telecommunications services for all Australians. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: There is a most unseemly discussion going on among members of the government and in the dialogue between the government and broader community on the subject of propositions around the sale of the remaining publicly owned share of Telstra. Most Australians consider telecommunications to be a matter of deep concern for them and they consider the overall structure of the telecommunications system to be a vital matter of national interest. It has become a matter of horse-trading between various members of the government backbench as to how much the price will be for betraying the national interest. Will it be a $2 billion price of betrayal, a $3 billion price of betrayal or a $5 billion price of betrayal? What price will it be? The Australian people are very clear-cut on this issue. The Australian people have said emphatically and for some considerable time that they do not want Telstra sold. They do not want Telstra sold if $2 billion is available for the bush, they do not want Telstra sold if $3 billion is available for the bush; they want Telstra not to be sold. That is their position. They do not believe that a Telstra sold will be in either their interests or the national interest. They do not believe that, if Telstra is sold, the concerns they have for the quality of services will be alleviated. They do not believe that, if Telstra is sold, they will get a better price for telecommunications. They do not believe that, if Telstra is sold, it will produce the peak performance in our telecommunications system that they and their businesses now need from new investment in better and better telecommunications technology. They believe that they will be exploited and that their interests will be traduced. It is as simple as that. It is a simple proposition in the mind of the average Australian. And it is not just in the mind of the average Australian Labor voter; it is in the mind of the average Australian Liberal voter and in the mind of the average Australian National Party voter. All of them think this. This is as close to a unanimous point of view as our community ever gets on a major national issue. The government cannot make a case for the full privatisation of Telstra, just as not make a case for industrial relations changes or for voluntary student unionism. It cannot make a case because there is not one. All this government has is an extreme ideology. It is a government drunk with power, in total control of both houses of parliament. It will do this because it can. And in the absence of any evidence, what do we get from this government? We get a bad vaudeville act from ‘Backdown Barnaby'. In 48 hours, Barnaby Joyce, who promised the Queensland electorate not that he would sell Telstra for $2 billion, $3 billion or $5 billion but that he would not sell Telstra at all, is apparently prepared to sell it for $3 billion. That is what his commitment to his electorate is worth. I can tell Barnaby this: the Australian people consider the offset of $3 billion for a regional telecommunications program as a rationale for selling Telstra as a joke-a bad joke, but a joke. Frankly, if after 48 hours Barnaby Joyce decides that he will vote for the sale of Telstra, they will regard him as a bad joke as well, because those in Queensland who voted for him had the very distinct point of view that he would take a stand. They voted for him in quite large numbers on this specific and explicit issue. He ran on it and they expect him to vote against it. We see the Leader of the National Party, Mr Vaile, in his former role as auctioneer. He is auctioneering Telstra among his colleagues and within the government. He is playing the auctioneer's role in the cabinet and participating in the bidding process at the same time: ‘What am I bid? I'm bidding $2 billion.' Then the Queenslanders come in and say, ‘No, it's really five.' Then the new President of the Queensland Nationals says, ‘It's three plus three; with three we'll leverage another three.' I tell you what: I have never seen anything quite so unseemly as this process that the government has entered it caninto on telecommunications, nor anything quite so sickening for the average Australian who sees an asset of immense value to them simply wafting away on the government's prejudice, wafting away on an unseemly bargain-a pork barrel of our political opponents, particularly The Nationals. They believe that a privatised Telstra will produce rising prices. They have an example of that with the partial privatisation of Telstra which has seen line rentals rise form $11.65 to now around $30. They fear very much that what will occur if Telstra is sold is that they will become the subject of a quasi-monopoly operation on pricing. It is not just ordinary citizens who feel this. Businesses as well fear the consequences of a predatory privatised Telstra operating unchecked, full blooded, with an obligation on it-as it will have-to optimise the return for shareholders in every decision it takes, whether it be investment in new equipment and technology, whether it be in prices for access to its network or whether it be any of the other services it provides. I once had in this place responsibility for microeconomic reform in communications. I had responsibility for Telstra and I had responsibility for the possibility that Telstra would have competitors. One thing we understood absolutely when we were dealing with Telstra in that context was that we were dealing with what was largely a monopoly provider, that no other company was likely to obtain a position of equality with it. The most sensible thing that you could do to ensure that new technologies were introduced and that reasonable prices were charged to consumers was to offer a regulatory restraint on the main provider and opportunities for new companies to come in and compete with it. But you understood absolutely when you went through that process-and we took advice on this from people who had experience of introducing competition to telecommunications in other countries-that, while ever there was a monopoly or a substantially dominant provider, the very last thing you wanted to do if you wanted to ensure that people got the benefit of competition with regard to prices and new technologies was privatise the main provider. That was an absolute no-no, because you immediately got confusion in the Treasury and confusion with those responsible for selling it as to what their obligations were. Was their obligation to optimise returns for the taxpayer? Or was their obligation to get in place a system which was a good one for all consumers, a system which enabled or ensured that all consumers got the benefit of competition? It was a very important question. But nobody-absolutely nobody-thought for one minute that you would get an impetus from a privatised monopoly or market-dominant provider for the benefits of competition. You would get absolutely the opposite. There are all sorts of suggestions about putting in place a competitive arrangement that would hold its position in check. Quite frankly, none of those regulatory arrangements work. The simple fact of the matter is that a privatised Telstra will go full bore for shareholder benefit over consumer interest all the time. Frankly, it is obliged to. The people who are sitting on the board of a privatised Telstra would be liable to legal action from any one of the shareholders if they failed to perform accordingly. That goes for a whole range of other things as well, not just the price of Telstra's tricts.' services. It also goes for decisions on rolling out the communications system. You see, we do not necessarily have in this country the best system that we could have. Mr Trujillo, in assuming the CEO's job in Telstra, has been extraordinarily frank, I have got to say. He has walked in and said that if Australia is to have a telecommunications system remotely competitive with those countries with which it likes to compare itself, a truly massive investment is required. He is no doubt influenced by facts like this: Australia's broadband performance of 7.7 subscribers for every 100 people is the worse of any major industrialised country and is 21st in the developed world. What you have to understand these days, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, as I am sure you do, is that the difference between private communications and private consumption and a person's business interests has narrowed dramatically in the world of work that we now see. The average household needs access to broadband not simply for the kids' homework but, frankly, for the business interests of the people in the house. That is what they need it for. It is a major element of their capacity to successfully conduct themselves economically now from their household. So a statistic like that is horrendous. And it is no small wonder that, in this appalling auction that we see going on on the other side of the House, we finally see one or two people start to put up their hands and say: ‘Hey, hang on a tic. We're not just dealing with a bush problem here; we're dealing with a problem across the totality of the system. We're not just dealing with a situation that requires a $2 billion, $3 billion or $5 billion investment in the bush; we're dealing with a situation that requires massive investment across the whole country, across the outlying suburbs of the major metropolitan areas, up to and including our central business disWhat Mr Trujillo has pointed out to our community is that there is a massive capital investment job in front of Telstra. I tell you this, Mr Minister at the table and Mr Deputy Speaker: if you privatise Telstra now, in advance of even taking the first step on the ladder of that capital investment, you can absolutely guarantee that two things will happen. First, roll-out will be slow paced, as the argument on the Telstra board goes to optimising the value of existing infrastructure all the time. Every time you try to roll something out, someone will say, ‘Well, maybe that is in the interest of that business, the interest of our business.' That is the first thing that is going happen. The second thing that is going happen is that that roll-out is going to occur in the patchiest possible way. It will occur firstand maybe exclusively-only where there are sections of the community able to pay a substantial price for it. That will not include regional Australia and that will not include the outer metropolitan areas of our capital cities; it may include the central business districts. The patchwork that we now have of an inefficient system will be repeated and the new technologies will not be made available to all. Nobody can predict now what the technologies will be that will be absolutely essential 10 years from now. You simply cannot know. You cannot future-proof telecommunications. All you can do is put in place a structure that ensures that you have a capacity to influence, as time goes by, the roll-out of new opportunities. And the only way you can do that is if you have your hands on those levers and the ability to influence them. What this government now proposes to do will not only damage individual Australians; it will damage Australian businesses. It lacks common sense and it is sullied by the obscene horse-trading that is going on amongst National Party members to get themselves yet another slush fund. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Gippsland-Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry) (3.22 pm)-The government welcome this matter of public importance. Every opportunity we have to debate our achievements in office with regard to telecommunications and to outline our future plan, even vision, we will embrace. Unlike the Labor Party, we do not underestimate the capacity, intelligence and desire of the Australian people to fully examine this issue, given its economic and social but it's not in importance. The Labor Party has marginalised itself, and that is the kindest assessment one can give. A more ruthless assessment would have the Labor Party having rendered itself irrelevant in this debate, whereas the Australian people are deeply engaged in the issue of the privatisation of Telstra. Just rolling up the old bogyman of privatisation as an inherently evil thing consigns the Labor Party to total irrelevance. The Australian people have moved on. One of the reasons they have moved on, apart from their own developing interest in the vital issue of telecommunications, with all the ramifications for their daily lives and businesses and for the nation's future as well as its current prosperity, is that it was debated, discussed and voted upon in the 1996, 1998, 2001 and 2004 elections. ‘Stop underestimating Australian voters' would be my call to the Labor Party. Australians have looked at this issue election in, election out. Consequently, the mere raising of privatisation is not going to scare the horses. They want a more informed and serious debate of the kind that the Labor Party seems constitutionally incapable of having on the privatisation of Telstra. It is not just an issue of privatisation. It is about the full privatisation of Telstra, which has been the government's long standing policy-it is no surprise. We are not ambushing anybody; we have gone to four consecutive elections on the issue and faced the judgment of the voters. We have three planks. The first has been to encourage greater competition. That will bring about cheaper prices and greater infrastructure. The second has been to bring in regulation in respect of customer service guarantees, universal service obligations and tough consumer safeguards. The third plank in the government's telecommunications policy has been to target those areas, especially in regional and rural Australia, where there is market failure or a decline in infrastructure unable to be provided for by the marketplace. We have delivered on all three planks. On all three this government honoured the commitment. Consequently, we come to this debate on the privatisation of Telstra not just having been open and honest with Australians in facing their judgment in every election since 1996 but also with a track record. As a result, our three-pronged approach to telecommunications has brought material and measurable benefits to Australians wherever they live. We remain committed to the sale of Telstra, because we believe it is in the best interests of the company. It is in the best intering ests of the 1.7 million shareholders of Telstra and it is in the best interests of Australia in that it will further competition and bring about new opportunities to introduce new services and lower prices. But that has to be done against the backdrop of regulation that protects the national interest as well as the interests of consumers. At the same time, one of the most significant benefits from full privatisation is that it will remove the tension inherent in the position of the government as part-owner of the country's major carrier as well as the nation's regulator. The key point in all of this is to understand the difference between the role of government and the role of the private sector-a key point that is lost on the Labor Party. The government's role is not to own Telstra; it is to regulate for the whole industry. It is this regulation that will deliver the benefits to consumers. This is the responsibility and the power of the government of the day. Look at our regulatory regime: look at the universal service obligation, which guarantees people access to a phone service; look at the customer service guarantee, which makes sure that people's phones are connected and repaired in a timely and efficient manner, or else the carrier faces a penalty; look at the regulation informing price controls, which constrains Telstra's pricing behaviour; and look at the regulation, indeed the legislation, that locks in untimed local calls. Since the introduction of competition in conjunction with the regulation imposed on Telstra and other carriers by the government, Australian consumers have seen a decrease in the real price of more than 20 per cent of telecommunications services. All Australians can now choose between different service providers for their fixed phone, mobile phone and internet services. There are more than 100 telecommunications carriers operatin Australia. There are now more than 16 million mobile phones in operation in Australia across a variety of networks, including Hutchison's 3G network. The number of broadband subscribers in Australia is now well over one million. It is a good sign for competition that almost half of Telstra's ADSL subscriptions are wholesale services being resold by competitors. As well as regulation and competition there is support for rural and regional Australia. Since 1997, the government has committed more than $1 billion to improving communications infrastructure and services in Australia, most of which has been spent in regional Australia. Remember that it is not the ownership of Telstra that preoccupies, concerns and will eventually decide the issue for rural Australians. They are much more pragmatic. They want to know what the future guarantees will be on the levels of service and pricing. The government is at one with them in that regard. As the cabinet and the Liberal and National parties consider these issues over the course of this week, that is what will be dominant in their thinking: future services for country people. I can assure the House that the government's credentials in rural and regional Australia are strong. Always remember, as many people in country Australia do, that in 1991 the Leader of the Opposition, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, led the then government's decision to corporatise Telecom and convert it into Telstra. From that moment on the directors of Telstra had to act under their corporate, legal and legislation, tive responsibilities only in the commercial interests of Telstra; so Telstra from 1991 could not invest in uncommercial ventures or spend money in an uncommercial way. Telstra received little or no assistance from the Keating governments leading up to the 1993 election and then between 1993 and 1996. It is the Howard government since 1996 that has spent, on average, more than $100 million a year from the budget allocations for rural and regional Australia. It was the Labor Party that put in place a commercialised Telstra that would not invest in regional Australia. What is Labor's record in government? Their record is little or no competition, little or no regulation to protect the interests of consumers and customers and little or no investment in regional Australia. I correct myself-they did make a major decision that affected rural Australia: in 1995 they actually closed down the analog mobile phone network. It fell to the Howard government in 1996, in partnership with Telstra and at considerable expense to all parties involved, to establish the CDMA network so as to give country people-who were unable to access the digital network for cost as well as territorial reasons-a mobile phone network. And full marks to all involved at the time. It was a superb engineering feat. So Labor's attack on the government rings hollow because they had their chance when they occupied the treasury bench to bring about meaningful, lasting reform of telecommunications in this country and to support rural subscribers and communities. They failed obviously and demonstrably in both regards. The Howard government has spent a great deal of money through Networking the Nation and responding to the telecommunication inquiries. Some of the specific achievements have been to spend more than $140 million to support the extension of mobile coverage to 98 per cent of the populaand 40,000 customers in remote Australia have received access to untimed local calls for the first time. There is also an opportunity for these customers to take up subsidised, two-way, high-speed satellite internet services, and moreover the HiBIS program has seen many small country towns receive broadband or high-speed internet for the first time in a way, without the government subsidy, they could never have done. So, quite frankly, there is a vigorous and sensible debate about the importance of telecommunication services under way in rural Australia, and the Labor Party is left behind, as will be the Independents if they have this knee-jerk reaction appealing to what they think is the more popular point of view of opposing privatisation, full stop. Any member of this parliament who opposes the privatisation of Telstra full stop is seriously underestimating their constituents. Our constituents want this debate to continue in the way that it has. They want to be able to match the government's intentions against its track record. They want to be able to examine the government's plans and proposals to secure regional and rural telecommunications into the future. But the members of the Labor Party and the Independents do not need gratuitous advice from me. Having been around this debate for a long time, having been to four elections with the privatisation of Telstra as the government's policy, I well know the depth of interest and the level of understanding that rural people bring to this debate. If the members opposite want to treat country people as if they will be easily persuaded by simple sloganism, they can go ahead and do it. Senator Conroy, the shadow minister for communications and information technology, has admitted that Labor made some mistakes on regional telecommunications. That was big of him. How could you deny that the Labor Party neglected regional Australia? How could you deny that the Labor Party was paralysed to reform the telecommunications sector in Australia by failing to introduce new competition, by failing to introduce the necessary regulatory framework that would allow competition to flourish and at the same time by failing to cap prices and ensure the level of service for customers that they require? The fact that the Labor Party is clinging to government ownership of Telstra as its central plank of telecommunications policy in the absence of any debate, discussion or policies on telecommunications highlights not only its irrelevance but its scant grasp the complex issues. Quite frankly, the Labor Party has vacated the field on all of these telecommunications issues. Most Australians know that Labor's telecommunications record in office was appalling, so it is no major concession by the shadow minister for telecommunications to say that Labor failed the people of Australia when in office. He is only stating what is known to be the obvious. We could give Senator Conroy some marks for such an apology, except he is not doing anything about it-that is the problem. Senator Conroy has proffered an apology on behalf of the Labor Party, but the Labor Party is returning to its bad old ways, trying to play the politics not the policy, underestimating Australians and failing to realise that this is a serious debate of national importance. Simply having one response only-the total opposition to the privatisation of Telstra-serves itself and the country poorly. Labor's record, quite frankly, is shameful and Labor is not doing anything about improving it because it will not do the hard work.
