It rolled up with an MPI today with no questions in the parliament about it. It is on the sidelines-in fact it is out of the ballpark-when it comes to all aspects of this debate. The government's record is strong, the internal debate is strong and the result will be strong.

Speaker: Mr WILKIE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The coalition, in their obsession with the sale of Telstra, remind me of a song sung by that great Australian rock band AC/DC: Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap. In this case it is a dirty deal, it is done dirt cheap and all Australians will be the poorer if it goes ahead. Over the past few months I have spoken many times in this House about Telstra's abject failure to deliver adequate telecommunications services in my electorate of Swan. Last week I related the case of a local freight-forwarding business, Freightshop, in of my electorate. Located 400 metres from the Perth international terminal, he cannot get broadband. Despite repeated requests of Telstra over a five-year period, this business is unable to access a broadband service. Mr Kel Watkins, the owner of Freightshop, has been informed by Telstra that the international airport is too far from the Ascot exchange and that therefore they cannot supply a broadband connection. As you can imagine, Mr Watkins's business depends fundamentally on access to customs systems on the internet and email. Understandably, he is becoming very frustrated with the slow speed of his current dial-up connection. Mr Watkins is a small business owner and says that, while bigger companies can afford wireless connection, small businesses are missing out. Today's edition of the local newspaper in my electorate, the Southern Gazette, reports that due to the unavailability of broadband Mr Watkins has now decided to relocate his business. On 29 July I wrote to the new CEO of Telstra, Mr Sol Trujillo, about this situation and have not yet heard back from him. Let us be clear about this: here we have an export oriented small business-the lifeblood of the economy-which is being massively disadvantaged because a majority owned government big business is failing to deliver a basic service. This demonstrates how utterly farcical this government's claim is that it looks after small business. What a joke! I raised Mr Watkins's case on Paul Murray's program on 6PR radio in Perth and afterwards Mr Murray's program was inundated with calls from Perth residents with similar stories of Telstra's poor services and the inadequacy of broadband access. When I raised Mr Watkins's case in the House last week, the member for Herbert came up to me afterwards and said that the solution was simple: everybody has access to broadband-all that the businesses and households in my electorate had to do was get a satellite dish. Get a satellite dish! This guy has a business 400 metres from the Perth International Airport and the best a government member can say is, ‘Go out and get a satellite dish.' It just goes to show once again how out of touch the member for Herbert and the government are when it comes to the provision of these services. It is redolent of Marie Antoinette's comment to the French people when they complained they had no bread to eat: she said, ‘Let them eat cake.' I think that is what the government is doing to people in Swan and around Australia. Let me relate just two of the many comments about Telstra services which my electorate office has received from people in Swan. Mr Robert Birch of Kewdale says: Although I live within 8 to 10 kilometres of Perth (a capital city in Australia), Telstra is unable or unwilling to provide [an ADSL] service to residents……How could they even propose modern services to the country areas when they cannot even properly service capital city suburbs? My sentiments exactly. Mr Dennis Cherry of Kewdale: Through my carrier, Up N' Away, I applied twice for ADSL … each time Telstra said I was too far from my exchange in Ascot ... Just after that I received a letter from Telstra saying they were conducting a trial to test new [broadband] technology ... I applied and it worked perfectly for three months. After that they closed it down and I had to go back to dial up. What is going on with Telstra? Mr Cherry is not alone in having been approached by Telstra to receive a service on a trial only to find that the services are not available on a permanent basis. I have heard many similar complaints from people in Swan about Telstra's often used tactics of promising residents access to broadband on a trial basis, delivering that service for the period of the trial and then informing the customers-lo and behold-that despite being able to provide broadband the service is not available on a permanent basis. Not only is this ploy misleading and deceitful but I cannot believe that it is actually good business practice. Can you imagine any other business which provides a service successfully for a three-month trial basis and which then says, ‘Sorry, I can't give it to you on a permanent basis'? What is the purpose of the trial if you cannot ultimately get the service? There is only one reason why Telstra gets away with it: Telstra remains effectively and essentially a monopoly. We all know that a fully privatised monopoly is the worse of all outcomes for consumers. Already consumers are getting a raw deal from Telstra's services. Under a fully privatised Telstra it will only get worse. So much for this government's rhetoric about its concern for families and businesses. It sells them out to pursue its ideological obsessions. Families need broadband to ensure their children can access the best possible educational services; businesses need broadband to ensure they can be competitive and successful. On both counts you can only conclude that, on the government's watch, families and businesses in my electorate and many others are being treated with contempt. You would expect that at the present time, when Telstra is under the spotlight, given its proposed sale, the company would be moving heaven and earth to improve its services throughout Australia. You would expect that Telstra would currently be demonstrating its corporate ‘best behaviour'. If what is currently being seen is best behaviour, the only conclusion that can be drawn is that it is far from good enough. The debate about Telstra, which has occupied so much print space in the newspapers and taken up so much time in the parliament, has focused almost entirely on services in rural Australia. Having been a farmer in Western Australia for a number of years, I agree that over the years their telecommunications services have been significantly below par, and those living in rural Australia deserve much better than this government is delivering in terms of telecommunications services. But the political preoccupation of the Howard government with services in the bush has overshadowed the needs of those who live in the cities, as was pointed out week in the coalition party room by the member for Lindsay. But this is not just the member for Lindsay. The member for Tangney issued a press release on 19 May this year in which he boasted that he had been to see the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts and ‘the big guns at Telstra': … armed with the weight of hundreds of complaints from local residents, university students, parents and small business operators, they argued the case for the people. Not one or two-hundreds of complaints. He went on to say that his electorate could now rejoice because Telstra had promised ‘ADSL will be fully enabled by the end of June'. The member for Tangney is new to this House, so perhaps he could be forgiven for swallowing such twaddle. You can bet your bottom dollar that his constituents have not yet popped the champagne corks in celebration of his efforts because they know their services have not improved. In the last election campaign the government announced $50 million to improve broadband access in metropolitan areas, but almost a year later not one single cent has been spent. This program was reannounced in this year's budget in May. That is $50 million not yet spent in the cities, as opposed to $160 million for the HiBIS program for internet access targeted at the bush. This proves beyond a shadow of a doubt that urban residents are being treated with scorn by this government as it falls over itself to hand money to the bush to prop up the National Party. It is vital that the Australian government undertake to deliver broadband services to all Australians, irrespective of where they live. That should be the overriding objective of the government in the debate about telecommunications, yet the government is ignoring that objective to pursue its ideological last agenda involving spending billions of taxpayers' dollars to buy the vote of Senator Joyce. Before I finish, let me comment on the role of the National Party in this debate. Without Senator Joyce we all know that the National Party would have caved in on the sale of Telstra ages ago. Despite crude bullying tactics, Senator Joyce at least had the gumption last week to stare down the Liberals. But, finally, as with past National Party practice, it appears that he too has been bought off. Once again, the National Party have their snouts in the trough. Having been a pig farmer, I can recognise the delighted little squeals from those opposite at the prosis pect of the sale. But those delighted squeals will soon turn to cries of terror when Telstra reaches the market. When the National Party sign off on the sale of Telstra, I believe the consequences them will be similar to the fate of the Democrats once they agreed to the GST. They will be finished; they will be part of tomorrow's breakfast. Frankly, once Telstra is what will be the point of the National Party? This is of course the Liberals' covert agenda. The fact is that there are many more Liberal MPs representing rural electorates than there are National Party MPs. Those Liberals are deeply frustrated by the fact that National Party MPs are disproportionately overrepresented in cabinet and the ministry. Everyone on the coalition side of politics knows that the fast track into cabinet is to join the National Party. As we see day after day in this House, you can perform in a way that can best be described as pedestrian and, if you are in the National Party, you still get to around the cabinet table. So the Liberals have developed a cunning plan to kill off the National Party by privatising the rest of Telstra and, in so doing, removing the last reason for their existence. Mark my words: the full privatisation of Telstra will herald the death knell of the National Party and its inevitable takeover by the Liberals. Telstra should not be privatised. Services are already woeful in the cities and in the country and they will only get worse if Telstra is privatised. I will finish by quoting a letter from Perth resident Mr Rodney Coker, published in the Australian last week. He said: When Telstra can give a broadband service to the businesses at Perth International Airport ... then maybe they will be able to get a decent service into the bush for people. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: This an interesting matter of public importance debate to be a part of. As I sat and listened, I heard coming from the opposition benches a host of interjections. Most notable was the member for Throsby who interjected that we for should listen on this side of the chamber to the Newspoll, that we should listen to our constituents and that we should closely look at what the people of Australia want. I wonsold, der whether the member for Throsby and other members of the Australian Labor Party have been looking at the wrong Newspoll. The Newspoll that I saw had the Australian Labor Party at a record low this morning. We saw dissatisfaction with the Leader of the Opposition at 51 per cent. We saw the Leader of the Opposition as preferred PM at 25 per cent compared with the Prime Minister, John Howard, at 57 per cent. In fact, only 31 per cent of the Australian population is satisfied with the opposition leader's current performance-the lowest level ever and lower than when Mark Latham, the former member for sit Werriwa, was leading the Australian Labor Party. The question can be asked: what has all this got to do with the debate currently taking place here in the chamber? Mr Deputy Speaker, I will let you know what it has to do with it. It has to do with the fact that the Australian Labor Party is so desperate to prop up the Leader of the Opposition that it will cling to anything in the hope that it resonates with the Australian population. In this particular case the Australian Labor Party is adopting a policy position completely devoid of any integrity whatsoever in the vain hope that in some way this might do something to assist the Leader of the Opposition to rise back up from those depths of despair-only a 31 per cent satisfaction level-to where he might in some way be a competitive alternative to the Prime Minister. This is not going to work. The reason this will not work is that there is a complete lack of integrity when it comes to the ALP position on the further privatisation of Telstra. Let us not lose sight of the fact that Telstra present is 49 per cent privatised. For all intents and purposes it is half privatised and has 1.7 million shareholders. Those 1.7 million shareholders have a right to demand of the Australian Labor Party their rationale for insisting that the only way that we can ensure future telecommunications services of an adequate standard is to continue this ridiculous half-pregnant ownership model that Telstra is currently lumbered with. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition, speaking this afternoon, made a number of comments about the need for Telstra to invest in more technology and in a roll out of additional technology. I agree with the Leader of the Opposition in that respect: there does need to be greater investment in the provision of infrastructure by Telstra. The question is: how do we ensure that that takes place? That is the most important question. It was interesting to hear the substanceor I should say the lack thereof-in the contribution of the second speaker from the opposition in this debate. The member for Swan came into the chamber today and used as the rationale for the continuation of this half-pregnant ownership model of Telstra the requirement that it should be split because there was a local person that the member for Swan gave as an example, Mr Watkins, who was unable to gain access to high bandwidth broadband even though his business was situated only 400 metres from the Perth airport. I would try to educate some members opposite about the difference between government policy and its effects and technological impacts. The reality is that we are talking about a telecommunications network that was rolled out 100 years ago and when it was rolled out 100 years ago it was rolled out to deliver voice services. What we are now seeking to do is to utilise that same technology in a way to deliver the demands of a new and sophisticated genat eral public. One way we are doing that is by enabling copper wire to carry high bandwidth. But there is a limit to this technology, and that means that if someone is more than 4.5 kilometres away from an exchange then they cannot have access to ADSL broadband-and that has nothing at all to do with the ownership of Telstra. There is a technological limit on what that technology can do. For the member for Swan and for the Australian Labor Party to come into this chamber and claim that because of limits on technology, because of limits on what we can do with a phone system that was installed 100 years ago, the best way forward is for Telstra to remain in this half-pregnant ownership model is absurd. It is farcical, and the Australian Labor Party knows it has zero substance when it comes to policy integrity on an issue like this. The question can then be asked: what can the government do? What can the government do to ensure that customers can be satisfied that Telstra will respond to their needs? What can the government do to ensure that people in regional Australia, that people in metropolitan Australia, have access to reasonable levels of quality when it comes to telecommunications services? The answer, quite simply, is regulation. Regulation is an entirely separate question as to whether or not Telstra is fully privatised or remains as this half-public, half-privatised model. Members opposite do not want to talk about this issue because they would much rather muddy the waters and claim that limits on technology are, in some way, going to have an impact on it. They think they can sniff a vote in this issue. But this government is not concerned with that; this government is concerned with good policy, good technology and good outcomes that will ensure that we continue to add value to the Australian economy-not with the opportunistic, petty politics that the Australian Labor Party focuses on in this debate. We saw the classic thinking of the Leader of the Opposition when he said, and I use a verbatim quote: ‘We need to command and control. We need to ensure that we, the government, keep our hands on the tiller.' That is classic left of centre thinking from the Australian Labor Party. It sits there and puts ward the contention that the Australian Labor Party is in the best position to know about what the Australian public needs in terms of new technology in the future. Unlike electricity, unlike roads, unlike water pipes, when it comes to telecommunications, there is more than one way to deliver a service. The Australian Labor Party might think it is particularly clever and the Australian Labor Party might think it is in the best position to command and control the roll out of new technology but, if it does that, it will lead Australia backwards, it will run down services and it will cause additional problems. If you think back to when the Australian Labor Party was in government, you start to see very clearly the difference between an Australian Labor Party that says one thing but then does something completely different. When the Labor Party today stands up and cries foul on the inability of people to secure a decent telecommunications service, it does not mention the fact that when the Australian Labor Party was last in government and when Telstra was fully publicly owned, it could, in fact, take up to 27 months for someone to get a connection to a telephone system-27 months! And the Australian Labor Party says full public ownership of Telstra is a superior system to privatisation. The reality is that this government is leading the charge through the universal service obligation imposed not only on Telstra but on all telecommunications companies. This government is leading the charge with the customer service guarantee. This government is leading the charge in ensuring, to the greatest extent possible, that there is parity between urban areas and regional areas when it comes to the provision of telecommunications services. Compare that to Labor's record. There were no consumer safeguards when Labor was last in power, so it is very rich for the forAustralian Labor Party to now come into the chamber and claim that in some way it is trying to do the right thing. This is a very simple issue. There is no connection between regulation and ownership. This government needs to concern itself with effective regulation. The best way we can ensure that we provide effective regulation of telecommunications companies is to separate ourselves from the conflict that we are currently caught in, where we are part-owner and partregulator. Let us forget this notion of trying to maintain Telstra as a half-pregnant ownership model. Let us get Telstra fully privatised. Let us let the market work out the best delivery platform for future telecommunications and let us stop the scare campaign of the Australian Labor Party and the Independents, who will go around their electorates talking up fear and talking up limitations to telecommunications technology because they think there is a vote in it. Policy integrity is what is required, and good policy integrity should see the full privatisation of Telstra. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The proposed sale of the remaining publicly owned shares in Telstra is a line in the sand issue in the bush. There is no competitive model that will work, other than in the biggest regional cities. Competition is a furphy in this debate. For almost a decade now, I have fielded the concerns of country people over poor telco services. Those concerns continue and those people know they will only receive upgraded services through continued public ownership of the most important thing that can maintain any sort of equity between city and country-their telecommunications network. Despite the millions spent in recent years, that network is still like an old tea towel-still strong around the edges perhaps, but seriously frayed in many parts, with big holes in other sections. People in country areas know how they can be left high and dry, as they were with the switch off of mobile analog services. CDMA came as an afterthought after tremendous political pressure, much through the work of Boyd Munro and APUMP and the stream of protests from all over country Australia through my office. CDMA is still only fair to poor as a line of sight technology. On the drive from Bathurst to Canberra, I have no mobile service for large sections on GSM and my staff have the same problems with CDMA. There are no plans for mobile services in towns of less than 300, such as Cumnock and Tullamore. Broadband ADSL services are impossible beyond five kilometres of an exchange in country areas, and many parts of large centres, like Bathurst and Orange, are still not ADSL enabled and there are no plans to carry out this work. Where ADSL is not available, the HiBIS option is offered at $40 a month more. It is not an option for most families. They are left with a dial-up guaranteed internet speed of just 19 kilobits per second. This is an equity issue, an education issue and a needs issue, and these gaping holes in the provision of services across rural and regional Australia cannot be fixed with a cynical $1 billion spend and $100 million a year interest earned from the Deputy Prime Minister's special fund-a fund, by the way, that any incoming government could wind up straight away and redirect to its political priorities; and if it is Labor, it will not be the bush. We have seen many figures bandied about in recent weeks. Let us go back to earlier this year when The Nationals' own Page report suggested that $7 billion would be required to provide adequate broadband services to rural areas. The then Telstra management suggested it would be more like $30 billion. The truth of the matter is that no-one has any idea how much is required to deliver state of-the-art services because any survey of needs is simply a snapshot in time. And who is going to do the work, with Telstra unable to meet its guarantees now? What about the so-called universal service obligation? Telstra argued several years ago that this would require a billion dollars a year for the foreseeable future. Telstra's competitors said $200 million was enough. The Productivity Commission looked into it and said the figure was closer to $600 million. This government signed off on $200 million and next year just $170 million will be spent to help equalise services covered under the USO-that is, basic landline telephone and payphones only, not the broadband internet that so many country Australians cannot access. No wonder Sol Trujillo does not want regulation or anything to do with the real problems of the rural network. He knows what it is like and what is needed. He wants to maximise profits for his private shareholders, just like Optus and all those other private telcos want nothing to do with providing services into unprofitable parts of the market. They are happy to cherry-pick the juicy bits, just like a privatised Telstra would do for its private shareholders. As I said, there is no competitive model that will work in other than the most profitable parts. The Nationals have had the chance for the past nine years to argue the case Senator Barnaby Joyce is now putting on behalf of his constituents. They could have crossed the floor at any time. They now hide among the skirts of Senator Joyce, wallowing in a newfound profile but saying nothing publicly, letting him cop the bullyboy flak from their Liberal coalition partners. The country Liberals, senators and members, have all been party to a disgraceful betrayal of their constituents, with the possible exception of the member for Hume, although he is not here and he, too, has been uncharacteristically quiet in recent days on this issue. Has Bill Heffernan got to him too? Senator Joyce, up until his hesitation today, had tremendous support throughout rural Australia-indeed right across Australia, as today's Newspoll shows. Returned diggers said to me at functions over the weekend, ‘We fought for this country and we fought for the sorts of things that the country had and one of those things is a proper communications network that is publicly owned.' That is the point that country people are making over and over again. My own electorate poll shows that 93 per cent of 2½ thousand respondents are adamant that Telstra remain in majority public ownership. Should Senator Joyce and his colleagues reject that opinion and support the sale, this issue will-as a previous speaker saidbecome The Nationals' GST. I say too to any other senator who may be wavering and who may be a substitute vote if Senator Joyce stands firm: it will be one of your very last votes in parliament because your days will be numbered as well.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: You know when the Labor Party are not fair dinkum because you just have to look at what the MPI is about and whether they actually address the MPI. Let me remind you what the MPI is about. It is about the failure to provide telecommunication services to all Australians, and the Labor Party did not once address that issue. Let me address it directly here and now. Every Australian, no matter where they are in this country, can get a phone service right now. Every Australian, no matter where they are in the country, can get broadband internet right now. They can get broadband internet and they can get a reliable phone service right now. So what is this business about the failure to provide telecommunication services to all Australians? They are there now. That is the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party. The member for Swan told this House that he has a customer who is 400 metres from the Perth Airport who cannot get broadband internet. I can tell the member for Swan that that customer can get broadband internet now and he can get it in either of two ways. Ms George-He can't get ADSL.

Speaker: Mr LINDSAY
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: He will not get ADSL because ADSL technology, as the member for Moncrieff rightly said earlier, only goes 4½ kilometres on copper wire from an exchange. We accept that. That is technology. That is the limit. But the member for Swan's constituent can either take satellite broadband or he can take wireless broadband. Both services are available at Perth Airport right now and it is irresponsible for the member for Swan to get up in this House and mislead the parliament. Haven't you noticed that the more of Telstra that is privatised, the better the services have become? Have you noticed that? It has been an amazing thing that the Australian Labor Party does not like to recognise, but it is true. Let me talk about some of those services. In the sitting break I went to Warrawagine Station on the edge of the Great Sandy Desert in Western Australia. You could not get a more remote location. And what did I find at this remote location? There were four homesteads on the station and every one had broadband internet access, provided free of charge by Telstra. Each house had its little satellite dish and it was connected to the world free of charge by Telstra. Also on the station was another satellite dish providing 32 phone lines if the station wanted 32 phone lines. That was provided free of charge by Telstra. This station only wanted four phone lines, as it happenedand most of us in the cities do not have four phone lines-but they could have had another 28 if they had wanted them, right there and then. What a fantastic service. The Labor Party says that we are not providing services to all Australians, but there they are. What did I do then? I took the troublethe Labor Party and the member for Batman should do this-to go to Telstra's global operations centre at Clayton in Melbourne. What do you find there? You find a state-of the-art centre that has been there for five years. There is nothing like it in the rest of the world. Of course, they have a back-up global operations centre in case something goes wrong with the main one. What did I do when I was there? I went onto the floor of the global operations centre and, without notice, said: ‘I've just been to Warrawagine Station in the Great Sandy Desert. I want to have a look at the state of their satellite ceiving terminal. Please show it to me.' From all of the technology all across Australia, Telstra pressed the buttons and up on the screen came Warrawagine's satellite earth terminal sitting on the edge of the Great Sandy Desert. They said: ‘This is what is happening at the moment. This line is actually engaged'-and so on. They showed me the earth receiving station in Perth and the other end of the satellite link so that they could see if there were any faults there. Then they said-using the internet, of course‘We'll take you to Warrawagine's point of presence in Karratha.' They just pressed a couple of buttons and we were looking at the point of presence in Karratha. What fantastic technology. The reason they have it is so that, if there is a fault, you can get in there and get it fixed quick smart. While I was there, right in the middle of a great bank of video display screens where they put up the most urgent faults in red, a fault was discovered on the TownsvilleCairns line. I thought they had put it up just because I was there, but they had put it up because there was a real fault. I said: ‘What is this serious fault? It's in red, right up in the middle. It is Townsville-Cairns. I want to know.' Out of the hundreds of thousands of services in that corridor, the fault was one 64-kilobit per second ISDN line that had gone down and Telstra's priority was to have it right at the top in red. They said, ‘We want to get it fixed as quickly as possible.' What sort of service is that? I take my hat off to Telstra. I want to see Telstra grow to be a great Australian. The only way that Telstra is going to realise its full potential is if we take off the brakes and let it fly. The sooner the Senate does its work, the better.

Speaker: Mr WINDSOR
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I was with the member for Herbert at the particular station, as was the member for Batman. As he has done in his speech today, rethe member for Herbert displayed his ignorance about Telstra's capacity to deliver services at that station, and I was a little disturbed by some of the things he had to say. This issue has been around for some time, and the past week has really brought it to a point. There are a number of people suggesting that the full privatisation should take place now and that some billions of dollars should be invested in current infrastructure and the so-called future-proofing that the government continually talks about. The Prime Minister has said in this very chamber, in answer to a question from me, that no government can bind a future government to the delivery of services or guarantee that regulations that are put in place by this parliament will be borne out in other parliaments. It is against our Constitution to do that. So it is absurd for people in the National Party-and I would be pleased to see the member for Hinkler address this issue when he follows me-to say that you can future-proof, set funds aside, to guarantee that there will be equity of access to services that are available at the moment and services that have not yet been invented. On Channel 10 on Sunday, for the first time, the Leader of the National Party alluded to how difficult it was-I think it was in answer to a question from Michelle Grattan-for experts to assess what it would cost to put in place future technology that has not yet been invented. Isn't that mind-boggling? The leader of the party that is out to sell for short-term political gain-and because it has got itself into a bit of a bind-said he was willing to talk to as many experts as possible, but then said, ‘It is impossible to cost this because we do not know what the technology is going to be.' That same person, the Leader of the National Party, suggested that setting aside a $2 billion fund which would produce $100 million per annum would be sufficient to future-proof regional and rural Australia. It is an absolute joke. The new CEO of Telstra had the audacity to come to Canberra and say to the Prime Minister and others that he believes there has been an underspend, an underinvestment, of about $5 billion in regional and rural telecommunications. He made that point and I agree with him. At least someone in the field who should know what he is talking about has put a figure on the underspend up until now. That is an indictment of the government's policy and the National Party's policy. In the last few days, even the minister has said, ‘It's patchy.' Last year she was saying it was up to scratch; now it is ‘patchy'. The people who were saying it was not up to scratch are starting to say it is looking good and that, if we set aside a fund of $2 billion, the money generated will guarantee services. What utter nonsense! They are taking the Australian people for absolute fools. The other part of this so-called plan is that $1 billion from the $30 billion to $32 billion from the sale will go into the immediate restoration of services. I have just been on a 10,000 kilometre drive across regional and rural Australia. The reception on my mobile phone-and I have as good an aerial system as Telstra can provide-provided access to mobile communications for 1,800 kilometres of the 10,000 kilometres. If people are suggesting that is up to scratch-that that is good enough-and that $100 million a year, or even $1 billion in a one-off payment, is this going to correct those sorts of problems, again they are taking the electorate for fools. You have a situation where the government are saying, ‘This is the grand plan: a billion dollar one-off payment. The interest on $2 billion'-this is over as many years as they would like to suggest-‘would equate to $100 million a year,' which is $25 million a year less than they have been putting in over the last eight years. The minister has said that the government have spent $1 billion since 1997-$125 million a year. The promise, the commitment for the future with this great fund, is $25 million a year less. But let us look at that. You have the CEO saying there has been an underspend, an underinvestment, of $5 billion. They are all-even Barnaby Joyce-running out there now saying, ‘This is better than we had a few weeks ago. This is looking good. They are looking for reasons to capitulate. The government's response is $1 billion and $100 million a year for the rest of history. It will take 40 years on those calculations to reach the equivalent of what the CEO had the audacity to say to the Prime Minister last week about the $5 billion underspend. He did not even get to what is required for the future because he does not know the technology that Australians will generally need to access these services in the future. The issue here is equity of access and equity of price. If you get that right, through this very important piece of infrastructure you can negate the problem of distance as being a disadvantage of living in regional Australia. That is the issue here. If you fully privatise this organisation as many have said-including the only member of the National Party, Peter MCGauran, who has spoken so far in this debate-it is a commercial reality. The Treasurer said today that it was commercial reality that they would have to operate for their shareholders not the service. What has happened recently is that the focus of the government and of Telstra has been on a sale, on underinvestment in infrastructure, on high dividends, so that the share price can be maintained at an artificially high level with the move towards a sale, and against service. I genuinely hope that Barnaby Joyce in the Senate sticks to his guns on this particular issue. I have seen indications of weakness in the last day or two. I say to members of the National Party who do have a genuine concern-the speaker following me, the member for Hinkler, has a genuine concern on this issue-that, if you have ever purported to represent regional Australia on an issue, this is the one to up on. The government and particularly, but not only, the National Party members have an opportunity to make a stand for regional Australia. Do not lie down on this issue. Telstra is too important to regional Australia to sell off. It is easy to decorate a cake that you know is only for short-term advantage to get out of a political bind. Take the Liberals on on this particular issue and stand up for country people. Listen to what they are saying in all the polls. Listen to what they are saying right across the nation on this issue and vote no to the sale of Telstra when the issue comes before the parliament.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If ever I have heard a lot of pious nonsense, I have heard it today. We should be looking at a vision for this country's telecommunications. What we have at present is just a mishmash of ideas. Some people say, ‘If it stays at the current level of ownership, it will be okay.' Others say, ‘If it's privatised, it'll be okay.' But what we are not engaging in is how we deliver to the people of Australia, in capital cities and the outer metropolitan areas, in the country and remote areas, a level a of telecommunications fit for a country in the 21st century. What we have is a mishmash. What has happened over the years, going back to 1991 and the current Leader of the Opposition, is a trail of betrayal. If in 1991 the then communications minister had really wanted to give Australia a first-class telecommunications system by corporatising it, he should have had the vision and the know how to know what that meant. When you corporatise something, you ask it to act commercially in the market. You have shareholder ministers if you do not have shareholders, and they expect, as shareholders do, profits. That is a given. If the minister had really been serious at the time, he would have separated the wholesale and retail operations of Telstra by whatever stand means-structural, operational or accountancy-into different streams. If we were going to have competition in Australia's telecommunications, fundamental to that was that, as you concocted a new system, Telstra had to provide third-party access. It had to provide wholesale rates for other people operating in the market. In something as competitive as telecommunications, without that separation you are left with the situation where the competitor is also the gatekeeper. You can argue about all these problems that we have heard today in the House and discuss so-called solutions to your heart's content, but, until you face the fundamental problem, it will never happen. The fundamental problem lies in three areas. The first is that you must create a new platform: a platform for delivering high speed broadband and other services into the heartland of Australia-from the outer metropolitan areas into the country and, to the extent that you can, into remote areas. Why? Because we are at the threshold of new technologies and we will never deliver them on a clapped out copper system, although executives of Telstra Countrywide would have us believe so. When you look around Australia and see that people are operating on 19.2 kilobits, you realise that it is just a disgrace. When you have an international hotel on the Gold Coast operating at 28.8 kilobits, you really have to ask: ‘Have we seriously addressed that problem?' We have not. We must roll out a new platform. My suggestion is that that would be a combination of copper fibre and uplink/downlink wireless connection. The Leader of the Opposition and the member for Hunter showed last Thursday that they were not even properly engaged with the debate and had an appalling knowledge of the whole issue. For example, the member for Hunter asked the Deputy Prime Minister: Is he aware of speculation that Telstra is now prepared to offer up to $5 billion? Deputy Prime Minister, how do you explain this $3 billion difference? In other words, he was asking about the $3 billion difference between the $5 billion that Sol Trujillo was talking about and the $2 billion that was suggested for the future fund. They are two totally separate things. The $5 billion is for the roll-out of fibre optic and wireless technology. It is funny, isn't it: Telstra has been telling the Australian public that the National Party's idea of rolling out copper to the extent of $7.2 billion would never work; it would cost somewhere near $30 billion. Can you all remember that? It was only a matter of seven or eight weeks ago. Yet when Sol Trujillo came here he was able to tell us that we can now hotwire regional Australia for $5 billion. I think someone has been kidding someone. The platform is the guarantee that as new technologies become available you can get them to the bush. But the future fund is also important because as new technologies become available, given the economies of scale in regional Australia, you will need something to guarantee that those new technologies are rolled out in the system. The third thing you need is a regulatory system that guarantees a separation of Telstra's wholesale and retail operations, because only in that way will you get a genuinely competitive market. One of the Independent speakers has said that you can never have a competitive market in regional Australia. I disagree with that. It is already happening in mobile technology; why should it not also happen in a properly restructured terrestrial system? There is no reason at all why that should not happen. Mr Windsor-That is why Qantas goes to every airport in Australia.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I will not prolong this speech any longer, other than to say that a lot of people have walked around with their hands on their hearts in this parliament for many years. When this was a key issue as far back as March 1998-I remind the member for Kennedy that he was a member of the same party as me-I raised this matter of drawing a line in the sand at 49.9 per cent until such time as these things had been worked through. I was not supported by one person in this parliament-not one! At the National Party conference in Brisbane just a few weeks ago I added an amendment to the motion that had been put up and which the government by and large adopted: The necessity for a commitment, as a fundamental principle, to a platform capable of delivering high speed broadband and, by extension, 3G services to rural and regional Australia. Until we get those three things in place all this puffery about selling Telstra and not selling it will achieve nothing. It could be happening today under its current level of ownership and it could happen in a totally free enterprise market. Let us cut all this nonsense and start thinking about the people in outer metropolitan areas, country areas and remote areas and about our nation as a dimension of our GDP with a modern 21st century telecommunications system.

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I come a little ill prepared for the debate on the matter of public importance today because it took me a long time to get here. We were delayed for four hours at airports on the way. This is rather interesting because in country Australia, as my honourable colleague from New England said, we do not have a choice of airlines. The great privatisation was wonderful for the big cities of Australia. We could go from Townsville to Melbourne for $270 return, but it was a bit unfortunate for the people in Mount Isa, who have to pay $880 return for half the distance-from Mount Isa to Townsville. In the five or six years-or whatever it is-since we privatised Qantas I have only travelled on a non-Qantas flight, I think, four times. Those who are familiar with me know that five, six or seven times a week I get onto an aeroplane to go between major ports. So the privatisation was possibly a wonderful thing for the cities of Australia. You can go to Auckland from Brisbane and return for $270, so it is terrific for those people, but for those of us who do not live in the metropolitan areas of Australia: too bad, so sad. We are now subsidising the cities. That is what has happened. Mr Barresi-Ha, ha!

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Deakin is laughing. This member, who is from Melbourne, is putting a proposition to this parliament that, after Telstra is privatised and Mary Murgatroyd's phone breaks down in Julia Creek, they are going to fly a technician from Townsville or Brisbane to fix her phone. Is this the proposition that the honourable member is seriously putting to this House? Does he seriously expect a single person in this country to believe that proposition? Mr Barresi-It's nice to see you in the House at last!

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: When you do not have an intellectual pathway open to you, you immediately turn ad hominem, don't you. It is the sign of the bankruptcy of intellectual argument on all occasions, and the member for Melbourne has demonstrated it here againnothing substantive; attack the person. Mr Crean-It's the member for Deakin!

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Deakin-yes, we want to get him on record because he has opened his mouth. I think that people in Australia feel there is a rising tide against the government with industrial relations and the sale of Telstra. If I were a betting man I would be shortening the odds on this side of the House for the next election. Every time a telephone breaks down in the electorate of the member for Deakin, those people are going to remember how he came into this place and advocated the sale of Telstra. That 70 per cent are not in the country areas of Australia. I have never seen this as a city/country debate. I do not think that the results will be much different in the city, but I am not here to represent the cities. I deeply regret that my National colleagues seem to now represent the city interests. If Barnaby Joyce sells us out and votes for the sale of Telstra, it will probably be the last gasp for the National Party. I was in a major debate with somebody on national television. He was naming all the countries that had privatised their telecommunications and even Cuba has privatised their telecommunications provider. I said, ‘It may be suitable for Cuba.' I do not come into this place with any fixed ideas that everything should be privatised or everything should be government owned. Each case should be judged upon its merits, but on that side of the House now is the belief that absolutely every single thing should be privatised-that it is a magic wand that will overcome all of our problems and deliver a better Australia. I would like to know for what area it will deliver a better Australia, and I do have to go back any further than last weekend, when we had our mid-west Rugby League grand final. It may mean nothing to people in this House, but it means a hell of a lot to us. Half the population of the town turns up to our Rugby League grand finals. I found that our president and our starring centre had left Hughenden because there was yet another round of sackings in the railways due to the fact that we have virtually no railway services left in the mid-west towns. There is just no railway system left. All of this competition business was highlighted by the Productivity Commission report on transportation by Mr Hilmer. They pointed out that there was a $4,000 million subsidy for commuter transportation in Australia, that this was disgraceful and that if we deregulated the taxis and privatised the railway system it would solve all the problems and be marvellous for us. I was originally pretty positive about it. I thought that maybe some of this $4,000 million subsidy would come back to the people in the bush, who pay 100 per cent tax when they go to work of a morning because their petrol is taxed at 120 per cent and at that stage our motor cars were taxed at about 50 per cent as well. So I thought this was a pretty good idea, but let us see how it worked out for rural Australia. In my home country in the mid-west of North Queensland, we have no rail services at all. We have lost all our football terms; we have lost all our people; we have lost our top senior high schools. Heaven only knows we have even lost our pubs in some towns. That is how it worked out for us. Getting back to the cities, I mentioned the $4,000 million subsidy the other day and a senior public servant corrected me and said the subsidy for the cities was now $6,500 million. I deeply regret it when I hear Liberal country members speaking on thisalthough they have had the decency not to not come in here and talk, but the National Party members come in here and talk. I do not know how they do that. They absolutely must know. What I am talking about here is not confined to the Kennedy electorate; it is every rural electorate in Australia. All right, we Independents have the freedom to speak out, but even when I was in the National Party at least I spoke out. Sometimes I did not have the courage to vote with my convictions, but at least I had the courage to speak out and call it what it was. When we were getting shafted I said we were getting shafted. I think that that somehow helped the people out there in regional Australia. I was at the Mount Isa rodeo on the weekend-I was working on the bar-and six people came up and said what a great bloke Barnaby Joyce was. I tell you what: after he has voted for the sale of Telstra, if he does, they will not be saying that at the rodeo next year. It is not a good thing, because it will just break their hearts again. Someone raises their hopes but then sells them out and dashes their hopes. It would be better if he had shut his mouth and not said anything if that is what he intends to do. A previous speaker to this debate spoke about technology. I do not know where these people come from. Do they know anything about Australia at all? Do not get up here and shoot your mouth off if you don't. Another speaker got up and said we have broadband everywhere. I have not checked it recently, but I know I have letters in my office telling me we have no broadband in Mareeba on the north-east side of the river. We have no broadband at Soldiers Hill in Mount Isa. We have no broadband in Ravenshoe or Herberton. Maybe these people are all lying-I have not had time to check these things since the debate has been raised, but I most certainly will now. I suspect that these people are not writing me letters for the joy of it. As far as technology goes, when I had a cattle station right up in the middle of nowhere, we saw four changes of technology in a 15-year period. Not us, but some of our neighbours had copper wire and then that was replaced by DRCS. Then the DRCS was changed to satellite and some of the other stations have now been changed from satellite to HCRC. I saw four changes of technology. I did not have to go on bended knee to the Treasurer and say, ‘Please will you finance this new technology?' (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The discussion is concluded. NA GOVERNMENT, TERRITORIES AND NA

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: ROADS
text: I move: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads from coming into the House and giving the undertaking that he will table the following documents before 6 pm this evening: (1) the letter from the senior advisor to the former Deputy Prime Minister directing the Minister's department to approve funding for Primary Energy and provide that funding as soon as possible; (2) the brief prepared by the Minister's department that recommended against the approval of the $1.2 million grant to Primary Energy that was intercepted by the acting departmental Secretary; and (3) the final departmental brief presented to the Minister that formed the basis of his decision to approve the grant. This involves a scandal in the highest offices in this country

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: PARLIAMENTARY ZONE
text: Robertson-Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads) (5.02 pm)-I move: That, in accordance with section 5 of the liament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal for work in the Parliamentary Zone which was presented to the House on 9 August 2005, namely: Pathway on the southern foreshore of Lake Burley Griffin including ‘Australians of the Year Walk'. The proposed pathway is located at the western end of the southern foreshore of Lake Burley Griffin. It connects an existing pathway adjacent to Commonwealth Avenue Bridge to the existing lakeside promenade. (Quorum formed) The southern foreshore is a popular walking, jogging and cycling route. The pathway generally comprises a concrete footpath in sound condition. However, parts remain as unformed dirt tracks in poor condition. The tracks pose risks to public safety within the Parliamentary Zone. They contain potholes and trip hazards and are slippery when wet. Provision of concrete footpaths to match the remainder of the pathway is consistent with the government's funding purpose of improving public health and safety. The pathway is adjacent to the lake's edge, and it is appropriate that bollards be included as part of the works as clear markers of the edge. The pathway comprises concrete paving, a series of bollards, street furniture and lighting. Incorporated in the pathway are five metal strips set flush in the concrete, forming the five stave lines to a musical score. Precast concrete bollards are to represent the notes to the music score of the Australian national anthem and will be placed within the metal strips according to their position within the music, along the length of the pathway. Set flush and fixed to the bollards will be photo-anodised, full-colour aluminium plaques containing the names and images of Australians of the Year. Each plaque will represent a year of the award, and they will Parbe arranged chronologically, starting at the western end of the path. At either end of the walk an interpretive sign will be installed, describing the history of the Australian of the Year Awards and introducing the Australian of the Year Walk. The pathway will be lit at night with the Parliamentary Zone light fittings currently installed along the southern lakeside promenade. The National Capital Authority has advised that it is prepared to grant works approval to the proposal pursuant to section 12(1)(b) of the Australian Capital Territory (Planning and Land Management) Act 1988. The approval of both houses is sought under section 5(1) of the Parliament Act 1974 for the pathway on the southern foreshore of Lake Burley Griffin, including the Australians of the Year Walk.

Speaker: Mr MCMULLAN
Title: PARLIAMENTARY ZONE
text: Fraser) (5.07 pm)As the person who represents this area until the current redistribution process takes effect, I want to say a couple of things about this proposal. I support the proposal, so I will not be controversial or long, but the statement seems to me to miss a couple of things. With the assistance of the clerks and the Table Office, I had a look at the original documentation that was tabled in the parliament in June, when, I think, the proposal was originally brought to the parliament for advice. It is very comprehensive in terms of design drawings and all those things, but there are two things we do not have: first, what is it going to cost, and, second, what is the timetable? Those are two things-the second, in particular-that we need to know. This work is overdue. In saying that, I am not being critical. All works have to be done in sequence; not everything can be done at once. If this is when this project came to its turn in the queue, that is fine. So, in saying is overdue, I am not criticising the failure to do it before; there is always more work to do than there are resources available to do it. I will give the minister about 30 seconds more while he consults with the officers, which is perfectly reasonable. I would like the minister to let me know now, as would be theoretically appropriate before we approve the motion, but obviously I am not going to hold this up. If the minister would send me some information about costing and timetable, I would be grateful.

Speaker: Mr LLOYD
Title: PARLIAMENTARY ZONE
text: Robertson-Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads) (5.09 pm)-Without wanting to delay the work of the House any more, I thank the member for Fraser for his support for this project. I am happy to provide further information to him in relation to the project. Question agreed to.
