Speaker: Mr STEPHEN SMITH
Title: AND SAFETY COMMISSION
text: These two bills were introduced into the House on Thursday last week. They are being debated here today, and they are listed for debate and passage in the Senate this week. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 and the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 are inextricably linked and, as a it consequence, I have no objection to there being a cognate debate on these two bills. I make it clear at the outset, though, that Labor supports the legislative underpinning to develop and declare occupational health and safety codes and standards but opposes the abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. As a consequence of that, Labor supports the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 but opposes the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005. Labor adopts that position for the following reasons. Firstly, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission bill seeks to abolish the tripartite National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the NOHSC, and replace it with the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, the ASCC. Secondly, the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 seeks to enshrine in legislation the power of the Australian Safety and Compensation Council to develop occupational health and safety standards and codes once the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is abolished. Regrettably, Australia continues to have a poor record with respect to work related death, injury and illness. It is estimated there are around 3,000 work related deaths in Australia each year. Work causes more fatalities than the national road toll. In 2002 road fatalities numbered more than 1,700 deaths. To think that Australia's workplaces have a higher fatality incidence is truly appalling modern Australia. When one breaks this down, the true gravity of the situation becomes apparent. Nearly 450 of those work related deaths-an average of nearly 10 per week-are the result of a traumatic incident at work, including work related road deaths, and a further 150 deaths occur while working Australians are travelling to or from work. Another 200 people who are bystanders die each year as a result of someone else's work activity. In 1996 National Occupational Health and Safety Commission researchers arrived at a conservative estimate that at least 2,300 people died each year as a result of work related exposure to chemicals. This does not reflect the current extent of death from occupational disease. In the near future this figure may rise due to the expected increase in asbestos related deaths, a tragedy that for many decades has continued its macabre assault on working Australians, particularly through the Wittenoom disaster and the James Hardie disgrace. Australia has the highest incidence of asbestos related disease in the developed world. The incidence in Australia has been rising steeply since 1970, and it is estimated that the total number of asbestos related deaths will reach at least 40,000 and perhaps as many as 60,000 by 2020. More broadly, approximately 480,000 Australian employees experience a work related injury or illness each year. That translates to approximately 2.8 million Australians suffering from work related long-term health conditions. Each year there are around 140,000 compensated work related injuries resulting in an absence from work of one or that more weeks. In comparison-excluding New South Wales, for which relevant data is not available-there are around 13,500 road accidents involving casualties each year in Australia. Turning to the compensation paid to in workers suffering as a result of workplace injury, I regret to advise that only around 40 per cent of all employees who experience and suffer from a work related injury or illness receive some form of compensation. This of course has an enormous deleterious cost to our social and economic bottom line. It has been estimated that the cost to the economy exceeds $20 billion per annum, and it should be borne in mind that this figure of course does not take into account the social cost-the trauma and personal suffering of the victims and their families. Most responsibility for the implementation of occupational health and safety legislation, standards and codes of practice is exercised by state and territory governments. The Commonwealth's involvement is through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council and, in its role as an employer, the Commonwealth Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission. In 1985, Labor established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission through the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. As a consequence, the commission has been in operation for about 20 years. The commission is not just the Commonwealth's national body but Australia's national body. It leads and coordinates the national effort to prevent workplace death, injury and disease in Australia. The commission is a tripartite statutory body with 18 members, including representatives of the Commonwealth, state and territory governments; and the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, which are the formal representatives of employers and employees. The commission is not a regulatory authority and thus neither makes nor enforces law. Largely the commission is responsible for producing key national standards as a model for laws in each Australian jurisdiction to help to achieve nationally consistent regulation; providing occupational health and safety statistics; ensuring that health and safety issues are included in trainderstanding ing courses for employees in Australian industry; providing practical guidance to solve occupational health and safety problems and issues; and setting the national occupational health and safety research agenda. Because the commission does not make or implement occupational health and safety legislation, each jurisdiction may take up and amend commission documents to suit its own regulatory processes. This can result in differences in the way legislation is implemented in individual states and territories and has led in more recent times to arguments for the harmonisation of occupational health and safety legislation and regulation across and throughout the Commonwealth. The principal goal in establishing the commission in 1985 was to reduce the unacceptably high national record of occupational death, injury and illness. In doing so, the commission sought to develop an awareness of issues relevant to occupational health and safety matters among members of the community and facilitate public debate and discussion on such issues; to provide a forum in the public interest by which representatives of all Australian governments, employers and employees may consult and participate in developing and formulating policies and strategies relating to occupational health and safety matters; and to provide a national focus for activities relating to occupational health and safety matters. A key element of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is its tripartite nature. Tripartism is the most positive way of working within Australia's constitutional framework. It ensures that the principal representative parties involved in occupational health and safety-namely governments, employers and employeesdevelop a close working relationship, an unof each other's points of view and a commitment to common goals. Under the existing tripartite structure of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the Commonwealth and state governments have clear and distinctive roles and responsibilities in occupational health and safety matters. The role of the Commonwealth is primarily one of coordination, facilitation and leadership. Since 1991, through its tripartite committees and working groups, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has declared seven priority national standards and codes of practice, covering a range of workplace health and safety hazards. While these have not always been adopted in a nationally consistent way in state and territory legislation, the very fact that priority national standards and codes of practice have been declared is testimony to the utility and success of the commission. In 1997, under the government's direction, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission reduced its activity with regard to the development of national standards and codes of practice, although there are a range of hazards still to be addressed, including working hours, stress and bullying. The commission has been reluctant to take national action on these issues. Funding to the commission has been reduced since the Howard government came to power in 1996. In 1995-96, funding for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was $19.78 million. In 2004-05 it was $15.023 million. This has lead to the virtual cessation of National Occupational Health and Safety Commission financial support for important occupational health and safety research. Some workplace hazards have the potential to cause so much injury or disease that specific regulations or codes of practice are warranted. These regulations and codes, adopted under state and territory principal occupational health and safety acts, spell out the duties of particular groups of people in controlling the risks associated with specific hazards. Regulations are legally enforceable. Codes of practice provide advice on how to meet regulatory requirements. As such, codes are not legally enforceable but they can be used in courts as evidence that legal requirements have or have not been met. The national commission sets occupational health and safety standards for hazards common to many industries and workplaces across Australia. These standards do not become law until they are adopted as regulations in each of the states and territories. March 2004 the Productivity Commission reported on its inquiry into national workers compensation and occupational health and safety frameworks. That report focused primarily on workers compensation rather than on occupational health and safety. The Productivity Commission found that ‘national uniformity in OH&S regulation should be a priority'-a reference to the harmonisation of approach to which I referred earlier. The Productivity Commission recommended that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission be reformed but not abolished. The Productivity Commission also recommended: clear specification of the objective of achieving uniform national occupational health and safety legislation and regulation in all jurisdictions in the NOHSC enabling legislation; agreement by all jurisdictions to adopt, without variation, the legislation and regulations proposed by NOHSC and approved by the Council; NOHSC have the ability to appoint advisory bodies, noting the importance of consulting with employers, unions and all jurisdictions; specified timetables for Council review of proposals from NOHSC, similar to those applying in relation to food standards - the process to be prescribed in the legislation; and funding of NOHSC shared by the jurisdictions, together with a commitment to funding the research and data collection necessary to ensure the development of a best practice national occupational health and safety system. The Howard government's response to the Productivity Commission's inquiry is to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and replace it with the proposed Australian Safety and Compensation Council-the ASCC. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations announced in May 2004 that the government would maintain current funding for this body. In other words, the current funding of In the commission would be applied to the proposed Safety and Compensation Council. Let me deal briefly with some provisions of the two bills. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 provides for the abolition of the commission through repealing the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985. The bill also deals with the consequential and transitional matters arising from that repeal and from the enactment of the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Act 2005. Notably, the current standards and codes declared by the commission will be taken to have been declared by the ASCC, the body replacing the commission. As the minister indicated in his second reading speech, the bill ‘also preserves the effect of any public consultations that are under way and allows for these to be treated as if they had been undertaken by the new council'. The bill also transfers the National Occupational Health and Safety Strategy 2002-2012 and the associated business plan to the Australian Safety and Compensation Council. The Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 establishes the Australian Safety and Compensation Council by administrative or executive action. The Australian Safety and Compensation Council will be an advisory body only. The council is to be created executively rather than being underpinned through legislation. Labor is opposed to this downgrading of the status of the primary Commonwealth body responsible for leadership in occupational health and safety matters. The Australian Safety and Compensation Council's functions will include the declaration of national standards and/or codes of practice relating to occupational health and safety. In addition, according to the minister, the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, as its title suggests, will: establish a national approach to ... workers pensation. As a result of representations from various stakeholders, the Howard government has agreed to empower the Australian Safety and Compensation Council through legislation with the ability to declare national standards or codes of practice. This is achieved through the bill and is a measure of the bill, which, obviously, Labor supports. Labor opposes the abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The Productivity Commission's report did not recommend the abolition of the commission. It recommended adding to the commission's role and specifying the objective of achieving uniform national occupational health and safety legislation and regulation in all jurisdictions within and throughout the Commonwealth in the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act. Labor believes that replacing this statutory body with one that is merely administrative and executive is a downgrading of the important role the Commonwealth should play in leadership for occupational health and safety. In addition, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Act 1985 provides a very detailed list of functions for the commission that includes: declaring national standards; formulating policies and strategies relating to occupational health and safety; making recommendations to action for state and territory governments; making recommendations in relation to compliance with international standards relating to occupational health and safety matters; reviewing laws and awards relating to occupational health and safety matters; evaluating policies, actions and laws made as a result of the commission's work; research, inquiries and publications about occupational health and safety; and providing training and educational and promotional programs regarding comoccupational health and safety. In part for these reasons, Labor opposes the abolition of the commission. Given the government's stated intention, as reflected by the bill, is to abolish the commission, Labor is pleased that the government has agreed to empower the new ASCC through legislation to be able to declare national standards or codes of practice. Labor is also pleased that the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 defines the ASCC as a tripartite body that represents the interests of governments, employers and employees. As a consequence Labor supports the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005. In addition, while Labor agrees that it is also important to address the recommendations the Productivity Commission made regarding workers compensation, to merely add this role to the body replacing the commission without providing additional resources means, in effect, that the government's financial commitment to addressing occupational health and safety has been significantly reduced. Labor believes that ongoing national research into occupational health and safety, something severely compromised by the ongoing funding reductions to the commission in recent years, plays an ongoing important role in the identification and prevention of workplace death and injury in Australia. The proposal to abolish the tripartite, statutory National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and replace it with an administratively created advisory body, the Australian Safety and Compensation Council, substantially downgrades the Commonwealth's participation and active role in occupational health and safety. Labor supports the development and implementation of national occupational health and safety standards and is committed to ensuring that there is a tripartite forum at the national level employer, employee, industry and union, and state and territory government representation. In Labor's very strong view this is best effected by the continuing role of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. As a consequence Labor opposes the repeal bill.

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: AND SAFETY COMMISSION
text: The Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 is required in order to ensure that the most important right for Australian workers is maintained-health and safety in the workplace. The bill will establish an Australian Safety and Compensation Council and will repeal the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. It will provide the legislative basis for declaring national occupational health and safety standards and codes of practice. The way this will happen is that through the bill we will ensure-and the government is committed to this-that there is a nationally consistent framework in place to manage safety. The bill will provide a platform for state and territory jurisdictions to adopt standards in the legislation and ensure that across Australia there are appropriate sanctions and penalties in place for failing to comply with certain workplace safety standards. The council will establish a national approach to safety and workers compensation and this national approach is very much needed. It is about 100 years since Federation. We now have eight different jurisdictions in this country, each with its own system of workplace relations and workplace safety. This government is committed to ensuring that, as much as possible, we have a uniform approach across Australia. Of course, we also recognise the responsibility and the obligations that the states have in this area of need. (Quorum formed) I am almost sure that the topic of safety with and workers compensation has never before had such a large audience in this chamber, but I will resume what I was saying before the member for Chifley interrupted me. The bill arose following the Productivity Commission's report National workers compensation and occupational health and safety frameworks of March 2004, which recommended that a number of changes take place in the area of occupational health and safety. We as a government have not accepted one of those recommendations. We decided to abolish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. This will be abolished; however, as I mentioned earlier, we will be establishing the Australian Safety and Compensation Council in its place. Its primary function will be to recommend initiatives for the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council and promote national consistency in occupational health and safety and workers compensation. The Australian Safety and Compensation Council will be established administratively, with membership to be made up from representatives from the Commonwealth, state and territory governments, employers and employees. I know that a lot of stakeholders in this debate have welcomed this representation. I note that the opposition is keen on the council being established by legislation rather than through an administrative instrument. Of course this is not taking place. Nevertheless, the new council will have the ability to make recommendations to the ministerial council, and each of the various jurisdictions around Australia will have the ability to introduce in its own legislative program the recommendations that are brought forward. The process of declaring standards which are suitable for adoption in legislation by the jurisdictions assists in improving uniformity in OHS regulations in Australia. We are often told by employers that they have to operate within myriad different regulatory frameworks in Australia. Accordingly, the declaration of occupational health and safety standards and codes that can be adopted in state and territory legislation is an important step in reducing duplication and inconsistent regulation. For a few brief moments I want to discuss the role of the Australian Safety and Compensation Council. I know members on the other side will support it, as noted by the member for Perth. The ASCC will undertake the following key activities. It will develop a work plan for the implementation of the national framework for OH&S and workers compensation priorities, which will be endorsed by the Workplace Relations Ministerial Council. It will seek agreement by all jurisdictions to adopt and implement national OH&S standards declared by the council and endorsed by the ministerial council. It will provide for and encourage the states and territories to undertake a leadership role in the revision of existing national standards and the development of new standards as required. It will monitor the OH&S and workers compensation performance data at a national level, including the appropriate use of performance indicators. This is an issue which I am very much interested in. I will have more to say about it in another debate which will take place tomorrow afternoon. Furthermore, where appropriate the council will establish subcommittees. This recognises of the importance of consulting with relevant experts in the development of general and specific OH&S and workers compensation policy and regulation. Above all, it will have a research role and an evaluation role to ensure that we have best practice in the workplace. The government continues to be committed to improving occupational health and safety and workers compensation in this country. It is committed to ensure that the myriad regulatory regimes around Australia are brought in line and that there is consistency across the states. Our commitment to improving workers compensation is one that goes back a number of years. We made an offer a number of years ago to successive Victorian governments on two specific projects that would have allowed for a federal safety inspector to go on site. In return, additional funds would have been allocated to that state government for those projects. I understand that one of those was Federation Square and the other one was the MCG project. On both occasions the state government of the day rejected the offer and rejected the involvement of the Commonwealth government in having the right to enter those work sites. We are committed to this bill. We do not see this as an issue that needs to be politicised. I certainly welcome the opposition's support of these bills. I note that they are not willing to support the repealing of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I think their concerns are illplaced. The states will continue to have the ability to introduce, through their own legislation, the various codes of practice and conduct which will be recommended by the council to the ministerial council.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: AND SAFETY COMMISSION
text: I am happy to rise to discuss the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 and the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005. Both of these bills are interrelated. true to say that, whilst Labor accepts that we can support the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill, it was made very clear by the member for Perth and by other commentators outside this place that we believe this is a downgrading of national occupational health and safety generally, particularly as it follows the proposed abolition of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. If Labor were to have its way it would be looking to revitalise and strengthen the current commission. The current commission has undertaken very good work since its inception and it focuses on a very important area in the workplace. The one thing I think we share across the chamber in this place is an understanding of how important occupational health and safety policies are and how important it is that they are enforceable to ensure that we mitigate the capacity for Australian workers to be injured. If we prevent that likelihood we diminish the likelihood of fatality or injury generally in the workplace. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has played its role in ensuring at least that there were efforts by the governments of the states, the territories and the Commonwealth to collaborate on matters of importance in this very important area of public policy. However, it is unfortunate that, instead of strengthening and building upon the importance of the commission, the government chooses to replace this tripartite body for an administrative council, which we believe would not have the teeth or the wherewithal to properly undertake the work that it will be asked to. We therefore see it as an unnecessary diminution of the national profile of OH&S. The commission itself managed to identify the fact that there are thousands of fatalities in Australia each year. Indeed, it received It is evidence from Access Economics that an estimate of 4,900 fatalities in Australia each year should be used as the approximate benchmark for fatalities in this country so that we can then work out ways to reduce that level of deaths in the workplace. The other very frightening statistic is the ABS statistic on work related injuries dated September 2000-some time ago nowwhich indicated that 477,800 persons experienced a work related injury or illness in the 12 months leading up to that date. In other words, between September 1999 and September 2000 almost 500,000 people had reported an injury of some sort, of whom 189,400 received workers compensation of some kind. That is a frightening proportion of the Australian work force-a frightening indictment on Australia's incapacity, at least to date, to reduce injuries in the workplace. Therefore, it seems odd that the government would be putting less money into this area rather than more money. It is important to note that, with the tion of the Howard government in 1996, the occupational health and safety budget at the Commonwealth level was reduced by between 30 and 40 per cent. I think that exemplified the government's priorities and illustrated to those who paid attention that it did not consider that the Commonwealth had a particularly important role in this area. Whilst it is fair to say, as the member for Deakin indicated, that we have given some qualified support for the new council, it is not true to say that we support the entirety these two bills or that we do not propose a preferred option, which would have ensured proper recognition for trade unions, employers and government in this legislation. It seems to me, and I think anyone who has represented employees in the workplace would say, that it is very important to bring all the parties relevant to the workplace together to consider ways to prevent injury. Therefore, to diminish one party's role in that seems a very odd thing to do indeed. However, it is consistent with the government's attitude towards employee organisations. It is a consistent thread that runs through all their legislation, not only industrial relations legislation-or, in this matter, occupational health and safety policies-but all areas of public policy. It seems now that it is almost a compulsory provision of any piece of legislation introduced by the government that there be some mechanism whereby collective bargaining will be diminished or threatened. We have seen that with education policies that tied Commonwealth funding to compelling employers to offer AWAs-even though that is not the intent of the Workplace Relations Act-and we have seen ministers outside the IR portfolio propose legislation that tries to reduce the likelihood of unions collectively bargaining. Unfortunately, even when it eleccomes to something that I thought we had some sort of consensus on-namely, occupational health and safety-we see an unnecessary reduction in the role of trade unions in what would generally be seen as an area where we could get consensus. That is unfortunate. It is another example where the government's blindness and its enmity towards employee organisations are such that it would rather play politics than have good public policy. As the shadow minister indicated, we of support the second bill as it is important that there be a national body, but we believe that there is no need to remove the NOHSC. We note that the minor parties and Independents in the Senate have been on the record opposing the abolition of the NOHSC. Andrew Murray indicated his opposition to its abolition. Other spokespeople-people not from the Labor Party-have expressed concern about this unnecessary repeal of an important piece of legislation and the abolition of a relatively effective commission, when compared with what is being proposed. Having said that, I indicate, along with my colleagues, that whilst we have concerns about the way the government has decided to go down this path we are relieved that in the NOHSC's place there will at least be somebody that will be able to bring together the parties nationally to talk about matters related to OH&S policies in order to bring some improvements to Australian workplaces and hopefully reduce the likelihood of injury or death.

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: AND SAFETY COMMISSION
text: I was interested in the contribution of the member for Deakin. He had the temerity to commence with an allegation that the Australian Workplace Safety Standards Bill 2005 and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (Repeal, Consequential and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2005 are ‘required for safety'. After listing the responvidual sibilities of the new body, he finally assured all and sundry that any concerns were ‘ill placed'. I am afraid that I must have some doubts about his assurances, because this legislation has to be seen in the context of measures over the period of the current government. We have heard earlier references to the reduced expenditure that has been devoted to this area in the last decade. We now see a body being established which, as detailed by previous speakers, will essentially have less legislative strength and will be given responsibility in workers compensation without any consequent increase in the allocation of money towards that body. One can see a record of reduced money being devoted to the field, and in this new responsibility there will realistically be less expenditure again for safety. Previous speakers have cited the numbers of workplace deaths in this country, the most dramatic example being in the building industry. The figure, for which there is no debate, argument or contention, is that a worker a week dies in that industry. A paper produced for the parliament some time ago by the Parliamentary Library stated: The NOHSC have estimated that there are more than 2000 fatalities from workplace accidents and diseases per annum. This figure is only an estimate, because the long latency period of some diseases and the difficulty in relating some conditions to periods of work makes it difficult to quantify the precise number of deaths. However, the figure of around 2000 is taken to be an accurate estimate by NOHSC, the Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) and the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS). Those deaths are estimated to cost the Australian economy $30 billion annually. We are talking about serious matters. On a broader front, we are talking about the indidevastation that occurs in families. In Sydney we have had very strong media coverage of the death of Joel Exner, a 16-yearold who fell 12 metres to his death from an Eastern Creek building; Anthony Hampson, a 42-year-old father of two who was badly injured after falling seven metres from a Gosford reroofing project; Dean MCGoldrick, a 17-year-old who fell 12 metres from a Sydney building site; et cetera ad nauseam. It is interesting to note that previous speakers have talked about what is essentially part of this process, the attempt by this government to marginalise the unions and to take them out of the focus in industrial relations. That, of course, should be seen in the context of the ILO-another tripartite body; both sides are talking about tripartite bodies today in this debate. The ILO, which is internationally recognised and respected and participated in by Australian employers, noted in 2004 the central role of unions with regard to safety and determined that there was a correlation between union involvement in safety matters and low injuries, et cetera. It said that internationally sites were three times more likely to be safe where committees with union involvement were on the site, and it was two times more likely that there would be a management OH&S audit of those sites where unions were involved. As I said earlier, this is a serious matter at a sonal level and with regard to national productivity and our overall financial situation in this country. People have spoken about asbestos. This is another area where we must have some concern and once again question the credibility of the government. We have witnessed the ACCC and the department of industrial relations harassing, following and pursuing councils in Sydney that have tried to put bans on the asbestos industry and its products. If they were really committed, as the member for Deakin says, to legislation to help workers, to protect people and to ensure safety we would not have measures by this government and its organisations to pursue those who seek to highlight the asbestos issue in this country-the dangers and the deaths that have resulted. They are estimated to be at least 53,000 by 2020. As the member for an electorate which is very close to the major manufacturer in Sydney, James Hardie, and also to the previous manufacturer, Wunderlich, owned by CSR, I am very aware of these issues. Those employers tended historically to employ the latest strand of migration to this country, the new wave of migrant labourers that occurred. In the period I was associated with the union that had coverage in this field, the Lebanese in particular were prevalent. In our area we have not only the possibility of a very high prevalence of deaths and serious illness over the next decade but also the reality of masses of illegal dumps by James Hardie in the region. The numbers are thought to be quite high. Can we have the confidence the member for Deakin puts to us that all our doubts as to the government's gestures and intentions should be dismissed and that we can be assured that the government really intends to do something? I say not because, as I said perwith regard to asbestos, we see them pursuing those who seek to publicise and dramatise this industry and its failings; and we see the expenditure they have devoted to occupational health and safety in this country. Also, they really got out of bed very early on one particular legislative endeavour over the last few years and that was to override the ACT legislation on industrial manslaughter. Once again, as the previous government speaker, the member for Deakin, said, that is not very active on all of the recommendations of the ACCC-they have decided not to follow one or two of those-but very active in intervening to make sure that workers in the ACT are not going to be protected by a bill which said that an employer or a senior officer could have fines of up to $5 million and 25 years in jail if they were perceived to have played a major role by their negligence in regard to an employer. The other thing that leads me to have some doubts about the government's real intentions to increase safety in the interests of workers in the industry is the performance of the infamous Cole commission into the building industry. The government did say that the minister should table the annual NOHSC report on progress in implementing the NOHSC occupational health and safety strategy for 2002-12. However, after hearing a plethora of complaints about the role of the CFMEU in this industry on what would seem to many of us to be a very serious issue, occupational health and safety-with one death a week in this industry-the commission ‘proposed to address this critical issue'they did say a few nice words on the way through-‘other than through the public hearing process'. It was decided that there would be a conflab and some discussion papers. That of course contrasted with a welter of witnesses coming forward, with tens of millions of dollars devoted to that inquiry and with the threat of court proceedings, most of which came to nothing-$60 million worth of taxpayers' money spent on supposedly a good purpose came to no significant prosecutions. As I say, I have grave doubts that we are going to get the protection of people in this country through this legislation. In general we have a government which has sought constantly to override legislation aimed at introducing measures against the pursuit of people responsible for deaths in industry. We witness a government which has reduced expenditure on safety in this country and the process of this committee itself. We are assured it is going to be tripartite and that it is going to have some role. But, given its performance over the period since 1985 when it was established to set standards, do analysis, come up with training proposals, produce statistics and propose national measures that would be taken up by the various states, one must have grave doubts that the real intention of this government is to accomplish anything worthwhile for workers in this field. Rather than come up with these kinds of measures which seek to diminish and deride the need for occupational health and safety in this country the government should be setting about establishing a proper national database, ensuring that the safety records of particular companies are kept, ensuring that licensing in an industry should become a matter for contractors and subcontractors with poor records, looking at a safety plan being provided on all projects-the successful applicant giving this to the union delegates afterwards to ensure it is adhered to, and looking at government contracts and adherence to safety standards by companies that are contracted. As I said earlier, the government should be looking at industrial manslaughter and at the annual inspection of various contracts and measures of adequate financial deterrence. In conclusion, there were some nice words said by the opposition about these measures, some of which are not of concern. Clearly the broader agenda of this government is to decrease the role of workers in safety issues on sites around the country, to ensure that there are not tougher measures against deaths on sites and to diminish the overall emphasis in this country on occupational health and safety. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Third Reading

Speaker: Ms LEY

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: The Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005 before us tonight does provide some welcome relief in funding for universities but it is very partial relief. It astonishes me that, on the very day when the government has announced that it will now seek an immigration program that has not been seen since the era of the ten pound pom, we are debating policies of a government that has been presiding over enormous skill shortages. Skill shortages do not happen overnight. There is evidence of the emergence of skill shortages going back almost a decade. In nine long years this government has done very little to anticipate and ease the skill shortages with which this country is now afflicted. This legislation makes a very small contribution to it but I have to categorise it as being too little, too late. I do in fact support the notion of a larger immigration program and one that is based on skills, but this should be a complement to domestic skills formation rather than a substitute. Yet after nine long years, this government has allowed the skills crisis to develop to the point where it has had to adopt almost emergency measures in the form of the announcements that have been made in the last day or so. It bemuses me that the present Minister for Education, Science and Training has been so unsuccessful in gaining support of the Prime Minister and his cabinet colleagues for extra government funding for our universities. The results of this sloth and inactivity are there for all to see. We know that there is enormous value in increasing the proportion of high school leavers who go on to complete university. I will cite some of the relevant indicators: Australian university graduates earn at least 50 per cent more than high school completers and 70 per cent more than high school drop-outs. So even the private benefits from a university education are very large-a 70 per cent increase in earnings, on average, compared with high school drop-outs. But that is not to count the wider social benefits-the benefits to the nation as a whole-which, in economic jargon, are called ‘spill-over benefits'. They are very large indeed. Plenty of empirical work has been done on this. Indeed, the nurturing of intellect and the acquisition of skills is by far the most potent source of productivity growth in the modern world. That point has been demonstrated by empirical work conducted by the OECD. Now knowledge and skills arguably stand alone as the only source of comparative advantage in the 21st century. This point was made in 1996 by Lester Thurow. The value of investing in skills through higher education is that it offers the double benefit of not only raising productivity but also lifting lifetime work force participation rates. I refer to a study by Access Economics that has just been documented in a publication released by the Business Council of Australia. In that report Access Economics says: Education is increasingly becoming the ‘engine room' of modern economies. If we get this part of the economy right, most other things ought to fall in place (or be better placed), because increased investment in education boosts both productivity and participation. The truth is that the Whitlam government opened the doors of the nation's universities to the children of working Australians-to average Australians and underprivileged Australians. The Hawke and Keating governments expanded access to a university education, equipping young people with the skills to be able to go on to a university education, through a doubling of the proportion of young people who completed year 12 from 36 per cent to well in excess of 70 per cent. Equipping young people to go on to university was a great contribution to our nation's future, but the Hawke and Keating governments did more than that. Through the introduction of HECS, the Higher Education Contribution Scheme, funding coming from the future earnings of the students themselves was used to expand greatly the number of university places, thereby opening up access to our universities by people who otherwise could not afford it. The coalition government, however, is reversing all this. It is making access to a university education a lot harder for all except the privileged. Both the increased rationing of places according to the capacity to pay full fees and the prospect of massive HECS debts for those fortunate enough to gain a HECS place are creating circumstances where the number of Australians going on to university has now fallen for only the second time in the last 50 years. This is a terrible tragedy. During the 1980s and early 1990s, when there was great debate and great activity on an economic reform program for Australia, it was often said that to stand still in the Asia-Pacific region is to fall behind. We needed to continue with reform and to invest in education, in knowledge and in research and development in order just to hold our place among other countries in the region and in the wider world. That was the accepted wisdom at the time, but it is not the wisdom of the Howard government. In relation to higher education, the Howard government at present is not only standing still but is falling behind. If to stand still is to fall behind, then let us think for a moment of the consequences of going backwards. In this the Asian century, the countries of our region are investing heavily in higher education-to the point where India alone is producing six million university graduates a year, two million of whom are English speaking; and China is producing an estimated 3.4 million university graduates a year. Australia, in contrast, is producing 215,000 university graduates a year. It is obvious that we cannot match the absolute numbers of university graduates of India or of China; but, in this the Asian century, we certainly need to take a great leap forward in the proportion of our young people who go on to a university education. In the 1960s, using the best available statistics-which sadly are scant-the proportion of young people going on to university was about eight per cent. Through the 1980s, with the introduction of HECS and the expansion of university places, it had built up and it is now around 30 per cent. In my book, 30 per cent of young people going on to university is a grossly inadequate proportion. If we are to be successful in this the Asian century, if we are to compete effectively against China, India and other emerging countries in our region, we must lift the proportion of young people who are going on to university-because, as Lester Thurow has observed, knowledge and skills stand alone as the determinants of comparative advantage and the wealth of nations in the 21st century. But what is the Australian experience with skills formation? It is an indictment. A Productivity Commission review of the Australian evidence concludes that the increase in average schooling in the working age population slowed from 0.5 a year in the 1980s to 0.2 a year in the 1990s. The Productivity Commission concludes: ... there appears to have been no significant acceleration in work force skills in the 1990s. In fact, the evidence shows a faster increase in skills the 1980s. So when Australia had genuinely entered the productivity race and was reforming the economy, that was a great period. But, to accelerate that productivity growth, we needed at the same time to continue through the 1990s and the early 21st century the sorts of investment in education that had occurred in the 1980s under the previous Labor government. Sadly, that did not happen and the Productivity Commission has concluded that there was a deceleration. The Productivity Commission is not alone. The conclusions have been confirmed by the OECD's work, which indicates that skill upgrading made no contribution to Australian productivity growth between 1990 and 2000. Drawing this work together, Saul Eslake asks: So why has education apparently not made any discernible contribution to the improvement in Australia's economic performance over the past decade? The answer, unfortunately, seems to be that there has not been any discernible improvement in Australia's educational outcomes-at least insofar as they impact on productivity growth during this period. I have to report that Australia ranks a lowly 20th out of 30 OECD countries in the share of 15to 19-year-olds enrolled in postcompulsory secondary education. So the story is a tragic one; it is a story of tragically wasted opportunity. Again, Australia stands alone among OECD countries on another score. The privately funded share of education spending has risen more quickly in Australia since 1995 than in any other OECD country. We have been unique amongst OECD countries in failing to increase public funding commensurately with increased private funding. By that, the OECD means that private funding has increased more rapidly in Australia than in any other country and that public in funding has fallen behind. In other countries both private and public funding have risen together so that obviously the total number of young people who could go on to higher education has been increasing. But that is not the case in Australia, and it is an indictment of this government. The fundamental problem-and it goes to the provisions of this bill-is that this government has failed to index adequately the Commonwealth grants that go to our universities. There are varying estimates of the total funds that the universities have missed out on as a result of the government's unwillingness to index those payments, but essentially the government's philosophy is that university education is a private matter and that nearly all additions to the funding of universities must therefore come from the private sector. The government does not recognise, does not acknowledge the wider benefits to the community of a university education. The consequence is plain: Australia stands out amongst OECD countries as the one country where increases in private spending on education have substituted for, rather than complemented, extra public spending. I will quote again: In fact, many OECD countries with highest growth in private spending have also shown the highest growth in public funding of education. This indicates that increasing private spending on tertiary education tends to complement, rather than replace, public investment. The main exception to this is Australia, where the shift towards private expenditure at tertiary level has been accompanied by a fall in the level of public expenditure in real terms. So there we are. Australia is unique amongst the OECD at a time when we know-when all the evidence shows-that skills formation is the most powerful contributor to productivity growth and therefore prosperity and the wealth of nations. The Australian government stands alone amongst OECD countries in shifting funding towards private expenditure at the tertiary level and reducing the level of public expenditure in real terms. I pick up where I began and ask the question rhetorically: why has this Minister for Education, Science and Training been so spectacularly unsuccessful in gaining the support of the Prime Minister and of his colleagues for increased support for our universities at this incredibly important period in Australia's development? The answer has to be, for starters, that the Treasurer does not want to see the minister for education succeeding to the same extent that he has seen his other rival, the Minister for Health and Ageing, succeed in getting a lot of money for Medicare before the last election. So, in this rivalry for the prospective future leadership of the Liberal Party, it is not only the minisJon ter for education who is missing out-and I will not be weeping crocodile tears for him-but also the young people of Australia. It is my duty to report a conversation in which the minister for education was involved. A matter of privilege was reported in this parliament just a few days ago by the member for Eden-Monaro in relation to the falsification of documents. I reckon this one deserves a bit of scrutiny, too, because it is surely inconceivable that the education minister could have engaged in the dialogue to which I am about to refer. When the minister announced that the government would be allowing universities to apply full fees to up to 35 per cent of Australian students, he seemed pretty confident that he would be able to remove a cap on the amount of fees that could be covered by the FEE-HELP funding support program. FEE-HELP is similar in design to HECS, but the problem is that FEE-HELP is capped at $50,000. We will recall that, many times before the last election, the Prime Minister was saying that there would be no $100,000 university fees under his government. Well, many scores of university courses now charge fees well in excess of $100,000, so that is yet another broken promise on the part of the Prime Minister. The minister for education was interviewed on the John Faine program on 4 August. John Faine asked: The man responsible for introducing student loans says the way the system is evolving and where you are taking it is only going to help rich students, students from rich families, is he right? The minister replied: Well in fact Professor Chapmanthe architect of the HECS programis right, but the interpretation of what he is saying is in fact a little bit incorrect. Professor Chapman is one of the people who designed the HECS program and what he is referring to in this context are the full fee paying students, these are the Australian students. Professor Chapman was indeed referring to those full fee paying students-up to 35 per cent of students now. The minister then went on to say: Well in fact we have got 784 courses in Australian unis which charge or offer full fee paying places to Australians, we have got about 16 of those courses that have fees of around $100,000 or more, needless to say veterinary science, dentistry and so on. I would just point out that that number has greatly increased since this interview on 4 August. John Faine then asked: Medicine? The minister replied: Well Medicine not yet, but that's coming in, and we know that Notre Dame will be about $125,000 and we have heard that Melbourne will be about $200,000. The minister seems very worried about this, but it is his legislation that is allowing this to happen. John Faine said to him: Now there is no way that an ordinary Australian family can afford to put a kid through one of those courses is there? The minister replied: Well in fact you are right. So here is the minister saying that John Faine and Professor Chapman are right. The reality is that the minister was confident that he would be able to get that cap removed from FEE-HELP. He went back to cabinet and he got rolled. The result is that here we are in this the 21st century-the Asian century, where we will need to compete against these countries-and the government has increased the number of full fee paying Australian places to up to 35 per cent and it has allowed universities to increase HECS by up to 25 per cent. It is pricing a university cation out of the reach of the sons of daughters of the working people of this country. This legislation gives me the opportunity to brand this minister a complete failure and to call as very urgent the need for fundamental reform of our higher education system.

Speaker: Mr BARTLETT
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: It is rather disappointing that the member for Rankin, in speaking on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005, which largely involves committing extra funding to James Cook University and the University of Western Sydney, used the opportunity to push his own hobbyhorse and in a distorted way represent his views about private funding versus public funding for universities. I must point out in response to the member for Rankin just a couple of critical points that omitted. In decrying, as he did, the cocontribution through the HECS scheme of students at university he totally ignored the that it was a Labor government in the mid1980s that introduced the HECS fee system on the principle that there was a role for dents who would benefit from a university education to contribute something towards their own education. He also omitted to say that the HECS increases for those universities which have decided to increase HECS funding over the last couple of years are really only marginal increases and that, even for those courses and those universities where a funding increase has been agreed to, it will still only involve students increasing their contribution to the cost of a university education from 26 per cent to 28 per cent. In other words, taxpayers will still be meeting 72 per cent of the cost of the average university education. This is an increase from 26 per cent to 28 per cent or a decrease in the taxpayer contribution from 74 per cent to 72 per cent-hardly the edudraconian changes that the member for Rankin was indicating. Another two points need to be made in response to the member for Rankin before I turn to the legislation before us. Firstly, in that change the government substantially increased the threshold at which university students would commence repaying their HECS debt from $24,365 to a threshold last year of $35,000 and a threshold in July this year of $36,814. Rather than being able to argue, as the member for Rankin has, that somehow university education is being priced out of the realms of possibility for the ordinary worker, the very substantial rise in the threshold at which repayment starts actually does make it a lot more affordable for average university students. They can earn a whole lot more after university graduation he before they need to start repaying their HECS debt. The other point that needs to be made is fact that the member for Rankin and many others on the other side keep referring to these full fee paying places and talking about $100,000 studegrees and so on as though somehow this means that ordinary people are being precluded or excluded from university. The critical point that he again conveniently omitted is this: no university is able to impose full fee paying places at the expense of taxpayer or HECS funded places. They are in addition to-over and above-the increased HECS places. They are not in any way precluding Australian students from taking up the increased number of university places under the HECS system. The other point that he omits is that the Labor Party is quite happy to continue to support full fee paying places for overseas students but would want to prevent Australian students accessing the same right that overseas students have. For the life of me I cannot understand the double standards that Labor wants to apply here: it is okay for students from overseas countries to come and pay to access an Australian university education but not for an Australian student who might have just missed out on a HECS place to avail themselves of the same opportunity. I am stunned that Labor wants to provide an opportunity for students from overseas that they want to prevent being made available to Australian students. Let me turn to the legislation. The technical details of this legislation really are quite straightforward. They are, despite the tangential offering from the member for Rankin, non-controversial, but the implications and the impact of this legislation are quite significant in three ways. Firstly, this legislation is a clear demonstration of this government honouring its election commitments. The amendments to the Higher Education Support Act 2003 are amendments for two purposes that were promised prior to last year's election. The first is to provide 100 new places in veterinary science and tropical agriculture at James Cook University. These places will commence in 2006 and will rise to 274 places by 2009. This was a commitment of $13.9 million that was made last year that is now being delivered. These extra places will provide veterinary science places for veterinarians specialising in the prevention and early detection of animal diseases that are prevalent in tropical areas, so they will be a great boost to the tropical part of Northern Queensland. As well as this, these places will provide for education in aspects of tropical agriculture, including the agriculture that involves sugar cane productionagain, of direct relevance to the local community. Here again the government is honouring its election commitments. The second aspect of this bill is the commitment of funding of $25 million over the next three years to improve infrastructure at the University of Western Sydney. I for one, along with a number of my colleagues-and I notice the member for Macarthur at the table there-have been pushing for years for extra funding for infrastructure and so on for the University of Western Sydney. Last year the Prime Minister made a commitment that we would deliver extra funding for infrastructure for the University of Western Sydney. This legislation delivers on that commitment. It delivers an extra $25 million. That includes $7 million for a new library at the Penrith campus. It delivers $2 million for upgraded research and teaching facilities at the Hawkesbury campus. It delivers $7 million for a medical faculty at the US Campbelltown campus-that is in addition to $18 million already budgeted. It includes $9 million for a new teaching building at the Parramatta campus. So that is $25 million for the University of Western Sydney, directly delivering on those election commitments that were made last year. We said we would deliver, and here we are delivering. This funding allocation involves substantial tangible improvements for these two universities, further evidence of the government's commitment to higher education. We had the member for Rankin somehow talking about a reduction in funding for universities, a government abrogating their responsibility. He very conveniently ignored the fact that we had an allocation of an extra $2.6 billion over five years for higher education or an extra $6.9 billion over 10 years for education in last year's budget and a record $7.8 billion in this year's budget for higher education. This is a substantial commitment to higher education, both broadly and also, I am pleased to say, in the area of Western Sydney. I was interested to hear the shadow spokesperson for education, the member for Jagajaga, speaking on this bill last week. What she was saying seemed to be supporting these funding commitments. It was quite interesting, though, to compare that with what she had to say last year. When the government made these election commitments last year, in this place the member for Jagajaga dismissed this $25 million for the University of Western Sydney and the $13.9 million for James Cook University as ‘cynical election sweeteners', ‘little sweeteners' and ‘just a drop in the ocean'. I can assure the member for Jagajaga that the $25 million for the University of Western Sydney is not just a ‘little sweetener'. It is not ‘just a drop in the ocean'. The people of Western Sydney greatly appreciate the $25 million that will improve facilities at our university, and I am sure the people of North Queensland greatly appreciate that extra funding for James Cook University as well. I am appalled that the member for Jagajaga could have dismissed them as ‘just a drop in the ocean'. This is very significant funding for two very important regional universities. The money committed to the University of Western Sydney will help meet the needs of a university that is vital to this region of Sydney. This is an area of really substantial need. We have 1.8 million people in Western Sydney, rising by something like 50,000 people a year, with large housing projects planned. The population will continue to increase in years to come. Yet, in educational terms, over the decades the Western Sydney region has not been catered for as well as other regions of Sydney. We have a lot of young people with aspirations for improved education, hungry for education and eager to get on in life, yet significantly, compared to other regions of Sydney, the educational attainment in decades past has not been as good. For instance, only 10.5 per cent of the population of Western Sydney is tertiary trained, compared to an overall average of about 21 per cent for Sydney-a much lower participation rate. So I am pleased to see that the government is demonstrating its commitment to building higher education in Western Sydney. For instance, in this year's budget we had $235.7 million committed to the University of Western Sydney. That is an increase of $15.3 million or 6.9 per cent over last year. This year there were 18,267 fully funded undergraduate places, up by 2,747 since 1996. So I am delighted to see this as yet another demonstration of this government's commitment to the University of Western Sydney. I want to refer to two specific aspects of this legislation. The whole of the $25 million will be a significant boost for Western Sydney, but two aspects are of particular interest to me. One is the $2 million for research and teaching infrastructure at the Hawkesbury campus. This will include a state-of-the-art confocal multiphoton fluorescence microscope system, which will be the only one in Australia. It will put applied science research at the University of Western Sydney Hawkesbury campus at the forefront of some of this research in Australia. The University of Western Sydney Hawkesbury campus has been doing it tough for a number of years-the declining interest in agriculture has been part of the reason for that-but in the last three or four years I have been greatly encouraged to see the numbers rebuilding there. We are one of the leaders in horticulture. We have seen exciting growth in recent years in aspects of applied science, including environmental science and forensic science. We have seen a growth in nursing places, and I want to see that continue. This $2 million for the state-of-the-art research microscope system at US Hawkesbury campus will certainly continue to boost its profile. The second feature I want to focus on is the extra $7 million allocated for the medical school for the University of Western Sydney. I make the point again that this $7 million is in addition to $18 million already committed, so this brings the Australian government's commitment to the US medical school to $25 million. Starting in 2007, this will mean 80 places for medicine, and that will pipeline out to 320 places by 2010. I note that last year the member for Jagajaga criticised the government for committing money for infrastructure but not for places. Again, the member for Jagajaga was wrong. We have a commitment for 80 places to start in 2007, and up to 320 places will be in place by 2010. The building and commencement of a medical school for Western Sydney will be a great boost to this area for two reasons. The first reason is educational. Young ing in Western Sydney who want to study medicine and who have the ability to study medicine will no longer have to spend three to four hours a day travelling from, say, the Blue Mountains or Kurrajong in my electorate of Macquarie into the University of Sydney or the University of New South Wales. They will now be able to study medicine in Western Sydney. This will be of tremendous benefit educationally. More broadly, the establishment of a medical school in Western Sydney will be a great boost for medicine and for health services in Western Sydney generally. Western Sydney does suffer. Our doctor-patient ratio is much lower than it is for most of Sydney. In Western Sydney in my electorate the doctor-patient ratio is one to 1,800, whereas in central Sydney it is one to 825, so we do need to attract GPs to Western Sydney. The government has undertaken a number of other initiatives that are starting to have an impact, and I greatly appreciate those. But this facility will also help to attract doctors to the area, for a couple of reasons. Firstly, some of the places will be bonded places. Students will be allocated places to study medicine at US on the condition that they practise for a certain time in Western Sydney. That will directly add to the supply of GPs in the area. Secondly, students from elsewhere who come to study at US will realise that it is a great place to live. They will put down roots, they will make connections, they will form friendships in the area and they will decide to settle in the area and practise in Western Sydney. So the establishment of a medical faculty there will boost the number of doctors practising in Western Sydney. This legislation is really going to be of significant benefit-and in your electorate of Blaxland as well, Mr Deputy Speaker Hatton. It will benefit all of those who live and people liv- work in Western Sydney. In summing up, I will make one other point. It is a disappointment to me that the New South Wales state government are not willing to help in this enterprise. When the idea of a medical faculty for US was first raised, the then Premier Mr Carr said: ‘Yes, this is a good idea. US needs a medical faculty.' The Australian government have now committed $25 million. There is $25 million on the table. But what do we have from the New South Wales government? No commitment of cash to help, and we really need it. The challenge is there for the New South Wales government. If they are serious about the benefits that a medical school will bring to Western Sydney, they need to match the Australian government's contribution. Even worse than the state government's neglect of US is its iniquitous payroll tax regime, which takes money out of US. I have made the point before that every year the state Labor government takes around $10 million out of the coffers of the University Western Sydney via its payroll tax system. This year we have the Australian government committing some $235 million to the University of Western Sydney and we have the state government saying: ‘Thank you very much. I'll take $10 million of that out and put it into state general revenue.' If the New South Wales government were really committed to the University of Western Sydney, it would be ending that payroll tax regime and supporting the University of Western Sydney in the same way that the Australian government is. I am pleased to support this legislation. brings a significant amount of extra money to the University of Western Sydney. It delivers on a key election commitment to the people of Western Sydney and it will bring substantial benefits to the people of Western Sydney, as well as to the people of North Queensland through its commitment to the James Cook University.

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the extension of funding, particularly in relation to the University of Western Sydney. I wish to speak on the extension of funding for the new medical school at Campbelltown. While I wholeheartedly support the development of a medical school at the Campbelltown campus, I do have some concerns. A $7 million injection of funds into development of the university's medical school is a welcome investment in the south-west of Sydney. It is an investment which I would suggest is well overdue. Although this commitment does not match the one that Labor took to the last election, clearly Labor's commitment of some $43 million has made the government realise that the medical school is something that is needed for our region. The Minister for Education, Science and of Training noted in his second reading speech: The ... medical school will enhance and improve the teaching hospital capacity and the delivery of health and medical services in western and southwestern Sydney. It will also provide opportunities for local students to study medicine in their own region. Might I suggest that the development of this medical school is on track. I am pleased to note that in the week before last the Macarthur Advertiser reported that the Australian Medical Council had approved the first stage of the university's medical school, which gives the university the go-ahead to impleIt ment their medical program. The Advertiser went on to report that over the coming months the university will develop detailed plans, outlining such matters as curricula, staffing facilities, research and clinical placements. It is expected that this second stage of the process will be submitted to the Australian Medical Council for its consideration sometime in February next year. I would like to take this opportunity to commend the work of the dean of the medical school, Professor Neville Yeomans, and the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Western Sydney, Professor Janice Reid, for their hard work in getting the school to this point. They should be recognised for and congratulated on their efforts. The development of a local, high-quality the medical school and medical training infrastructure is extremely important to south-west Sydney and Western Sydney because our region needs more doctors. As a young and rapidly growing community, the ability to find affordable and accessible medical services is essential. In my electorate alone, there are more than 20,000 families with dependent children. Although the medical school will be a welcome addition to the medical infrastructure in the south-west, it is a medium-term proposition and the government continues to fail to address the shortterm needs of this community. In 2004, it was estimated that Australia needed up to 3,000 more GPs. Consider that in conjunction with the report by the Medical Observer last year which indicated that 57 per cent of those GPs surveyed believed that general practice was not a good career choice for students. Having regard to that statistic, hope the government intends to integrate its policy approaches to medical training and workplace planning. The Campbelltown campus will not produce a fully qualified doctor until 2012. While its contribution over the longer period is likely to be immense, families in my electorate and throughout the south-west of Sydney need the government to do more right now to increase the supply of doctors and affordable and accessible health services within this region. At the outset, I mentioned that I had some concerns. My concerns do not directly relate to the appropriation of $7 million to the university but rather to the notion that this will mean that local students can automatically access the medical school. I understand that all students will have that access, subject to meeting the relevant education standards. I also understand that prospective students will be subject to a battery of aptitude tests and interviews. My concern is that, due to the decade of neglect of tertiary education under this government, local students may be priced out of the education market. I am concerned that, because of the quite draconian changes to student income support over the last decade, many students and their families are placed under considerable financial pressure when they undertake university studies. Often parents contact my office to seek some insight into why this government is making it even more difficult for their children to get a university education by subjecting them to an income test to receive the youth allowance. The income test is not based on the income of the student but on the income of the supporting parents. Labor took to the last election its policy aimed at improving income support for students while they study. I note that the Australian ViceChancellors Committee, in its submission to the 2005 Commonwealth budget, called on the federal government to improve income I support for students but, alas, the government has not acted on that submission. I am concerned that the belief behind the strong community support for the medical school, which is predicated on the basis that the sons and daughters in greater Western Sydney will have access to it, will not necessarily translate into reality. In my electorate, the 2001 census reported that only six per cent of the people had attained a bachelor degree or higher. Many of those people were among the first in their families to receive a university education, because a university education was not placed beyond their reach. The importance of having a high-quality, local university is not lost on my constituents. When I was studying, I would have appreciated the opportunity to attend a local school rather than attending lectures in Sydney and making that late-night trek home. To some extent, for people who studied in those days-and particularly for those who lived in Campbelltown-it was half dangerous. It was not dangerous in respect of personal security but, in those days, you did not catch the normal suburban train home to Campbelltown. At that hour of the night, you lined up to catch the Cooma Mail. You could not afford to get too comfortable on that train because, as the member for Macarthur will know, if you missed Campbelltown, you were likely to end up in the Southern Highlands or somewhere between there and Goulburn. The students who follow us will at least not have to brave the ventures of part-time study in Sydney and travel home to Campbelltown. Recently I spoke to Dr Andrew MCDonald, the Director of Paediatrics at Macarthur Health Services. He is right behind the medical school and is looking forward to integrating the local hospital network with the school. He knows the quality of health care professionals in our area and is confident that the medical school, with the support of the region's hospitals, will produce high-quality doctors. While no-one can ever be certain that locating a medical school in Western Sydney will produce more doctors who live and work in the region, I am heartened by the findings of a number of studies that in fact suggest as much. The evidence suggests that students from rural and regional backgrounds often end up practising in rural or regional areas. It is my understanding that the likelihood of this occurring is heightened when these students have the opportunity to study in or near the areas which they are from. I am confident, with the support of the local hospitals, with the support of highquality health care professionals such as Dr MCDonald and his team, who are currently practising in our area, and with the support of the local community, that once students have the opportunity to experience all that our region has to offer they may make the decision to stay. I hope it is the case that students from south-west and from Western Sydney do get the opportunity to study at this medical school, because they already know what a great place the region is and what a great place it is to raise a family. I would be reasonably confident that the majority of graduates who come through that infrastructure would continue to see some purpose in living and practising within our region.
