I hope the funding in conjunction with the government's tertiary education policies will not mean that the first generation of people from this region to have reasonable access to a university education will be the last. I hope that the medical school will act as an inspiration for the local students to study hard in the knowledge that they could end up studying at a fantastic institution that is just down the road from their families and their longestablished personal support networks. The University of Western Sydney medical school was suggested by a Labor Premier and later adopted by this government, and as a Labor member I have to say that I am extremely proud to support it. The school has been supported by the Labor state government, contrary to the suggestion from the member for Macquarie, as the state government intends to provide a site adjacent to or within the Liverpool Hospital grounds for the development of support facilities. The University of Western Sydney is a fine institution and I support its aim to develop a distinctive and innovative school that will support and integrate with our local community. I look forward to the extension of the Campbelltown campus of the university and the development of the medical school itself. Not long ago the university launched a Bachelor of Laws program. I can report that this has proven to be a success, with many graduates who have studied at the campus continuing their association with the region by living and working there. I noted recently the on the Whitlam Institute's online forum on the medical school that a student from the university made the following contribution: Indeed, it not only makes good strategic sense to establish a medical school in Western Sydney ... For why should people residing in greater Western Sydney have to travel up to one hour and half to attend a medical school, when the best training ground is in their own back yard? I think that is a reasonable quote. It is important to realise that for south-west Sydney to grow we should have resources like those of the medical school being developed. South-west Sydney has much to offer. It is certainly a ground for significant development not only in industrial production; it is also an area where we are producing many fine students who will be there to service the higher technical industries as they develop. I did mention earlier that, having had the opportunity to meet with and discuss matters with Dr MCDonald, I understand the supportive role that does fall to the medical profession in developing further professionals-in his case paediatricians-to be supplied within that area. We do have very committed medical practitioners residing within the region, and I think their contribution certainly needs to be acknowledged in this debate as well. This is not just a matter of making a contribution of $7 million and establishing the medical school; this is the combination of a lot of hard work by many peopleincluding people in this House, which I will freely acknowledge-who are committed to improving the lot of Western Sydney and to the development of educational facilities and clearly focused on what is necessary if they are to advance and improve the productiveness of greater Western Sydney, which obviously encompasses a number of electorates, including that of the member for Macarthur and my own. I am proud to be here to support the efforts to have this medical school established. I look forward to seeing, by the year 2012, doctors being produced by this facility. I would very much hope that the statistics and reports that I quoted earlier do come to fruition. I hope that we manage to attract and retain within south-west Sydney many of the practitioners that would otherwise be encouraged to go elsewhere-places other than Liverpool, Campbelltown and their surrounds. I indicate that, apart from the facilities of the university, there will be a significant integration of training facilities at hospitals such as Campbelltown Hospital and the Liverpool Hospital-and I understand that there will possibly be discussions with Camden Hospital-which will have a significant effect in the placing of students during their practical training. Also, those hospitals will significantly contribute to the educational development of students who attend the medical school on the Campbelltown campus. Those facilities are already staffed by people who are not only qualified but very dedicated professionals. From my discussions with those people, I understand their level of support for this facility. Their personal support is unquestionable. They will certainly do everything that they can possibly do to facilitate the building of strong links so there will be a teaching hospital capability closely linked through curriculum and medical facilities with the school as it is developed at the Campbelltown campus. As I indicated, notwithstanding the concerns I have expressed, I support the development of this institution. I look forward to its opening. Moreover, I look forward to the Campbelltown campus being expanded to include the medical school and to seeing local students given the opportunity to participate and aspire to such a wonderful thing as being a doctor servicing people throughout my local area. I look forward to the prospect of having those students retained as doctors servicing our community.

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: MacarthurParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.02 pm)-In summing up debate on the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005 I would like to thank the members of this House who have spoken on the bill for their interest in the issues. However, I wish to correct a few comments made by the member for Jagajaga at the start of the debate and the many errors contained in them. The member for Jagajaga spoke at some length about the financial health of the university sector. I am happy to inject some facts into the picture of doom that she represented here in this place. In 2003, the followthe ing results were reported. Sector revenue was $11.9 billion, an increase of around $650 million from 2002. Total net assets were $22.8 billion. Cash investments were $5.6 billion. Over the past five years, net investments and capital assets have totalled $5.2 billion. The financial health of the university sector is strong indeed. The member for Jagajaga also spoke about the purported massive increase in the number of full fee paying students in Australian universities. Again, the facts show exactly the opposite. Last year, there were only 16,299 full fee paying domestic undergraduate students in public universities, of whom 6,086 were undertaking summer and winter courses outside their regular semester study. This number was around three per cent of all domestic undergraduate students in public universities-hardly a massive increase in domestic full fee paying students. The member for Jagajaga made much of the reported high fees for some courses, including a combined medical and law degree at Monash University, reported to cost $256,000. In fact, the university has advised that the combined degree is not currently offered on a fee paying basis, and no decision has been taken to offer it on this basis in 2006. This is clearly scaremongering. The member for Jagajaga claimed that the OECD figures show that the government has taken Australia backward in educational participation and attainment. In fact, educational attainment levels have been increasing steadily. In 1998, some 25.4 per cent of Australians aged between 25 and 64 had tertiary qualifications, according to the OECD. In 2002, this figure was 31 per cent. Australia still has the highest school expectancy, or years in study, at 21.1 years, according to the OECD. Finally, the member for Jagajaga raised issue of the higher education triennium report-a report put out by the Department of Education, Science and Training each year on the state of higher education in this country. I am happy to say that that report will be available in September. I look forward to the member for Jagajaga having the chance to digest some of the facts in this sector and making a more accurate and informed contribution on higher education at her next opportunity to speak. I would now like to reiterate a few points about the bill before the House. The bill is a further illustration of how the Australian education sector will benefit from the record $7.8 billion investment that the Australian government has made in this sector in the 2005-06 budget. As members will be aware, the policies of this government have resulted in record numbers of students accessing university. The Australian government is making available more Commonwealth funded places than ever before, with 409,393 places this year, an increase of more than 12,000 places over last year. The Australian government is also addressing student demand by funding over 39,000 new student places over five years between 2004 and 2009. These places will enable an estimated additional 50,000 students to study full time or part time at university. The measures in this bill will further strengthen the facilities and the infrastructure available to our universities. As a federal spokesperson for Western Sydney, I and my Western Sydney colleagues are proud to be members of the Howard government, a government that delivers on its commitments to improve the educational options and opportunities for all people in Western Sydney and beyond. This bill will provide the University of Western Sydney with $25 million for new capital infrastructure funding to boost teaching, research and facilities for students over the next three years. As members will recall, in the 2004-05 budget the government pledged $18 million towards the establishment of the university's new medical school in order to encourage school students in the outer suburbs of Sydney to study medicine and to contribute to their own community. If people study medicine in their local area, there is a good chance they will practise medicine in their local area. This bill provides a further $7 million to the university's medical school for 2006, making a total government contribution towards the medical school of $25 million. The new medical school will serve the welldocumented medical needs of the Western Sydney community and will provide opportunities for students from Western Sydney to study medicine in their own local area. The Western Sydney community will further benefit through the provision in this bill of $7 million for the university's construction of a new library at its Penrith campus. The new funding for this critical facility will provide library services for US staff and students but, just as importantly, also benefit the wider Penrith community, like many other universities around Australia do. This bill also assists students at the University of Western Sydney by providing an additional $9 million towards the establishment of a new teaching building at the University of Western Sydney's Parramatta campus. Furthermore, this bill provides an additional $2 million to the University of Western Sydney's Hawkesbury campus to upgrade its research and training facilities. As members would be aware, the university has a long history of providing high-quality agricultural education at Hawkesbury. The funding provided through this bill will further enhance the delivery of educational courses that are of direct benefit to the Australian agricultural sector. These initiatives reflect the Australian government's ongoing commitment to building better community facilities and providing improved education and opportunities for the people of Western Sydney. The University of Western Sydney puts the people of Western Sydney at the heart of its mission. The university has set itself an aim that over the next 10 years its teaching facilities and practices, research activities, student experiences and community engagement will rank among the best in Australia. The people of Western Sydney deserve no less. In addition to the $25 million of new support to the University of Western Sydney contained in this bill, the Australian government is providing $25.9 million to strengthen the educational and research opportunities in North Queensland. Members would recall that earlier this year the government provided $12 million over two years towards the new veterinary science and agricultural school at James Cook University's Townsville campus. In recognition of the importance of the study of tropical sciences the government is providing $26 million to James Cook University to fund teaching and research in veterinary science and tropical agriculture. This bill will fund courses in veterinary science and tropical agriculture at James Cook University. It will establish a new undergraduate degree program and provide 50 new places for the courses, including studies in the prevention and early detection of diseases in livestock. The bill also provides an additional 50 places for new undergraduate degree programs in tropical agriculture, giving graduates expertise in tropical plants and exposure to research in vital agricultural eas, such as sugar cane production. These 100 new places in veterinary science and tropical agriculture will commence next year, and by 2009 future undergraduate numbers will rise to 274 places at a cost of $13.9 million. As we have seen elsewhere, new diseases can have devastating consequences across nations, affecting both their rural and urban communities. We must take steps to place Australia at the forefront of the cutting edge research to avert such disasters here. These new undergraduate degrees will provide Australia with expert understanding in the fields of tropical animal diseases and tropical culture, which is vital to Australia's national prosperity. Breakthroughs in the production and the knowledge of plants that thrive in a tropical climate can boost crop production and improve the livelihoods of many Australians, particularly those in the regional and rural communities. It is essential that Australians continue to develop expertise in these fields. The establishment of the new veterinary science and tropical agriculture schools and undergraduate courses will help position James Cook University as a global leader in teaching and research in these fields, further enhancing Australia's international reputation. The funding provided to James Cook University through this bill reflects the Australian government's recognition of the unique contribution that regional higher education institutions like James Cook University make to their local communities, for students from rural and regional areas and to our national prosperity. This bill will also amend the maximum funding amounts under the Higher Education Support Act 2003 and the maximum amounts for transition funding under the Higher Eduar- cation Funding Act 1998 to reflect indexation increases. This bill will enhance both the quality of our higher education systems and the choices available to our students. It also reflects the Australian government's strong commitment to ensuring that our universities continue to play a vital role in Australia's economic, cultural and social development. I urge all members of this House to support this bill. Question agreed to. Bill read a second time. Message from the Governor General recagri- ommending appropriation announced. Third Reading

Speaker: Mr FARMER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: MacarthurParliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.14 pm)-by leave-I move: That this bill be now read a third time. Question agreed to. Bill read a third time. NA AMENDMENT (SMALL BUSINESS EMPLOYMENT PROTECTION) BILL 2004 Second Reading Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Mr Andrews: That this bill be now read a second time. upon which Mr Stephen Smith moved by way of amendment: That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: “whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House: (1) noting that the nation's independent umpire in industrial relations matters, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC), has examined and heard submissions concerning the impact of redundancy payments on small business; (2) noting that the AIRC has found that the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small businesses across the board does not have the capacity to pay severance pay; but (3) recognising the circumstances of those individual small business which are incapable of making redundancy payments, and calls on the Government to comply with the AIRC decision and to adopt mechanisms to address those individual businesses with a genuine incapacity to make redundancy payments”.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: It is another day and we have another bill showing yet again the government's ideological approach to industrial relations. The government has a blinkered view and a divisive approach. There is a preparedness on the part of the government to bend over backwards to meet the extreme views of its constituency. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 again demonstrates that, despite its rhetoric, it is not a government that is governing for all Australians. I have been involved for more than 35 years in aspects of industrial relations in this country. I have had many negotiations, discussions and understandings with people about the best way to get the best results. I have always found that most people are reasonable and are willing to see the other person's point of view. It has taught me that it is much better to take the cooperative and consultative approach, but that has never been a lesson that this government has understood or practised. It prefers to hammer an ideology and it prefers division and disagreement rather than discussion and agreement. It is very interesting that this government, having been re-elected, refuses to stand by its promise that no worker would be disadvantaged under its brave new world of workplace regulation. Of course they will be disadvantaged. I spoke last week about legislation that would see that disadvantage occasioned. This bill also makes workers worse off. Worst of all, it also seeks to overturn a decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission-a decision of the independent umpire. Now that this government has the numbers in both houses, it will legislate away what a tribunal has determined on the merits of the case presented to it. Quite frankly, it is un-Australian not to accept the umpire's decision. There were a few Australians who were not too happy with the Damien Martyn dismissal last night, but the Australian cricket team with all the tensions involved accepted the decision and went on to get a remarkable draw in the circumstances. It is un-Australian not to accept the umpire's decision, but that is what this bill does: it overturns the umpire's decision-a decision which gave employees of small businesses fair redundancy provisions and which was arrived at when parties had had the opportunity to put their case. The commission said that redundancy pay is to compensate employees for the loss of entitlements and credits and for hardship when they are made redundant. The commission's decision was consistent with moves at the state level to provide for redundancy pay for employees of all businesses. That is what the commission and the states have determined and that is what is fair, but not in the eyes of this government. This bill seeks to overturn that decision. The minister says that it is a flawed decision. We know that the government went to the last election promising the following: A re-elected Coalition will continue to pursue changes to take the unfair dismissal laws burden off the back of small business and protect small business from redundancy payments. In other words, that means that they are going to make it easier to sack people and strip away their protection. That is what it means. They were prepared to assert that in the context of a decision arrived at in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the AIRC. The government talks about the need to protect. I accept that it is important to protect the interests of small business, but it is also important to protect the interests of the people who work for them. It is important to protect people like 15-year-old Deanna Renella-who I spoke about in this place last week and will return to later-an employee of a national franchise chain, Bakers Delight. What about the protection of people like her? That is where the government lacks balance and fairness. This bill seeks to remove redundancy pay requirements for small businesses with fewer than 15 employees, cancel the commission's decision and override any state laws that provide for redundancy pay for small businesses. The minister says that this legislation does not prohibit the employers from agreeing to redundancy provisions and reaching agreement with their employees, but they are prohibiting the commission determining that outcome when the parties cannot reach agreement. This is a fallacious argument on the part of the government. They say that they want to encourage relationships between employers and employees that envisage this, but, when parties cannot reach agreement and the commission determines-that is the commission's role-on the case and merits put by the employers and employees and comes down in favour of the decision, the government say, ‘No, you cannot have it; we are going to overturn it.' In other words, they reject the merits of the case and just proceed with their ideological thrust. I pose a question to the parliamentary secretary at the table and to the government: how realistic is it to expect the balance to be in favour of the employee when they front up to an employer? What do you think an employer is going to say when the employee says, ‘By the way, after that set of conditions, I also want two weeks pay for every year of service if I am made redundant'? What do you think the employer is going to say? It is a fatuous argument; it is nonsense. That is why for a century in this country we have had the Industrial Relations Commission, the independent umpire. But this is a government that is now prepared to torch it, to burn it. If anyone doubts my statement about the balance between employer and employee look at what a judge in the Industrial Relations Court of South Australia had to say in the case I referred to earlier. This is what Judge MCCusker had to say on the ability, the balance if you like, of an employee to be able to stand up and bargain on the same terms with an experienced employer: In considering this submission I leave aside for the moment the manifest disadvantage of the respective bargaining positions of a 15 year-old Year 10 student negotiating her terms with an experienced businessman. Of course, he is right. Here is the government talking principle and protection but allowing the types of draconian industrial relations laws and practices that it is overseehave ing to tip the balance. I heard the Prime Minister last night in an address to the Australian Industry Group and here today in the parliament saying that it is not the the playing field in favour of the employer. If it is not the intention it is certainly what is happening. I believe, quite frankly, that it is the intention because you cannot believe a word the Prime Minister says on this, particularly when he has ditched his no disadvantage test. We on this side of the House accept that small businesses do need some protections. They do need, in the case of the unfair dismissal situation, an ability to deal with the problems of redundancies where there have been litigious and vexatious employees, where demands have been made on them for hush money, where they have been pursued and encouraged by ambulance chasers, where they have been encouraged to pay goaway money and where small businesses that cannot afford the time or the money to defend themselves in court have been forced to pay. They do need protection from those sorts of circumstances. Every time this government, on whatever number of occasions, brought their unfair dismissal legislation into this parliament Labor proposed amendments to give that protection to small businesses, to look after their interests. On every one of those occasions the government were not interested in accommodating or embracing those amendments. They just want the blanket ability to make it easier to sack employees-to improve employment prospects by making it easier to sack people. I have never heard anything more ridiculous in my whole life, and I have had to deal in practical terms with a lot of these issues and a lot of these disputes. The government of the day has to set the framework in which the parties can negotiate and if they cannot resolve it they can access to an independent umpire. That is the only sensible way these issues can go. If there are people exploiting the system by all means make amendments in the way we intention to tilt have suggested. In relation to the unfair dismissal proposals, we even proposed alternatives that exempted small businesses. Now the government, not content to make exemptions in the case of small businesses, wants to classify and make those exemptions in the case of companies employing fewer than 100 people. Of course, the Treasurer of the country wants to go even further and extend the ability to sack people to any company in the country. This legislation does not address the issue that we have talked about. Labor have proposed sensible amendments previously; the government should look at them again and come back and present a more balanced approach than the one we are experiencing today. Our proposed amendments address the real issues faced by small businesses whilst providing protection and assistance to employees-protection for both sides. We are not stripping protection away from one side and tilting the playing field in favour of the other. Our proposals note that the commission does not believe that in general small businesses do not have the capacity to pay severance pay but it does recognise the fact that some small businesses may not be able to pay. What also concerns me about this legislation is that it may also affect workers' other legitimate entitlements. The General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS, meets certain employee entitlements in the event that an employer is unable to pay them due to insolvency. GEERS is not legislated, but the government accepted at the time that the community standard of eight weeks pay for redundancy entitlements was the norm. Presumably, it now no longer accepts that community standard. GEERS requires a legal obligation before it pays. This bill may remove that sion. So I would be interested to know, when the government responds on this bill, whether it has the effect on GEERS that I have outlined. Labor have proposed a better alternative in this field too-a trust fund to protect the entitlements of all employees, not just those who happen to work for the company that the Prime Minister's brother was chairman of. The only time the full entitlements of employees have ever been protected in this country was when Stan Howard's company got into trouble. We propose the introduction of a trust fund that would have exempted from contributions all small businesses. Here we would have had a win-win outcomeprotection for employees and protection for small business because they would not have had to pay. The government again ignored that constructive suggestion because it prefers blind ideology to real solutions. We have now entered an Orwellian world where, as in Animal Farm, four legs good, two legs bad. For this government everything is either black or white: business is good; employees are bad. Do not listen to their rhetoric, look at their track record: AWAs good; collective agreements are bad. We are prepared to discuss these issues, to look to solutions to reach agreement, but that can only happen if the other side is prepared to do so too. I want to return to the Baker's Delight case because it is instructive in terms of AWAs and the way in which this bill seeks to strip away protections for certain employees. I raised this matter in the House last week and the Leader of the Opposition questioned the Prime Minister in relation to it. In response, the Prime Minister said that the 15year-old worker concerned was not covered by a valid AWA. This is correct. He said that the 15-year-old worker was a casual worker proviand had been underpaid according to the relevant South Australian award. That is also true. That is true, but it is not the point at issue here. Her AWA was only invalid due to a technicality because it had not been filed-it had not been properly witnessed and lodged. If it had been witnessed and lodged properly, she would have been able to have been paid at the lower rate. The court was only able to order restitution in her case for the underpayment of the award rate, the $1,500 payment, because the AWA had not been properly filed. I make that point because the Prime Minister promised that there would be no-one worse off as a result of going on to an AWA. This is the famous no disadvantage test. Clearly, this girl could have been disadvantaged as a result of going on to an AWA. She not only could have been underpaid but also could have lost her sick leave, her annual leave and her annual leave loading-so much for the Prime Minister's guarantee of no disadvantage. She would have been paid less and she would not have been entitled to those entitlements that I just mentioned beare cause they would have been included in her pay rate-a pay rate 25 per cent lower than the award rate. We even had the situation in which the employer, Yurong Holdings, attempted to argue that the worker was allowed to take home a loaf of bread and that that should be taken into account. I have heard the argument ‘Let them eat cake,' but now, under the brave new world of industrial relations that the Prime Minister talks about, we are paying people with loaves of bread. This is an outrage, yet it is the system that this government is encouraging. It gets worse, because the employer tried to blacken the worker's reputation-a 15year-old girl-by saying that she ‘is believed to be responsible for a till deficit of $751'. The judge in this case said: This is a very grave allegation. It is pressed on appeal. Yet not one piece of probative evidence beyond assertion was identified or suggested to back it up. This is the brave new world of AWAs. This is the evenness, the protection and the no disadvantage that the Prime Minister talks about. No wonder he is not prepared to give a no disadvantage test now, because it is worth nothing in the current climate, and he is going to strip it away. I make this point because it is terribly important: the girl in that case was able to get restitution because the court ordered that she be paid. Why? Because the technical failure to lodge the AWA meant she was not covered by an AWA and had to be covered by the industrial law of South Australia. But what about the other 50 workers employed by the same company under precisely the same terms where the AWA was validly lodged? These people must be underpaid too by any reasonable objective test, yet they cannot get restitution. That is the problem. Here we have a government that says, ‘Unions cannot have collective pattern bargaining,' but is prepared to condone pattern bargaining in terms of AWAs that strip away entitlements and underpay people. The no disadvantage test cited by this government is worthless. This legislation is stripping away collective rights and undermining entitlements. It is bad legislation and it should be opposed (Time expired).

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Mitchell) (7.35 pm)The previous speaker, the member for Hotham, raised one issue of a girl working for MCDonald's in South Australia as being the total basis of Labor's opposition to this proposal. Let me go through some of the cases that have been described by the former opposition spokesman for small business, the member for Watson, as ‘go-away money'. Let me describe some of the instances of goaway money that have been the cause of the government's concern and small business's concern about this issue. Sharan Burrow, in a presentation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Human Services inquiry into balancing work and family claimed that research shows that 93 per cent of employees in the private sector on individual contracts have no additional family rights. Let us have a look at that research and get some accuracy because, as always, the Australian Labor Party's comments have to be read in detail and then referred to the original statements. The ACTU omits the following information, which has come from the research that Sharan Burrow quoted from. AWA employees are more satisfied than collective employees that they are rewarded for their effort-44 per cent to 29 per cent. Nearly twice as many AWA recipients compared with employees on collective agreements are happy with their reward. This is the research that Sharan Burrow would not quote. Out of a range of figures indicating how successful AWAs have been for most employees, she chose to quote to a parliamentary committee one figure on family issues, neglecting to mention the others. I will go through them. AWA employees are more satisfied with the change in their pay and conditions-38 per cent to 29 per cent; that is a 50 per cent advantage for people on AWAs compared with those on collective agreements. AWA employees felt they had more influence over decisions affecting them in the workplace69 per cent to 65 per cent. AWA employees were more likely to say that stress in the workplace had reduced over the last two years-19 per cent to 14 per cent; while collective employees are more likely to say stress has increased-49 per cent to 37 per cent. AWA employees are more likely to say that management does its best to get along with staff-64 per cent to 44 per cent. AWA employees are more likely to feel that management gives them a say in how they do their job-58 per cent to 35 per cent. Giving only an insignificant part of the story forms the basis of the way the Australian Labor Party is operating during this debate, and that is pretty typical. The minister today indicated how workers in small businesses would continue to be protected against inappropriate conduct by their employers. For example, it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss or victimise an employee for refusing to agree to a new workplace agreement. That is not being run by the Australian union movement or the Australian Labor Party. They say that people will be penalised by being sacked if they do not agree to a new workplace agreement. That is not true. It is a blatant lie being told by the union movement and the ALP on this issue. The Office of the Employment Advocate will continue to provide a strong inspection service. In 2003-04, the Office of Workplace Services concluded over 4,700 investigations into breaches of federal industrial law. But what did the leader of the ACTU say in these circumstances? She said, ‘I need a dad or a mum of someone who has been seriously injured or killed; that would be fantastic to run'-I suppose, as part of their publicity campaign. What a way to look at these issues, just to search for the tragic loss of an individual to publicise the union part of this campaign. Let us look at some of the specifics. Why does small business feel so reluctant to employ when there is the prospect of unfair dismissals? Sharan Burrow says, ‘It's only a matter of process; fix up the process and everything will be okay.' The previous speaker for the opposition tended to say the same thing-‘We are now ready to talk; we are now ready to listen to the government.' For years those opposite have rejected the government's approach to consider, for small business, a modification. Peter Reith and subsequent ministers, Tony Abbott and now Kevin Andrews, have tried many times to talk logically to the Australian Labor Party. The Australian Labor Party in every instance in the Senate rejected our approaches about making it fairer for small business. Even your shadow spokesman, Tony Burke, said that this was go-away money that was being demanded. He said, ‘There is go-away money being demanded'-and there is. Let me give you a few examples. Mr Tanner interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: If the member for Melbourne wishes to speak, perhaps he should rise and seek the call.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: The member at the table should be very interested to hear of an employee of a manufacturer who was dismissed for physically assaulting a coworker. The New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission reinstated the employee, finding that there had been an unfair dismissal. An employee from another factory was dismissed for sleeping on the job and falsifying the attendance records. But, in an extraordinary decision, the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission determined that the dismissal was unfair. He had been sleeping on the job and falsifying the records and was then reinstated. This is happening time and again. Small business knows of these instances, so why would they be prepared to employ extra people? They know that, if the process goes to court, there is a cost of between $5,000 and $20,000. So what do they do? They pay go-away money to the employee involved. In another instance an employee removed over $15,000 from a safe, lent it to an offduty colleague and then falsified the reconciliation documents relating to the safe. The money was gambled away and the employee was sacked. He was subsequently reinstated by the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission to a supervisory position where he still would be responsible for large amounts of cash, notwithstanding his complete breach of protocol and the employer's trust. Under the unfair dismissal provisions of the legislation that Laurie Brereton brought into this place, which was approved by this parliament, that is the stupid situation we have with small business and the reinstatement of people. This government has been consistently trying to get rid of the problems the Brereton legislation has created. Not all of these instances make the front page of newspapers, but the Daily Telegraph on Monday, 4 July told the story of the New South Wales Department of Education and Training being incapable of doing anything and being unprepared to sack a teacher who had been convicted of possessing 600 images of child pornography. This teacher in the New South Wales system was convicted of possessing 600 pages of pornography and the department was not prepared to sack this person because it feared being hit with another unfair dismissal case. Why did the New South Wales Department of Education and Training feel this way? Because the department had recently had to reinstate and pay out $28,000 to a teacher it had sacked for having an affair with a pupil, the department was not prepared to move when it found another teacher with 600 pages of child pornography. That is how this process is working. The Australian subsidiary of an offshore manufacturer had a major problem with an aggressive employee who engaged in verbal abuse and other intimidatory behaviour against other employees and management. A serious concern for this employer was the length of time that due process took to dismiss the employee under the present New South Wales legislation. Legal costs of some $40,000 were incurred, but the greatest concerns were the safety, morale and OH&S problems that persisted until the employee could be removed from the premises. So there were long, protracted processes, with the troubled person still on the job and the employer being unable to remove the individual. Therefore, the dangerous situation continued and legal costs amounted to $40,000 to get rid of and solve the problem. A tourist operator received complaints from the passengers of a particular bus driver. The passengers complained that the driver was rude and had taken the passengers on an alcohol-induced wild ride. The bus operator gave the bus driver a chance to redeem himself only to find that another group of passengers were also taken on a wild ride. The sacked driver took the operator to the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission. The commission found the employer was justified in sacking the driver but then found that the operator had to pay his own costs of $12,000. The operator is no longer in business. This is the thing that employers fear. This is the thing that worries them. I have them in my electorate, and they come to see me. A pub owner employed a young woman who said that she wanted to work part time, four days a week. Within two weeks she had told him that she wanted to work only two days a week and, two weeks later, said that she was pregnant and wanted to work only one day. The pub owner said, ‘I'm sorry. I really wanted somebody for four days; that was what you were employed to do. I am going to have to let you go and get somebody who can work for four days.' He let her go, and there was an unfair dismissal claim of $10,000. That bloke nearly lost the pub and nearly lost the capacity to continue his business. He did not have a spare $10,000 in cash to resolve this matter. He came to see me and I tried to resolve the matter. The court had decided that he had to pay the money and, even though the terms and conditions of employment were clearly stated and understood by the employee, they were abused by the employee and this small business man found himself up for the amount of $10,000. It is completely unfair. But the protection needs to remain for employees, and the protection will remain for employees, as the minister said today. It will be unlawful for people to be dismissed if they refuse to sign an AWA. That will not change. It will continue to be unlawful for people to force someone else into an AWA that they do not want or to dismiss somebody for a temporary absence from work due to illness or disability. All that will continue; will not change. But the crazy idea that unfair dismissal meant that you could dream up something, that you could have a grievance against an employer, that you could be vexatious in your claims or that you could be angry because you had lost your job and wanted to get back at your employer is going to be removed, because it is stalling employment opportunities for others. Those who make angry or vexatious claims, those who can see an easy way of claiming $5,000 to $10,000 from a former employer, are going to have to find a different way of earning their money because this is going to stop. They will no longer be able to get at the employer for easy cash. They are going to have to find different ways of getting their money, and it is only fair that they should make way for those following behind them who want to work. Another story is that of a manufacturing company repeatedly warning an employee about inappropriate conduct and language. A final warning was given to the employee when he threw a tool at another employee. The employee was finally sacked when he again verbally abused another employee. So this guy was a menace to his own workmates and to himself, throwing tools at them and abusing them. The employee brought an unfair dismissal claim, and the commission found that the employer acted fairly towards the employee in relation to procedural issues. Therefore, the proper warnings were given and the appropriate processes were gone through in relation to this employee, who had been abusive to his workmates and to those around him in throwing tools at them. The commission found that the process the employer had gone through of warning this guy, saying that his behaviour was unacceptable and then finally sacking him was satisfactory and that the employer had followed all the procedural processes. But the comit mission then determined that the abusive behaviour and remarks to other employees was not a valid reason for summary dismissal. The commission determined that the dismissal was unfair and awarded compensation to the applicant, in addition to substantial costs to the employer in the form of management time and legal costs. I have another story. A US professional service organisation decided to close its office in Australia. A manager who was on maternity leave at the time received redundancy pay and all other entitlements. This person was the company's representative. The professional services organisation decided to close its doors. The manager, who was on maternity leave, quite appropriately received redundancy pay and all the other entitlements. Nonetheless she alleged that the decision was taken in response to her being absent on maternity leave and claimed additional compensation through an unfair dismissal claim. The US based employer, unfamiliar with the principles that operate in this country and with Australian law and concerned that the allegations could affect its reputation, engaged a solicitor. It is normal for an overseas company to want to maintain its good name. In spite of the claim having no merit whatsoever, the employer became concerned that its defence would consume excessive resources and settled with a payout. That is what it is about: the capacity to bluff somebody into paying you when there is no reason to receive payment-and that has to stop. This needs to stop in Australia. is a cancer that eats away at the relationships between people, particularly people in small businesses-the very businesses whose livelihoods and success depend on trust between a small number of people. That is what is eating at the core of small business employment in Australia today. The Australian Labor Party has had many opportunities to agree with changes. If it was the process that was the problem, as Sharan Burrows is now saying, we could have agreed to a process and we could have settled it in the Senate. But the Australian Labor Party decided, ‘No, we'll tough it out'. The game has changed and it is going to go through and be restored to where it should be. It is not going to be unfair to employees, because every employee in Australia is going to have these basic protections. Those in large businesses will have a few additional ones, but those in small businesses will have all the basic protections of their salaries, holidays, sick leave and unfair dismissal if there is a dismissal for not signing an AWA or for temporary absence or illness-it will continue to be unlawful to dismiss a worker because of absence at work due to family responsibilities. All of that will continue. It will continue to be unlawful to dismiss an employee for filing a complaint or participating in proceedings against an employer involved in alleged violation of laws and regulations. None of these things are going to change. They are all going to be there. The protections for employees in small businesses remain. What will go is the capacity to dream up some trumped up charge against a former employer and threaten them with court-threaten them into having to take time off and leave their place of business and not be able to carry out their duties because there is only a small number of people in the enterprise, and threaten them with financial damage because of the need to be off the job It defending a trumped up case in a court. That is going to change because those former employees are going to have to find genuine cause from now on as to why the employer has dealt badly with them. I have read out probably a dozen cases and one from my electorate. I know that there are many more out there like this, and all the Australian Labor Party can come up with is a case that is under the current law and not even an unfair dismissal case, claiming that as the reason why these changes should be opposed. I have never heard such a weak argument. I have never seen Simon Crean on such thin ice. I have never seen the leaders of the Australia Labor Party grasping at straws like this to make a case. I have never seen the ACTU so desperate that they want to see a person dead on the job or maimed or seriously injured in order to support their case. I think it is disgusting that the Australian Labor Party can so abuse workers-its so called supporters; half its membership-in this way. I know Australia is going to change for the better when this change comes into place. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: I am not entirely surprised that the member for Mitchell has problems understanding what we are saying, because he is clearly speaking to the wrong bill. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 does not deal with unlawful termination; this bill concerns whether or not small businesses should have exemption for redundancy payments. It is an important matter for us to debate and the member for Mitchell was clearly speaking to the wrong bill. He was obviously focusing his energies on unlawful termination when what he should have been doing was considering the bill before us and, indeed, the amendments moved by the member for Perth. This bill reminds me of the extent to which the government is willing to go to override any other party who would like to determine a particular matter-in this particular case, of course, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It was charged with the responsibility of listening to parties, pursuant to the Workplace Relations Act 1996, making applications on whether or not there should be changes to the TCR provisions to allow the possibility for employees to be in receipt of redundancy payment if they were made redundant and happen to be unlucky enough to work in a small workplace-for an employer with fewer than 15 employees. That is the nub of this matter. Last year the full bench of the Industrial Relations Commission determined that, yes, there should be some capacity for Australian workers who work for a company with fewer than 15 employees to be in receipt of some payment if indeed they were unfortunately retrenched. There were a number of reasons why the commission determined that way. I can assure all members in this place of this: the ACTU made its applications, the major employer bodies made their applications and the commission rejected parts of all submissions made and determined what they believed to be a balanced and reasonable decision. In the end they sought to amend the TCR provisions so as to include the capacity for employees in those smaller workplaces to be in receipt of redundancy. They acknowledged that there would be circumstances in which small businesses may not be able to pay, and so they went to the matter of incapacity to pay. But they also recognised the changing nature of our economy and the fact that a much greater proportion of employees are now working for smaller employers since the 1984 TCR decision was made. Twenty years on, the commission, headed by Justice Giudice-a government appointee, and some would argue a wise president, but certainly someone who has standing in society-who indeed presided over this matter, determined that there had to be some way in which employees were not unreasonably discriminated against by their fate of working for an employer with fewer than 15 employees. So the decision determined to allow for a maximum of eight weeks payment if someone were so tragically made redundant. I for one do not agree with the contention that we on this side do not accept that it is a difficulty for small businesses. In fact, today the government had an opportunity to allow small businesses to be represented by whom they wished and withdraw the provisions of the proposed Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005. At the moment, if enacted, that legislation would proscribe the rights of small businesses to have employee organisations represent them. If you want to talk about the rights of small businesses, here was an opportunity today for the government. In the gallery we had many small business people-people who are on occasion in a great deal of debt, purchasing their own rig and placing themselves in a position where they must receive an income just to keep up with the payments of the debt for that rig. They came here today to ask the government to reconsider the way in which it seeks to limit their rights-not unions' rights; the rights of small business people-to be represented by trade unions if they so wish. Indeed, they have a right to choose anyone else. It is quite extraordinary that the government manages to distinguish organisations like the Australian cricket association or other employee bodies from employee organisations registered under the Workplace Relations Act. This again highlights the fact that it is even willing to hurt small businesses if it can in some way adversely affect trade unions. So we do not really need a lecture from the member for Mitchell or any other member on the other side in relation to the concerns that small businesses have. I return to this bill and say: we would hope that small businesses are not affected. We would hate to see the case whereby a company is so commercially affected or in some way injured that it cannot continue to employ as many employees in its work force. But of course we need to have some balance in the argument. It is instructive that the ACCI, the AiG and other peak employer bodies quite rightly represented their views, the views of their members-that is, the many employers in this country-and submitted their position to the commission, the statutory authority, the independent umpire that has been around for over a century. Indeed, the ACTU on behalf of registered organisations of employees did likewise. As a result of that, the independent umpire rejected parts and accepted parts of submissions made by all parties and came up with what would seem to be a reasoned position. It was not an extreme position, as it been purported to be-that is currently being put forward by the government in relation to industrial relations generally-but a position that balanced the rights, concerns and entitlements of employees and the obligations of employers in that regard. It was also a commercially sound decision, to ensure that there was not too great an impost upon small businesses. Further to that-and I certainly have not heard this mentioned today in the debatewhen the employers, along with the Commonwealth and other bodies, made subsequent submissions before the full bench, the full bench amended its decision of 26 March 2004 on 8 June in that same year. It said that recognition of the years that would have to be calculated to determine a redundancy payment would not commence until this year. In other words, there would be no contingent liability held by any small business on the basis of the decision and the amendments that were made by the commission in June last year. So, again, that was a very sound, reasoned and careful decision. I ask the members opposite to consider reading at least parts of the 103-page decision, because I think it allows members opposite-who seem to have an extraordinary ignorance about industrial matters, in some respects anyway-to realise how much effort goes into not only the submissions by the parties on behalf of employees and employers in this country but the efforts by the commissioners to make a decision that is fair and reasonable to all parties. We have to juxtapose that behaviour-of process, of listening to arguments, of finding a decent and reasonable determination-with the extremes of this government in relation to its attacks on working people. We have seen its willingness to deny small businesses the right to be represented in cerhas tain matters by trade unions but by no other. The government mantra ‘right to choose', if genuine, would allow anybody to be an agent for a particular party if that party wished them to be so. But of course the blind hatred the government has towards unions unfortunately blurs propriety. It blurs the right and wrong in this matter. Equally, there is a failsponsibility ure of the government to see that there has to be some balance between protecting small businesses on the one hand and protecting small business employees on the other in relation to a prospective redundancy. It is getting that balance right but is instead riding the Industrial Relations Commission and its decision. If you look at the evidence and the submissions made by the parties, you will find that the decision really comes down the middle of the two respective submissions. I go to the statement that has been made by the full bench. The statement does provide for an increase. In the broader sense, beyond the application for small businesses, it provides for greater increases in redundancy payments for four years up to 10 years. It does not change at all the current entitlements for less than one year up to four years. Remember that that relates to more than 50 per cent of the work force these days, so clearly it is a very important part the decision. I do not necessarily agree with it, but the commission felt that an increase would be an impost and chose not to support that. Whilst the commission accepts that small businesses should indeed pay a redundancy if they are able to, it suggests that it should be a maximum of only eight weeks. So there is still consideration of the position of the small business. I will not compare the government's position with the opposition's position and I will not compare the government with previous Labor governments; I will compare this government with previous conservative governments. I have to say that by any comparison, particularly in this area, this government is very antiworker. You would not see Menzies, Fraser, Harold Holt or other conservative governments legislate on every occasion possible to prevail over a decision made by a statutory authority that is charged with a reto hear submissions, undertake a due process and proper consideration of matters and determine a particular outcome. You would not see such injudicious intrusion by those governments into these matters. But not you do see it, constantly, with this governoverment. It is a major problem. I know members opposite are concerned. Every time. I raise my own fears that this government has it in for working peopleMr Hunt interjecting

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: I understand the member for Flinders wants to open his mouth. Maybe he should enter the debate, rather than challenge me from the table. The member for Flinders knows, and his predecessor certainly knew, how to stick it to workers. Certainly his predecessor knew all about balaclavas and attack dogs; I can assure you of that. The current member for Flinders at least seems to be a more temperate soul in relation to these matters, but I may be wrong, given that he wants to interof ject while I am trying to contribute to the debate properly. It is very unusual for a government to continually legislate to prevail over decisions made by the Industrial Relations Commission. So I hope the government reconsiders its position. The government is in a very powerful position; I understand that. The government is in a very powerful position in both houses, and I believe that when you have so much power you should use it wisely. You have a responsibility to use it wisely. The amendment moved by the member for Perth, the shadow minister responsible for this area, really says: why not reconsider the decision made by the commission to determine the matter, because it is a balanced decision? The amendment moved by the member for Perth asks that the House note: (1) ... that the nation's independent umpire in industrial relations matters, the Australian trial Relations Commission (AIRC), has examined and heard submissions concerning the impact of redundancy payments on small business; (2) ... that the AIRC has found that the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small business across the board does not have the capacity to payand, importantly, that the House recognise(3) ... the circumstances of those individual small business which are incapable of making redundancy payments. That is an even-tempered, well-balanced proposition that the government would accept if it were not so extreme in its outlook with relation to working people. That is the difficulty that this side of the House has with this matter. We understand that there will be differences of opinion; however, the government should consider whether it is motivated by the wrong reasons-motivated not to create good public policy but to hurt groups that do not agree with the government of the day. We see that now with the government's attacks on students and registered employee organisations. A wise government, in light of its power, would reconsider its approach and try to reflect some balance. To date there has been a grave failure of the government to do that. I think the government is making a mistake in selling Telstra, and it is making a mistake in not allowing student organisations to run at campus level in the manner in which they have been. I think the government is making a mistake in preventing small businesses from being represented by unions if they so wish. The government is denying them that right by bringing into the House the Trade Practices Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2005, which effectively removes the choice. It is the opposite of what the government preaches about the rights of principals and their agents-it removes the choice. I would like to finish my contribution to Industhis debate by saying that the government has an opportunity to find the right balance between small businesses and their employees and to ensure that the rights and considerations of each other's position is extended to both. Unfortunately it would seem that, unless there is a change of heart by the government, the workers of this country will get it in the neck again.

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Bowman) (8.15 pm)There is no doubt that the small businessesall one million of them-are performing well in this country. They are the very engine room of continued growth, and this side of the House will never forget that. They are the backbone of the strong economy that we in this country enjoy. Without doubt, many small businesses are very profitable but we must never confuse that profitability with the ability to afford large redundancy payments. You only have to work in small business to know just how hard that can be. That is precisely why it is completely outmoded to come into this House to talk about preventing retrenchments in business-be they small or micro-by applying severance pay to those who create jobs in this country. Placing an obligation on small business to make those redundancy payments will simply lead to an additional cost impost on the very wrong group if you want a strong economy and more job opportunities. It would be unaffordable for many small businesses, and that is the case that I will make tonight. Clearly employees of small business will not gain anything from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission decision that we are debating today if they have no job to go to as a result of that decision. The member for Gorton gave a very considered 15 minutes about the removal of choice and about both parties having rights. He also provided something that I hear very rarely: a robust defence of the AIRC, which underlines this country's flawed process of averaging out the submissions from two completely divergent parties and making decisions based on that. We just flail around in a miasma of ambit claims, with the member for Gorton satisfied that a decision between the two means that everyone is being looked after. We have to be far more considered, and we must ask ourselves two key questions. The first is from a small business perspective. Have you ever run a small business of three, four or five people, where your employees are effectively members of your commercial family, and been faced with making that horrible decision? The decision of redundancy is not necessarily affordable. Are the right parties taking responsibility for a decision to restructure or to make somebody redundant? The second question is from the point of view of the worker. No doubt there is hardship when one loses employment. Who should pay for that restructure or that move? To make the case that the small business should be penalised for doing what it does best is about placing the punishment on the very group that can least afford it. The opposition has to make a case that someone else should pay. (Quorum formed) It is the height of effrontery for the member for Gorton to simply hold up a piece of paper from the AIRC and claim that, because they said that redundancy payments were affordable for small business, they are. Anyone who has run a small business would know that that is far from the truth. The second case that has not been made by the opposition, of course, is: if there is going hardship that needs to be met for those who lose their jobs, why is it that small business needs to pay? If welfare for those who lose a job is to be considered in this country then I say that that case has not been made by the opposition. The one lesson that we have learnt from having those on the other side of the House in government is that you can certainly and quite easily regulate to increase costs, but you cannot regulate to save jobs, because only real jobs deliver job security. You need the conditions whereby small business feels confident to create those jobs. We on this side of the House think it is imperative that small business, as a sector, has every opportunity to be supported to put on and employ as many people as possible, and this legislation is a great example of doing just that. It will serve Australia's small businesses well and it will save them the decision and the cost burden being imposed by the AIRC. Preceding me, what we had from the member for Gorton was 15 minutes of considered reason whereupon he hit the wall and basically collapsed into some antiworker ramble and antigovernment diatribe. For 15 minutes we had some belief that by averaging out the parties at the AIRC we could make great employment and workplace policy in this country. That is patently not the case. If we are trying to seek an optimum balance then we have to find a balance of interests. That is not necessarily an average between the two claims of two parties at the AIRC. There are obviously the equally meritorious considerations of looking after the welfare of workers and making decisions that are best for business. But tonight we are considering those who employ fewer than 15 people. It is not that hard as a microbusiness to find yourself employing 15 people. It is completely time-wasting to be considering to be one side at the expense of another. That completely hostile, 1890s type approach to industrial relations, as we have heard from a couple of speakers on the other side, where they simply raise examples of vexatious employers, or they give ludicrous examples of being summarily dismissed over the phone for one's family requirements or looking after children, is completely unrealistic. Redundancy is never taken lightly by reasonable employers, and we need to be looking after the welfare of those who are made redundant. The case that has not been made tonight is that weeks and weeks of pay should be the responsibility of small business when they are employing fewer than 15 people. That is a case that has not been made, and to simply assume it should be because the AIRC said it is so is to misunderstand what it is like to be in small business. The AIRC effectively tried to remove that exemption for businesses of fewer than 15 people. That redundancy scale that was set up in 1984 that applies to larger businesses has been in place since then and ranges between four and eight weeks. It is interesting to remember that it was not so long ago that the ACTU came to the AIRC with another series of ambit claims. It does serve this liament well to remember what they were: an attempt to double the existing award redundancy payment obligations on employers from eight weeks to-wait for it!-20 weeks; to extend redundancy pay to casual employees; to include penalty rates and overtime payments in redundancy; and to add an additional allowance for employment and financial advice. That was the ambit claim coming from the other side that, in some way over time, led to this decision made early year. This Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004 will do important things. It will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to ensure that the allowability of redundancy pay is limited to those who employ more than 15 people. It will provide that any variations made to the award since March of last year, that are effectively imposing redundancy pay obligations on employers with fewer than 15 employees, will have no effect. It prevents the commission from making redundancy pay orders under section 170FA against an employer who has fewer than 15 workers, and it overrides any territory laws that might impose similar redundancy pay obligations. Of course the evidence from leading economists supports the case I am making tonight. Businesses will feel reluctant to restructure if they are being rendered less efficient and if they are being rendered less capable to adjust to or to reflect changes in the workplace and markets. They will be more prone to closure, less resilient to future crises and, in the end, offer less security to all the other employees in the business. They will be less able to renew, less able to pursue new opportunities in a high-risk environment and obviously less able to grow. Single or partial redundancies, if they are made impossible to do or extremely expensive for small busiparness, eventually simply threaten the entire business. There is an increased capacity to make viable restructuring that saves all other employees. We should also look at the other side of the story; economic and employment conditions are very different to how they were 10 years ago. There are a large range of services that actually make redundancies-while I would never ever want to go through the experience of redundancy-far less harrowing last than they were just 10 years ago. We have a near-universal award redundancy scheme in place for employers with more than 15 people; that has been in place for 20 years, but extending it down to the smallest-the microbusinesses, I call them-will do nothing to improve workplace relations. It will not do anything to improve competitiveness. It will not do anything to help efficiency, productivity or, in the end, the jobs, the products and the production that they are responsible for. It will not do anything to help the opportunities for future growth. Expanding these existing standards down to the smallest businesses simply fails them, because the redundancy payments increase currently for length of service and one's salary, but for the smallest of businesses these payments can sometimes be crippling. I completely reject the assessment of the AIRC that there is the capacity to pay in all microbusiness. The other side of the House is ignoring the fundamental point that employees are gaining just as much as their bosses in a strong contemporary labour market. The Australian redundancy standards, currently funded by employers, compare extremely well internationally, and in many cases are even higher. Career expectations are changing. Individuals today have realistic and wellunderstood expectations about training, working, retraining and changing places of occupation. How companies now train, retrain and retain their staff means that workers will seek re-employment based upon their experience, their training and their retraining, so it is a far more fluid and flexible work market than ever before. There is already an increasing investment by employers and governments in education and training, and there is a trend towards more transportable skills. Both from an active and a passive labour point of view, the market assistance that is available in the community to assist in the process through redundancy and back into employment is witnessed by some of the shortest periods of unemployment between jobs that we have seen in a generation. My case tonight concerns extending these laws to the smallest of business. Many of these employers are taking home extraordinarily low salaries. Often their businesses are struggling. At a time when additional regulation is expected, this can only cause more trouble and more uncertainty within a small business. The alternative from the other side is this. If the small business is not to pay redundancy payments, precisely who should be paying them? We have not yet had any coherent argument that government should be paying them. That would be the case that would have to be made if, as the member for Gorton said, we could find some middle ground. Effectively there has been no regard to the economic benefits that we have seen in this country that make redundancy a very different proposition from what it was a decade ago. Of course, businesses have a commercial and a legal obligation to run and to act in the best interests of their employees and either the business itself or its owners. In some unavoidable cases, that does lead to redundancy. But why should we penalise the smallest of businesses for what is effectively commercial common sense, if not commercial law? In conclusion, let me say this. Losing your job can be an absolute kick in the guts. There is no doubt that that is the case for those who face termination of employment. The case that needs to be made tonight concerns whether the burden of redundancy payments should be placed upon small businesses themselves. Redundancy is never completely the fault of one party or the other. There are multiple parties that suffer from redundancy and that are likely to be affected by a decision to restructure, to make a company more effective and efficient or to respond to the demands of the marketplace. That burden should not be rested with the smallest of small business in this community. It rests with individuals; it rests with society more generally, through government, taxation, welfare support, retraining and the labour market opportunities that this government is providing.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Once again I find myself following the honourable member for Bowman, and doing so after he has done an admirable job of trying to defend the indefensible. The honourable member for Bowman put together a mishmash of arguments to defend the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004, which takes away not the rights of workers but the rights of ordinary people to be sustained in their moment of greatest need. This is an example of this government's extreme industrial relations agenda that we see time and time again in this House. It is also an example of this government's confused and schizophrenic approach to small business. This government thinks that the only way it can help small business is to pit the owners of small businesses against their employees. It thinks that there is always a zero sum game-that the only way the proprietors of small business can benefit is to take something away from the employees of small business. We on this side of the House have a very different approach. We say that small business can be helped and that the employees of small business can be helped at the same time. Our entire small business policy supports that argument. This government finds itself in the situation where it has breached its promises to small business. It has not delivered at all small business. It is strong on rhetoric but small on delivery. It can only take away from the employees of small business to benefit the owners of small business. The honourable member for Bowman talked about a miasma of ambit claims. He talked about small business being less able to renew. Small businesses will still be able to renew if the Labor Party's amendments are adopted, but they will be able to renew in such a way that the innocent victims of downturns in the economy and, sometimes, poor management decisions do not have their livelihoods taken away in such a way that they are unable to put food on the table. That is what this government is doing. This bill overturns the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to ensure and entrench the redundancy rights of employees of small businesses. The bill appears to ignore a supplementary decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which essentially agreed with the submissions of the Commonwealth and the employers, particularly the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and the Australian Industry Group. The commission noted that small businesses may lack the financial reserves to meet redundancy payments arising out of the March decision. Accordingly, the commission varied its March decision and decided that, for the purposes of calculating redundancy payments, small business employers need take into account only employment service rendered after 8 June 2004. This means that the contingent liability of small business is zero until June 2005, irrespective of the employee's years of service. The commission's recognition of the potential of some small businesses to have difficulty in paying is sensible, as is the commission's solution. I was drawn to the commissioners' decision, for and in particular the following excerpt from it: While some small businesses lack financial resilience and have less ability to bear the costs of severance pay than larger businesses, the available evidence does not support the general proposition that small business does not have the capacity to pay severance pay. In the period 1997-98, the most recent period for which data are available, some 70 per cent of small businesses which reduced the number of persons they employed made a profit. For those businesses which are unable to meet their redundancy pay obligations the incapacity to pay provision, as amended by this decision, provides an avenue for relief. Neither the honourable member for Bowman nor any other government member, to my knowledge, has referred to that particular finding of the commission. Those opposite say, ‘No small business will be able to pay this. We are lifting the burden off small business.' They say the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has not considered this matter properly. They do not recognise the fact that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has done considerable research. It did not toss a coin or say, ‘The employers say this; the unions say this. We'll go fiftyfifty.' It was a considered decision which has been ignored by the honourable member for Bowman, by other members opposite andsurprise, surprise-by this government in its extreme approach.
