The commission's approach is a sensible one. It approaches the capacity or incapacity of a small business to pay on a case-by-case basis. It is an approach that the opposition endorses. The government has endorsed another approach-an extremist approach. This is the logic of the government's argument. The government says that, if you work for a company with 16 employees, you should get redundancy pay. However, if you are unfortunate enough to work for a company with 14 employees, you miss out. Let us go back to first principles. The honourable member for Bowman said one thing that I agree with: if you lose your job, it can be a kick in the guts. What is redundancy pay for? It is to help people who lose their jobs through no fault of their own. It has been generally accepted on both sides of politics, indeed throughout the Western world, that redundancy pay is legitimate. But rather than adopting a case-by-case approach, rather than adopting the principle of capacity to pay, the government has taken the approach of simply abolishing the rights of people who work for companies with 15 or fewer employees to redundancy pay. The government has failed over its nine years in office to deal with the matter of employee entitlements generally. I have a private member's bill before the House on this matter. The government, after the scandal of national textiles and Ansett, introduced the General Employment Entitlements and Redundancy Scheme, GEERS. I would like to address the intersection of this bill and the GEERS. The scheme meets certain employee entitlements in the event that an employer is unable to pay due to insolvency. However, the entitlement to payment under the scheme is generated by evidence of (a) the entitlement and its accrual and (b) a legal obligation to meet the entitlement. This bill potentially removes the right to access the GEERS for employees of certain small businesses. By removing the right to redundancy pay, this bill removes the entitlement to redundancy pay and therefore potentially removes the capacity of some employees to access the GEERS. So this government says it is all about capacity to pay but, with this bill, it removes the rights of employees to access a scheme that is not paid for by small businessMr Ciobo interjecting

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: Order! The member for Moncrieff will have the opportunity to put his views.

Speaker: Mr BOWEN
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: The honourable member for Moncrieff will have his opportunity. He caterwauls from the back in his normal rightwing manner. My friend the honourable member for Moncrieff rushes into this House for any opportunity to support the government's extreme right-wing industrial relations agenda, as is his perfect right. He caterwauls from the back. I challenge the honourable member for Moncrieff to deal with the intersection of the GEERS and this bill. I challenge him to explain to this House why the GEERS will not be affected by this bill. I challenge him to explain this government's approach to employee entitlements generally. I challenge him to defend the government's record on employee entitlements, the national textiles disaster, the Ansett imbroglio et cetera. This government's rhetoric on small business is strong; its record is poor. Is this ority for small business? As I have said before in the House, I spend as much time as I can talking to small businesses in my electorate. Not one of them has raised the need for exemption from redundancy payments. As I have said before, small business regularly raises with me the need to be freed up from unnecessary paperwork. This is something that the government has made much worse. The government promised to cut small business paperwork by 50 per cent. Instead, it has increased small business paperwork substantially. We have seen the GST and superannuation choice-two massive burdens on small business and their paperwork compliance regime. Some small businesses have also had a significant increase in their paperwork and compliance costs as a result of financial services reform. One small business in the financial services field that I know of in my electorate has gone out of business because of these reforms. If the government's reality matched its rhetoric, we would see much more action on these fronts and less ideologically driven attacks on the employees of small businesses, which create two or even three classes of citizens. There will be three classes of small business employees in this country if this bill is passed. There is the class where, if you work for a company with fewer than 15 employees, you have the right to be dismissed and you have no right to retrenchment. If you work for a company with between 15 and 100 employees, you could still be dismissed but you will have some rights to retrenchment pay. If you are lucky enough to work for a company with more than 100 employees then you are right on both fronts. This government is so ideologically confused that it has created three classes of citizens-first-, a prisecondand third-class citizens-when it comes to employees of small business. As I said at the outset, this government's approach is that there is only one way to help small business-that is, to take something away from the employees of small business. Why doesn't this government do something about the paperwork compliance burden for small business? Why doesn't it do something to take the burden that it has created in relation to superannuation choice? The government has the chance to do this right now. Why doesn't it do something to give certain small business owners the capacity to have the bargaining agent of their choice, whether it be the Cricketers Association or, heaven forbid, a registered trade union? Why doesn't it give the small businesses of this nation that right, that choice? We hear all about choice from this government-superannuation choice, for example-but it is taking away the right to a choice for certain small businesses to have trade unions representing them in their negotiations. This government is ideologically confused but ideologically hell-bent on taking away the rights of employees of small business. This is an illogical, unfair and ideologically driven system that lets down Australian workers, lets down small businesses and lets down the economy generally. I call on the House to support Labor's amendment and I call on the House to take a sensible, wellmeasured, reasoned approach and reject this government's extreme ideological agenda.

Speaker: Mr CIOBO
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: I am pleased to rise to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004. This bill amends the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to maintain the exemption that exists for small business from redundancy pay by overturning the recent decision of the Australian dustrial Relations Commission imposing redundancy pay obligations on small businesses. I am pleased, as a representative for the seat of Moncrieff, which on a per capita basis is the small business capital of Austrafused lia, to associate myself with the very good benefits that will flow and will continue to flow to small business as a consequence of the enactment of this bill. It is interesting for me to follow the memfor ber for Prospect and the remarks that the bor Party have made in this debate. It has been interesting to hear the Australian Labor Party come into this chamber and argue in some confused way that they in fact are the friends of small business. They argue that they are the friends of small business by enforcing very harsh obligations, in many instances, on the small business sector. Nothing could be further from the truth. I heard the member for Prospect remark that it is up to the Howard federal government to justify the various propositions that we are putting forward in reforms to industrial relations and the need that we see to maintain the exemption for small business from redundancy pay. I also heard the member for Prospect claim that it is an ideologically confused Liberal Party and an ideologically confused National Party that are sending mixed signals to the Australian work force and Australian small business owners about what we see as the best way forward for this sector. It is interesting that the member for Prospect and the Australian Labor Party would argue that in this particular bill it is the Howard government that is ideologically confused. It is interesting because, when the test case was put before the AIRC in this particular instance, the state Labor governments did not support having redundancy pay imposed on small business. State Labor governments In- adopted a contrary point of view to that which the member for Prospect and other Labor members have put forward in this debate this evening. Let there be no doubt that there is only one political party that is conwhen it comes to what is necessary to continue the growth of employment and small businesses in Australia, ensure the profitability of small businesses and, most importantly, provide the necessary conditions a flexible work force for small businesses La- so that they can provide one of their most overriding concerns-that is, employment opportunities for Australians. After all, it is almost a cliche now when we say that the small business sector is the engine room of the Australian economy. I am very pleased to speak on behalf of small businesses in my electorate of Moncrieff and in Gold Coast City, and to argue for a continued exemption for those small businesses from the burden of redundancy pay. I recognise that an exemption for small businesses from redundancy pay may have possible ramifications for an employee. But I am reminded that, if a small business becomes insolvent, then there is nothing for the employee at all. Far be it from us to say, ‘We'll impose a redundancy pay obligation on you'-which may be a contributing factor to the eventual insolvency of a business. There will be nothing for the employee then. The crocodile tears from the Australian Labor Party about how harshly this government treats employees could not be further from the truth. This government is committed to ensuring the right economic conditions through strong economic management, the right conditions to employ a productive work force and, most importantly, that the impossible shackles that Labor Party policy would impose on future employment are not imposed, so that small businesses will actively go about employing Australians, giving them a chance and providing them with a pay packet which, fundamentally, is a key concern. I have always rallied behind local businesses on the Gold Coast and I am not about to stop. My wife is involved in small business and I come from a small business family. I continue to stand up in this chamber and speak on behalf of small businesses. Many small businesses simply cannot afford large redundancy payouts. There are now some 1.6 million small businesses operating in Australia and, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, their annual profit is approximately $32,000 per business. This recent decision by the Australian dustrial Relations Commission will impose unreasonable financial burdens on small business. For example, a typical retail small business with, say, seven employees, each with six years continuous employment, would face a contingent liability for redundancy pay of nearly $30,000. There are reasonable grounds to assume that the bill will have potential influence over the redundancy entitlements of some one million small business employees, on the assumption that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's redundancy decision potentially broadened access to the redundancy pay entitlement. I recognise that, for those one million potential small business employees, it could be construed as a negative. But the point that I will stress, and the more important point, is that if these kinds of exemptions are not provided to small businesses-small businesses with an average profit of some $32,000 per annum-people will not be employed to begin with. As I said earlier, if a business becomes insolvent, then people would not have the opportunity to receive many of their entitlements, let alone their redundancy pay entitlements. The coalition is absolutely committed to opposing unnecessary restraints on small businesses, which make it harder for them to employ people. If this bill is not passed, the vast majority of small businesses that are covered by federal awards will eventually, it is fair to say, be subjected to providing redundancy payments for their employees in accordance with the AIRC decision. It is likely that this decision will also flow through to the state jurisdictions. This bill will not affect any redundancy pay provisions that were in awards prior to the AIRC decision. The AIRC has created a new entiIntlement which did not previously exist. It is absolutely vital that opportunities for continued growth and job creation for those 1.1 million non-agricultural small businesses in Australia continue to be maximised. It is even more essential for the 3.3 million people that are employed by these businesses. This bill in no way prevents small businesses reaching agreements with their employees to include redundancy provisions in their terms of employment. It is about preventing the imposition of a one-size-fits-all regulation which, quite frankly, many small businesses will not be able to afford. The government have been consistent and strong and I will be consistent and strong in my support for small business. We recognise that the biggest threat to jobs growth in Australia is the unnecessary impediments which make it harder for small business to employ people. This decision is fundamentally flawed because the decision the AIRC took overturned the exemption from severance pay for businesses with fewer than 15 employees. This exemption was established by the AIRC's predecessor back in 1984, a decision which was then turned on its head. The Queensland Industrial Relations Commission recently decided that the small business exemption under the Queensland system should remain. It found that the imposition of redundancy pay obligations had ‘the very real potential result in the insolvency of a number of small businesses.' In 1994 the New South Wales Industrial Commission also reaffirmed the need for small business exemption. It is significant to note, as I stressed earlier, that none of the four state governments that took part in this AIRC test case supported the removal of the exemption-the Queensland and WA state Labor governments opposed the removal, while the New South Wales and Victorian Labor governments neither supported nor opposed it. Despite what the member for Prospect said earlier, the fact remains that redundancy pay provisions can be incorporated into awards if that is the decision of both parties to the award. The result is that we provide a framework which provides flexibility to small business owners and employers as well as ensuring that small business employees are in a position to also argue the merits of their case. The fundamental fact is that redundancy pay principally comes into effect at a time when a small business is having problems. There are not many small businesses that will make their staff redundant if everything is going very strongly. Typically, the reason for redundancy is the fact that a small business is encountering financial difficulties or experiencing transitions gard to the goods or services that they provide. So there is no point in wondering what the impact would be on small businesses if at a time of financial difficulty we were to say, ‘You must meet the liability of redundancy payment to those employees who are taking redundancy.' Can you imagine the problems that would cause? This was a flawed decision. This bill is crucial to ensuring the long-term sustainability of a flexible workplace relations system that is to the benefit of employees and employers. Most fundamentally, this bill continues to reflect the Howard government's to and my own commitment to supporting small business because it is fundamentally central to the long-term sustainability of employment and economic prosperity that all Australians enjoy. In conclusion, I highlight that this is a positive bill, good for small businesses on the Gold Coast and good for continuing employment in Australia.

Speaker: Mr BARRESI
Title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS
text: In the brief time that I have to make a contribution in this debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Small Business Employment Protection) Bill 2004, I am more than pleased to add my voice to the government's argument its need. (Quorum formed) Like many of my colleagues on this side of the House I am more than pleased to add my voice to this bill, which protects small businesses. From the contributions of all members on this side it is evident that there is only one voice speaking out on behalf of small business, and that voice is on this side of the House and not on the other. We have the interests and the livelihoods of those who take the brave and often risky gamble of entering into a business venture of their own to heart. I know that all of us on this side certainly have made it a core concern of ours throughout this term of government, and in fact throughout the entire Howard governwith re- ment stewardship of this country. I too know how it feels to put all your hard earned savings on the line and to have your family wondering if it was the right move to give up your salaried position. It is only through small businesses that we truly begin the process of employment growth that so many others in the community will eventually benefit from. I welcome the opportunity to stand up and assist small business in this place. I am also proud of coalition remains the only political voice in Australia that will vehemently oppose unnecessary restraints on small businesses, particularly when they make it harder for them to employ people. Small businesses can well do without excessive shackles being placed upon them. By voting against this bill, that is exactly what the opposition are doing! They are placing shackles upon them which have been imposed by a recent decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Debate interrupted. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 9.00 pm, I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Johann Kwasnycia Reid Electorate: Ukrainian Community

Speaker: Mr LAURIE FERGUSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We have heard much talk of the 60 years since the end of the Second World War. Tonight I want to talk about a person whose contribution to this country in the postwar period so epitomises the contribution to this country and to my own electorate of the Ukrainian community. My electorate has one of Australia's greatest concentrations of Ukrainians. It has many Ukrainian community institutions, such as the Karpaty Credit Union, the Ukrainian club, the Ukrainian Catholic Church, the monastery, the women's association hall et cetera. Johann Kwasnycia lived within 10 houses of the house I grew up in. His life epitomises the contribution of a lot of the Ukrainians in my area, families such as the Iwachiws, Baranowskis and Shymkos. In giving this speech, I will paraphrase extensively the obituary speech given by his son following Johann's recent death. It is very interesting to read the contribution that Johann made to the fact that the this country. Johann left his homeland to escape the invading Russian Army when he was only 15. When the war ended in 1945, exactly 60 years ago, Johann was working in Germany, where most had to struggle to survive under extreme food shortages. Johann continued applying to return to his homeland but was forced to stay and work in Germany. Johann and his family migrated to Australia and arrived on 11 November 1949, after six weeks of sailing in cramped ship accommodation. During the trip he worked on the boat, painting to earn a bit of extra food supply. In order to pay the fare to Australia, the family had to sign a contract to work on a farm in Tenterfield for two years. However, on arrival in Australia, they were told the contract was cancelled and they were required to be resettled in corrugated iron shelter housing at Cowra. In 1950 they moved to Kensington, Sydney, where the four lived in the rented one bedroom of a house. Life proved very difficult in Sydney, with Johann frequently walking to the city and back to find work. He eventually landed a job on the faraway Snowy Mountains hydro scheme, where he worked until the late 1950s. He often spoke of the cold and freezing conditions working there and living in Cooma. Later on, Johann was to work on a number of construction projects in Sydney, including the Eastern Suburbs railway tunnels, the Malabar treatment works and the Warragamba Dam, before moving on to the Opera House, where one of his final tasks was being suspended high in a harness gluing the large tiles onto the giant sails. Johann's life revolved around the Ukrainian church at Lidcombe, which he attended fervently. He was extensively involved in many of the Ukrainian community's activities. He enjoyed the company of his countrymen in a community house at Merrylands until its sale, playing cards and recalling past. He made many donations to various Ukrainian and local charities and sent parcels and money home. Johann was a devoted family man and became a true grandfather; in Johann's obituary, his son spoke about Johann's many family outings. Johann tinkered endlessly under his house in his spare time. He built his own cross-cut saw, plane saw, ripper, grinder and anything else he could put together from bits he collected. He clearly passed his collection habits on to his son. In 1994 at the age of 70, following the of the USSR, he was finally able to go back to his home in the Ukraine to be reunited with his family, who he had not seen for 55 years. He told of the difficult conditions they still endured. Johann Kwasnycia's life typifies the contribution of the Ukrainians in my electorate and more particularly in the suburb I come from, along with those families I mentioned earlier. In this country we have 33,000 people who say they are of Ukrainian extraction and, of those, 13,000 were actually physically born there. This community has endeavoured very strongly to maintain its Ukrainian traditions. It is increasingly difficult in second and third generations to imbue people with interest in their background and their history. To give a typical example of their continued activity, I recently attended the celebrations of the Cossack group which has toured Australia. They are very proud to say that they have been to Yulara, amongst many other places, showcasing their culture, skills and music. As I said, Johann's life typifies the Ukrainian contribution made in my area, which essentially derived from a migrant hostel on Merrylands Road that had previously been an American hostel during the Second World War. As we celebrate 60 years the since the end of the Second World War, we should also put on record the contribution of those early migration waves after the Second World War, as those migrants contributed so much to the building of this country and its diversification. Johann was typical of that contribution. (Time expired) Paterson Electorate

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Paterson) (9.05 pm)From time to time members in this House are tempted, for a variety of reasons, to change their direction in life. Recently I was asked by a very successful local company to join fall their progressive and dynamic team. The company is one the fastest growing businesses in the Hunter. I had the pleasure of working with them briefly prior to returning to politics in 2001. Since then I have witnessed their contribution to the development of a stronger Hunter. I am flattered that they value my abilities to make a substantial contribution to their effort and to share in their successes. I have an excellent rapport with the owners. Their direction and ideals are much in line with mine: building better opportunities for our region, creating wealth and jobs, and doing so with the utmost integrity. However, I have found that politics offers rich rewards that money cannot match. I will give two recent examples. The first was when I recently assisted a constituent, Sue Brown, to be reunited with her injured daughter Louise Barry, in London, following the train and bus bombings. The second was the smiles on the faces of the students at Dungog High School when, after their sheep were slaughtered by disturbed youths, I was able to organise replacement sheep so that their studies could continue. That is what makes the work of a politician so enjoyable and worthwhile. It is the reward you get from helping your constituents-a mother to be reunited with her daughter, or students to overcome a traumatic experience. I think back to why I went into politics in the first place. I did so not because I was a long-time member of the Liberal Party or an ideologue shaped by conservative icons. I came into politics because I was an angry person and had just experienced one of the most significant events in my life-the birth of our twin boys. It is an understatement to say that the birth of your children refocuses your priorities in life. In 1991, when my twin sons, Robbie and David, were born, I genuinely feared for their future. I recognised challenges they would face and believed our country was headed in the wrong direction. Rather than complain, I accepted a challenge from a friend and decided to jump in and do something about it. I can clearly remember the evening of 5 July 1995 when I was heading out to a Liberal Party ‘meet the candidate' function for the Paterson preselection. My then four-year-old son asked me, ‘Daddy, why are you going out tonight? Can't you stay home?' I told him that I was going out for him and that in a few years he would understand why. Over the time. I have been in parliament, I have spent a lot of time discussing the issues of time management, reason and direction with my family. Like others in this chamber, my family do understand-sometimes with difficulty-encourage and wholeheartedly support my decision to represent the people of Paterson. Their reason for doing so is simple. They support my being in this parliament to help make this country a better place. In my first speech in this House, I said: ... if I can be remembered for one contribution to this House I would want it to be that I was part of the team that helped turn the ship around; to steer a new course towards the nation's salvation. Today, when I look into the eyes of my children, I know that there is still a lot of work to do to provide them and others like them with the opportunities that I and many in this House enjoyed as young Australians. When asked what drives my passion to be in parliament, I say that it is best summarised as my family and my nation. I forever ask myself what the future holds for the people of Paterson, those I represent and care about. My place is in this parliament representing them. Accordingly, I have advised the company that I cannot accept their kind offer. I am determined to do whatever I can to make this nation a better place and to provide opthe portunity, hope and leadership for our children. Workplace Relations: Boeing

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Last Wednesday I had the opportunity to meet with maintenance engineers from Newcastle who are the subject of industrial action being taken by their employer, Boeing. This is not the first time that this matter has been drawn to the attention of the parliament and I am sure that it will not be the last. In rising to lend my support to the engineers at Williamstown, I acknowledge the hard work of the member for Newcastle in standing up for the rights of these workers, including their right to be represented by the Australian Workers Union. This dispute goes to the heart of concerns that working Australians have about the government's industrial relations agenda. This is more than a dispute between a group of employees and their employer. The engineers at Williamstown have already had a taste of what is to come from the government's industrial relations agenda, as for the last four years they have been on individual contracts. They are not simply taking a stand against the notion of being on contracts. They have tried it, have found that it does not work for them and have decided that they would prefer to be under a collective agreement. Being on individual contracts, they have found that every time the company makes a change in policy or procedure it fundamentally and unilaterally changes their conditions of employment. I am sure that everyone was relieved to hear the Prime Minister's views on the matter last week when, in response to a question from the Leader of the Opposition, he said: ….the existing law means that the company is within its rights in taking the position it is It is fair and proper, under the existing law. Everyone would have been relieved by that answer, as it gives some insight into the future of industrial relations-at least in the way John Howard sees it. So much for assurances that employees will have a choice. The minister keeps reminding the House that workers will be able to elect to be on an AWA or, if they wish, they may negotiate collectively and, indeed, through a union. However, that is not the case for these employees at Boeing. The Prime Minister continues to refuse to guarantee that workers will not be worse off. He maintains that his record is his guarantee. I have to say that people are starting to treat his record in this regard very sceptically. We have an example right here and now at Newcastle. Boeing has been in Australia for a while and knows the industrial relations system. It has no qualms in having its employees at Bankstown under a collective agreement with the AWU as the principal respondent, but it is another story at its Williamstown site. We understand that the company is quite adept in reading between the lines, particularly when it comes to currying favour with the Howard government. In fairness, what better way to maintain the inside track when eyeing off Australian Defence Force contracts than to embrace the government's Holy Grail: the Prime Minister's personal ambition for the past 30 years to have workers forced onto individual contracts. It is difficult to look at this dispute in any other way. Boeing workers at Bankstown, as I said earlier, are happily ensconced on a certified collective agreement, while the workers at Williamstown are locked out because of the company's insistence that they be on Australian workplace agreements. Either the company is suffering industrial schizophrenia or it is displaying taking. gross corporate hypocrisy at levels not seen before in this country. Some might even go so far as to suggest that Boeing is simply sucking up to the government to prove its loyalty and improve its standing. There has always been a resolution available for this dispute. The employees at Williamstown agreed previously to have all of their claims heard and determined on their merits by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, the country's peak industrial umpire. These are not militant people. The majority are former RAAF personnel who have served their time protecting this country. The last thing they want is to be involved in an industrial dispute. They are skilled engineers who look after our fleet of FA18 fighters and all they want is a fair go. Interestingly, Boeing has opposed the intervention of the industrial umpire and has shown its preparedness to starve its employeesthese former servicemen-and their families into submission. I wonder what this company really believes when it thinks of its employees, their families and the community. Does this famous American icon see its workers only as units of production? (Time expired) Gaza Strip: Withdrawal of Jewish Settlers

Speaker: Mr TURNBULL
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Yesterday the Israeli defence forces began supervising the final withdrawal of Jewish settlements from the Gaza Strip. Many of these settlements have been home to Jews for more than 30 years. It came as no surprise that there is enormous sadness about this withdrawal on the part of the Israeli people, nor can it come as a surprise that many Israelis have opposed the withdrawal-vigorously, but so far without violence. Long may that be so. Traditionally, victors do not surrender land to those they have defeated. Israel occupied the Gaza Strip from Egypt after its successful defence against attack from its neighbours in 1967. Now it is withdrawing from those last parts of the Gaza Strip upon which it built settlements. It is not receiving anything in return; this is a unilateral withdrawal. The pragmatic justification made by Ariel Sharon is simply that Israel cannot maintain settlements in areas which are overwhelmingly populated by Arabs. There are about 1.4 million Palestinians in Gaza and just 8,500 Jews. The cost of defending the settlements is $US560 million each year. It is better to consolidate in those areas where the Jews are a majority. This is an about-face for Sharon, often known as the father of the settlement movement, and a reminder of the wisdom of Moshe Dayan's reproach to those Israelis flushed with victory after 1967 who thought of a greater Israel from Jordan to the sea: ‘You want the dowry,' he said, ‘but you do not want to marry the bride.' But the opponents of the withdrawal say that this is a capitulation to terror. It will be seen as a victory for the violent, a win for Hamas and a confirmation that Israel will continue to retreat in the face of a terror campaign that has been waged against it. They cite Sharon's earlier claims that a withdrawal is not a recipe for peace but a recipe for war. Many observers watching the demonstrations with thousands of Jews flying their orange flags of protest will conclude that it is Sharon and Israel that have most at risk. I beg to differ. If the withdrawal results in no diminution of terrorism, if it results in a Hamas controlled Gaza being the source of further attacks against Israel, then the Israeli defence forces have the capacity to respond decisively. Sharon said yesterday, in a nationwide address, ‘If they choose fire, we will respond with fire, more severe than ever.' But, most importantly, if this unilateral withdrawal is rewarded with violence, Israel's complaint that there is no partner for peace will be confirmed. The world will have seen Israel go through the most agonising and demoralising internal struggle as it withdrew from Gaza. It will have seen how difficult-nearly impossible-it was even for a leader like Sharon to complete that withdrawal. Then, if after all that, the critics of withdrawal are confirmed-if, after all that, withdrawal is a recipe for more violence, not peace-how can the world continue to pressure the Israelis to cede more territory? On the other hand, if all our prayers are fulfilled and the withdrawal does succeed in creating a new level of trust and the end, or perhaps the beginning of the end, of violence, then all the people of Israel and the Palestinian territories will be winners, as we will all be. Prime Minister Sharon is as tough and as shrewd as they come. He knows what he is playing for. One outcome least sought but most likely is that the withdrawal does nothing to diminish the level of terror, but it will certainly make Israel's borders somewhat easier and much cheaper to defend. It will give Israel a powerful moral argument to use to resist further concessions. The other outcome most sought but less likely is that it will be the beginning of peace. Abu Mazen and the Palestinians have the most at risk in this game. It can be the renewal of a peace process or it can be the loss of considerable moral capital in the eyes of the free world. So while the world focuses on Sharon and Israel, it is the player on the other side of the chessboard who has the most challenging moves to make and the most to win or lose. Sharon is putting the ball in Abu Mazen's court-he cannot afford to drop it. Rural and Regional Australia: Dental

Speaker: Mr ANDREN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In the past few days I have delivered a petition to this House from 1,008 petitioners in the central west of New South Wales. The petition: ... draws to the attention of the House the appalling availability of dental services throughout and regional Australia in public dental clinics for those in most need. This is caused primarily by inadequate staffing levels due to low salaries paid to lecturers in universities and the length of time required to train dentists. The petition also asks the House to: ... take the necessary action to train and fund quate numbers of dentists willing to staff public dental clinics ... as well as maintenance and oral education to all citizens deemed eligible. I do not believe there is one member of this House who has not seen distressed lowincome and pensioner constituents seeking assistance for urgent dental treatment. They have problems that, if left unattended, will present far more serious health consequences down the track and a burden on the public health dollar far in excess of timely treatment for their current crises. This petition has been gathered from as far afield as Grenfell, Hill End, Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow by the central west based Rural Dental Action group, with the able assistance of Bathurst Combined Pensioner and Superannuants branch. I pay tribute to Marge Bollinger and Dr Cath Errey, who were instrumental in the establishment of the action group in August last year. Thanks to this group, the wider public and those who cannot get dental care now realise how much was lost when the program introduced by the former government was axed in 1996. This government said then that the scheme had served its purpose and that dental care was a state responsibility. The federal scheme had reduced waiting times for public dental care from two years to six months. In Services the nine years since its axing, a two-year wait is again normal. But the Minister for Health and Ageing has recognised the public outcry with his very minimal Medicare cover announced in last year's budget when $200 per annum rural worth of care was reinstated for the most chronic and complex cases. However, the minister knows how minimal is the care one can obtain for $200. But he at least recognises that the Commonwealth does indeed have power under section 51(xxiiiA) of the Constitution to make laws for dental seradevices, a power specifically granted in a 1946 referendum. Dental care for the needy is a national responsibility as well as a power, and the petition I deliver also seeks a national program to address the urgent need for more graduates and university lecturers with payments that will attract them from private practice dentistry. At the moment, a senior lecturer in dentistry receives about $72,000, hardly the kind of remuneration that would attract a senior experienced dentist from private practice to academia, whatever his or her dedication to the cause. Charles Sturt University has been working on a plan to train dentists under the health sciences program with a transfer to postgraduate training at Sydney University. That is one model that needs urgent exploration. The Australian Dental Association, with whom I met last week, has recently detailed the extent of the crisis. In my own area-the central west of New South Wales, where the Rural Dental Action Group is working so effectively-there are just 17 dentists per 100,000 people, whereas the national average, itself quite insufficient, is 47 per 100,000. The other sad fact is that the age of dentists is ever increasing, with a third of them over the age of 50. The Dental Association has a number of proposals for improving those figures, one of which is the establishment of a Commonwealth dental health program similar to that discontinued in 1996, which would be administered by the states, with a mix of public and private surgeries being utilised. The other part of the association's plan is a scholhe arship scheme for rural students. As well, the association is suggesting a moratorium on fee indebtedness for dental graduates who agree to work in regional, rural and remote areas. These are issues of health care and health education, yet the association has had little joy in trying to meet with the health or education ministers. One office says that it is a health issue and the other says it is an education issue. Well it is both, and I hope both ministers can find the time to sit down with the association and work out a solution to this crisis. I applaud the Rural Dental Action Group for its efforts and its petition, and I urge the government to act upon its requests. Child Support Agency

Speaker: Mr SCHULTZ
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Over the last 12 months I have compiled 4,500 submissions from all round Australia on the body that I refer to as the national shame of Australia-that is, the Child Support Agency. Out of those 4,500 submissions I have, with the able assistance of a researcher, sifted through and compiled those submissions which carry detailed evidence of the way in which the Child Support Agency operates. Let me inform the House of a case relating to one of those submissions, which is the tip of the iceberg with regard to the problems associated with this government agency. A couple's 14-year-old child runs away from home because of a dispute with the father about his possible suspension from his local high school. The couple are frustrated and bewildered after nine months of attempting to get the child to come home and receiving absolutely no assistance at all from the New South Wales Department of Community Services or the New South Wales Police Service, who tell the father that the child has a right to stay where he wants providing the people he stays with are not harming him or is not in trouble with the police. The child is drinking alcohol and the parents are concerned about him getting into unlawful activities. The child tells police and DOCS that he wants to live with his aunt, the father's sister. The parents were advised that it was this 14year-old's choice as to where he wants to live. The parents are further advised to give him his clothes. The parents are also unable to obtain school records relating to the child as he has changed his address without the parents' knowledge. They are advised by the school that they cannot forward any correspondence to the parents because he is no longer living with them. The rights of the parents are further violated by the bizarre actions of the Child Support Agency approving the aunt's application for child support from the parents of this child. The CSA then advise the parents in writing that they have calculated the amount of child support the parents must pay the aunt. We have a situation here whereby a child who is 14 years of age has been assisted to live with his aunt despite the biological parents' opposition and concern for his safety and well-being. In other words, their rights as parents have been abused. They have been forced to pay child support-18 per cent each of the earnings of each of those individual parents. There are a number of questions that need to be asked about this particular Child Support Agency case, as there are a significant number of questions to be asked about the other 899 I have so far processed and which I hope will culminate in about 1,150 to 1,200 cases. The questions are: (1) Under what act or sections of an act of this parliament has the Child Support Agency taken this action to assist in removing a child from his biological parents? (2) Under what section or sections of federal legislation has the Child Support Agency made a decision to force biological parents to pay child support payments to a person who is not a parent of the child? (3) Is the child and/or the person he is living with receiving any payment from Centrelink or any other Commonwealth social security agency and/or department and, if so, under what Commonwealth legislation is this payment being made to this person? I believe this example is a serious abuse of the rights and responsibilities of law-abiding citizens and parents, and it is typical of the abuse of power which appears to be endemic in the Child Support Agency based on the 899 further cases I have to date. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, and I can assure the minister of the Crown on my side of politics responsible for this agency in this parliament that they are going to be hearing a lot more about the illegal activity and the way in which the Child Support Agency has not only contravened a number of federal acts of parliament but-more importantly, I believe, based on constitutional advice I have received-contravened the Constitution of this great nation of ours and that I am going to bring them to account for it. Question agreed to. House adjourned at 9.29 pm NA NA Parliament House: Turf Replacement Costs Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Speaker, in writing, on 29 June 2005 What is the itemised cost of the removal of the dead thatch layer, re-levelling of the surface and laying of the new turf in the general areas of the outer wings of the Senate and House of Representatives side of Parliament House and who will undertake the work.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: INFORMATION
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The turf replacement project has a planned cost of $100,000. The major components of the work are: - thatch removal $20,000; supply and lay turf $73,000; - supply topsoil $1,000; and - other costs $6,000. The work is being undertaken by staff of the Department of Parliamentary Services and the following contractors; Manoeuvre Mow Pty Ltd; and Canturf Pty Ltd. Parliament House: Replacement of Trees Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Speaker, in writing, on 29 June 2005 In respect of the courtyard outside Aussie's in Parliament House, (a) how many trees will be removed, (b) what is the cost of removing and replanting trees and (c) what is the cost of removing the soil and replacing it with a structured soil profile.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: INFORMATION
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (a) Four trees are being removed in the courtyard. (b) and (c) The total cost of the project is $55,000 and includes the following major components: - removal and replacement of pavers and concrete $42,000; - excavation $3,300; - supply structured soils $3,000; - replacement trees $1,000; and - allowance for unforseen costs $5,700. Parliament House: Security Costs Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Speaker, in writing, on 29 June 2005 Since 11 September 2001, what are the itemised costs of security work undertaken for Parliament House including changes to the structure and operation of the physical structure of Parliament House.

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: INFORMATION
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The following security works have been undertaken to the structure of Parliament House since 11 September 2001: 1648-39 Prime Minister's Courtyard Gates Upgrade Cost: $50,000 Works completed: 16 July 2004 Description of works: Replace all locking mechanisms of the gates as they were over 14 years old and were in poor condition, causing maintenance problems. 1669 Parliament Drive Security Barriers Cost: Current budget $11.2m Works completed: Expected to be complete in August 2005 Description of works: Construction of barrier (low wall) around the inside of Parliament Drive and installation of retractable bollards at the slip roads to prevent unauthorised vehicle access while permitting authorised vehicle access. 1672 Ministerial Wing car parks Cost: Current budget $294,000 Works completed: Completed July 2005 Description of works: Installation of boom gates, cameras and other measures to control access to the external car parks. Ministerial Wing Southern Windows Cost: Current budget $134,000 Works completed: Expected to be completed August 2005 Description of works: Installation of blast proof film to the inside surface of south facing windows in the Ministerial Wing. 1681 Brisbane Avenue/Loading Dock Security Upgrade Cost: $640,000 Works completed: 26 May 2005 Description of works: Installation of a truck stop gate and guard post to control vehicle access to the loading dock. (Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 2005) Mr Baird to move: That this House: (1) notes the historic and turbulent background of the state of Bangladesh and its cultural and religious diversity; (2) calls on the government of Bangladesh to adhere to the terms of the 1997 peace agreement which calls for the: (a) demilitarisation of the Chittagong Hill Tracts (CHT); (b) formation of a land commission to settle disputes; (c) rehabilitation of international refugees and internally displaced people; (d) establishment of a separate ministry for the CHT with an indigenous MP as its Minister; and (e) formation of a police force up to the level of sub-inspector drawn from among the indigenous population; and (3) calls on the Bangladeshi government to address the concerned region in a more compassionate and democratic way and also to recognise the autonomy of the Jumma people. Mr Kerr to move: That standing order 271 be added to the standing orders in the following terms: 271 Address for removal of a federal justice An address to the Governor General pursuant to section 72 of the Constitution shall be dealt with in the following manner: (a) A Member may give notice of a motion for an address praying for the removal from office of a named justice of the High Court or of another court created by the Parliament on the ground of proved misbehaviour or incapacity. The motion must make specific allegations in precise terms. (b) A Member giving such a notice of motion shall at the same time lay before the House a statement of reasons in support of the motion together with any documentary materials relevant to that statement. (c) On the notice being given, the Speaker must immediately advise the justice who is the subject of the allegations of the terms of the notice of motion and provide the justice with a copy of all relevant documents tabled in relation thereto and invite him or her to make a written response. (d) The Speaker shall give consideration to the terms of the notice of motion, the statement in support together with any relevant documents, and any response from the justice made in response to the provisions of paragraph (c), and, if the Speaker forms the opinion that: (i) the allegations against the justice are clearly laid out; (ii) the facts alleged are such that, if they were to be proven, they could lawfully form a basis for the removal of the justice on the ground of misbehaviour or incapacity; and (iii) either the facts alleged have been established, or there are reasonable grounds for believing the conduct alleged may have occurred and that examination of this possibility would be justified; the Speaker must grant precedence to the moving of the motion. (e) At the first sitting day occurring fourteen days after the justice has been advised of the motion, whether the justice has responded or not, the Speaker must advise the House of whether precedence is to be granted to the moving of the motion. (f) If the Speaker declines to grant precedence to the moving of the motion the Member who gave the notice may, without notice, thereupon move that the House disagree with the Speaker's opinion, but unless that motion is carried the notice of motion for the address shall not be moved and it shall be removed from the Notice Paper. (g) If the House votes to disagree with the Speaker's opinion, the notice of motion shall be dealt with as if the Speaker had granted it precedence. (h) Following the moving of the motion for the address: (i) the debate on the motion must be immediately adjourned; (ii) the Speaker must immediately refer the allegations in the motion, together with all materials tabled with it and any response by the justice, to the Parliamentary (Judicial Behaviour or Incapacity) Commission; and (iii) until the House receives a report from the Commission on the matter referred no further debate on the motion shall be permitted. (i) When the Speaker receives the report of the Commission on the matter referred, he or she must, as soon as practical, present the report to the House. A copy of the report shall be provided to each Member, and arrangements made for the inspection by any Member, at his or her request, of any original document or exhibit referred to in the report. (j) If the report of the Commission concludes that facts do not exist amounting to proved misbehaviour or incapacity such as would warrant the removal of the justice, there shall be no further debate on the motion for the address and it shall be removed from the Notice Paper. (k) If the report of the Commission concludes that facts exist amounting to proved misbehaviour or incapacity such as would warrant the removal of the justice, debate on the motion shall resume immediately and the debate shall be given priority over all other nonurgent parliamentary business until disposed of. (l) Before the question on the motion for the address is put to the House for decision, the justice whose conduct is the subject of the report, or counsel on his or her behalf, shall be permitted to address the House from the Bar of the House, if he or she so requests. (m) A Member who, deliberately or recklessly, puts forward baseless allegations against a justice under this standing order is guilty of contempt of the House. (n) In addition to action under any other procedures available to punish contempts, a Member who, in the opinion of the House has deliberately or recklessly put forward baseless allegations against a justice under this standing order shall be suspended from the service of the House, on motion being moved without notice, for a period of 7 days, or such greater period as may be specified in the motion.
